Isn't that... dangerous?
Stealing from the mob? You bet it is. You get caught and I kiss the world good-bye.
Then the trick is not to get caught.
You guys are nuts, you know that? For one thing, the money is kept in a safe.
What kind of safe?

I don't know. It's in the countroom and there's a guard outside the door, twenty-four hours a day. And even if you're able to get past him, there's still the little problem of the two countmen inside.
I'll get a look at the safe.
And we'll figure out a way to deal with the guard...
... and the countmen...
... and anything else that comes along.
Then we're agreed?
Absolutely.
I'm in.
Me, too.
Okay.
Sure.
Let's do it.
Let me get this straight. You're going to knock over the casino and swipe a cool million from the mob?
You want your lounge back or not?
Deal me in.
Have you ever seen a prettier shade of green?
Looks like you had a very profitable night.
And the night's not over.
Is this for me or am I just keeping it warm for you?
It's all yours, baby. And there's more where that came from.
I'll take your word for it.
What are you looking at?
Nothing.
That's right. Now keep counting. After you, sweetheart.
Are you sure you didn't go to high school in Asheville, North Carolina?
Positive.
That's funny, you look just like the captain of our football team. I had such a crush on him.
You know I played a little football...
I knew it. You have the body of an athlete.
You call this a cheesesteak? I wouldn't feed this to my parole officer.
Cicci -- can I have a word with you?
One second. Now I want a cheesesteak and I don't care if you gotta fly to Philadelphia to get me one.
I'm telling you, a guy can starve to death in this town.
Ezri, this is Tony Cicci.
Nice to meet you.
The pleasure is all mine.
Ezri's new in town and needs a job.
I'm a very good waitress.
Yeah? You wouldn't happen to have a slice of pizza on you?
No, but I'll go the kitchen and get you one.
That chef wouldn't know a good pizza if it hit him in the face. All right, consider yourself gainfully employed.
Really? That's wonderful.
I owe you one, Cicci.
Don't mention it, Stretch. Maybe one day you could show me how to...
I don't believe it.
That monkey must have a death wish.
Take it easy, pallie. I'm not looking for trouble.
That's a relief.
I'm here to see Frankie... I want to try to work things out with him. You know, let bygones be bygones.
... Frankie, I'm dying here. The Sands, the Dunes, the D.I., no one'll even return my call.
Tell me something I don't know.
There's got to be a way for us to bury the hatchet.
I already did. In your head.
Frankie... you want me to beg? I'll beg. Give me a chance to make things right. I know people. People with dough. High rollers. I could bring 'em into the casino.
What? You want to be my shill?
I'm talking about people who can drop ten, twenty, thirty big ones a night.
Oh, give him what he wants -- I can't take much more of his whining.
Bring in a couple of players, then we'll talk.
That's all I ask. Let me buy you a drink.
I don't bet with losers. Come on, dollface. Let's warm up the poker table.
Welcome back.
You're in charge of what?
Of distracting the guard so we can sneak someone into the countroom.
Kas, I can't believe you're involved in this... the whole thing is ridiculous.
I guess that means you're not going to wish me luck.
And you're telling me that virtually my entire senior staff is part of this nonsense?
You're supposed to help your friends when they're in trouble. And Vic -- hologram or not -- is in trouble. Not that I'd expect you to care.
Look... this is not about Vic Fontaine.
Then what's your problem?
You want to know? I'll tell you. It's Las Vegas, nineteen sixty- two! That's my problem.
In nineteen sixty-two, brown people weren't made to feel very welcome there.
Oh, sure they could be performers or janitors, but customers? Never.
Maybe it was like that in the real Vegas, but that's not how it is at Vic's. I've never felt uncomfortable there -- and neither has Jake.
But don't you see, that's the lie. In nineteen sixty-two, the Civil Rights movement was still in its infancy. It wasn't an easy time for our people and I don't want to pretend that it was.
Baby -- I know Vic's isn't a totally accurate representation of how things were. But it isn't meant to be. It shows the way things could've been. The way they should've been.
We can't ignore the truth about the past.
Going to Vic's isn't going to make us forget who we are or where we came from. What it does is remind us that we're no longer bound by any limitations... ... except the ones we impose on ourselves.
What about Worf?
He'll never agree to it.
There's always Quark...
I'm not sure he'd help. He thinks of you as his competition.
I'll get it.
We're still one man short.
We need a high roller that Vic can bring to the casino. Someone who can draw a crowd. Keep everyone's attention off the countroom.
Otherwise the whole plan falls apart.
And we can't let that happen.
Now what exactly do you need me to do?
Let's go over it one more time.
Do we have to? Everyone knows what they have to do, right?
It's all pretty simple really.
Hey, far be it from me to tell Starfleet officers how to do their jobs.
Robbing casinos isn't part of any Starfleet job description I've ever read.
We can't afford to make any mistakes.
And we're not going to. Take us through it again.
You got it, pallie. It all begins with you --
-- keeping Frankie Eyes away from the casino and the countroom.
Meanwhile, the captain and I will be laying down some heavy bread over at the craps table. Enough to draw a crowd.
Where are we going to get that kind of money?
I put a little away for a rainy day.
Now each night, at precisely eleven forty-five...
Al, one of the countmen, takes a break to call home.
He never varies his routine. He's gone for six minutes every night.
During those six minutes, Howard, the other countman, has a martini brought in.
That's where I come in. But first, I make a stop at poker table three.
Where I hand a drink to Julian.
And I slip a few drops of ipecac into Howard's.
After which, I continue on to the countroom.
I set the tray down, and leave.
Now, once Ezri's out of the countroom --
-- I go running up to the guard and tell him that Chief O'Brien has stolen my purse.
Don't be afraid to turn on the waterworks.
And Chief -- you play innocent.
I am innocent! I've never seen this woman before in my life.
That's the ticket. Now remember, the two of you have to keep that guard away from the door for at least two minutes.
Once he takes a sip of his drink, Howard will come flying out of that countroom at warp speed.
Which is where I come in.
With those fabulous Ferengi ears of yours.
And once I've opened the safe --
-- you'll need someplace to put all that money.
You're going to be surprised how much a million bucks weighs.
I think I can handle it.
When you walk into the casino, don't talk to anyone -- don't even look at anyone. And whatever you do, don't run. Just head for the exit and dump the cash in the garbage cans outside.
Without the money, there's no skim to give to Mister Zeemo, and ol' Frankie becomes yesterday's news.
And then, everything returns to normal and we can pop the champagne.
Music to my ears, pallie.
Six minutes. That's how long we have to get into the countroom, open the safe, grab the money, and get out again.
I bet we can be out of there in five.
When do we "pull off the caper?"
The sooner, the better.
Zeemo's due in two days.
Then we have no choice. We go tomorrow night.
Crazy.
That was fast.
It has to be.
Two minutes, fourteen seconds.
I've got to do a lot better than that.
Right.
Better finish getting dressed. It's almost time.
I'm telling you, Morn...
... there's something going on in Vic's that we don't know about.
Looking good, as usual, dollface.
I'm glad you like what you see.
I only wish I could see more.
They say good things come to those who wait.
Who are "they" and how much of you have they seen?
I never kiss and tell.
I bet you don't. So what do you say we blow some of my money at the craps table?
Maybe later. Right now, I want you to buy me a drink. We can play footsies under the table.
Footsies? I guess it's a start anyway.
Nineteen. Let's see you beat that.
Twenty-three. You're busted.
Vodka martini, stirred not shaken.
Right away, sir.
Ten thousand.
Good luck to you, sir. (Craps TECH).
A hundred dollars?
Too much?
You're supposed to be a high roller. So start rolling. Make it two thousand.
Dice are coming out. (CRAPS TECH at will.)
Four. The point is four.
Another two thousand on four, the hard way.
Snake eyes. Shooter is a loser, field is a loser, pass line is a loser.
That's why they call it gambling.
I have not yet begun to fight.
We have a new shooter.(CRAPS TECH.)
Here's where things get interesting.
Dice are coming out.
C'mon, seven --
... and this is the hand that shook the hand of Bugsy Siegel. The man who built Las Vegas -- I'm telling you he was a visionary and is there even one statue of the guy in this town?
There's no justice.
You can say that again. You sure you don't want to play the tables for a while?
I'm perfectly content right here.
Who am I to argue with a lady.
Seven twice. The shooter's on a roll.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: Let it ride.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: We have lift off.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: Your drink, sir.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: I'm so sorry.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: Don't worry about it.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: You're too kind.
scene: 71   INT. CASINO - ANGLE ON SISKO - NIGHT

quote: You're not Howard.
He's out with the flu.
Then I guess this drink is yours.
I'm not thirsty.
But...
Hey, you're making me lose count.
Sorry. Mind if I drink that? I've been on my feet for hours, I could use a little pick-me-up.
That's about the saddest story I've ever heard.
Now get lost.
What? No tip?
Beat it!
You've got to help me. That man -- he stole a stack of my chips.
Hey, you! Stop right there!
Me?
This lady says you stole her chips.
I did no such thing.
Liar! I'm telling you, he took them. You're a thief!
And you're a drunk!
I'm not!
All right -- everyone just calm down.
Not until I get my money!
Uh-oh.
What do you mean, "uh-oh." We don't have time for an uh-oh.
This safe... it has an auto- relock tumbler. Kira didn't mention anything about an auto- relock tumbler.
She obviously didn't know about it.
Four minutes... that's not enough time.
It's all we have.
You in some kind of hurry?
Me?
You keep staring at that watch.
Really? I hadn't noticed.
And your drink... you haven't touched it.
The night is young. I've got to pace myself.
Pace yourself for what?
Frankie, there's someone here to see you.
I'm busy.
You don't look busy.
Mister Zeemo.
We weren't expecting you until tomorrow.
I'm early. You got a problem with that?
Not at all. Sit down, have a drink.
We'll drink later. Where's the countroom.
Follow me.
Mister Zeemo.
It's a great honor to meet you.
I know.
Frankie's told me all about you...
The money, Frankie.
Right this way.
Nog, it's been five and a half minutes, we're running out of time.
(to the guard, re: O'Brien) What are you standing around for? Arrest him. He stole two hundred dollars worth of chips from me.
Then how come all I have on me is this lousy five bucks?
Don't believe him.
I'm telling you, this broad ain't playing with a full deck.
Beginner's luck.
(sotto, looking at his watch) Six minutes.
I wonder what's taking them so long?
I fold.
Excuse me. Is your name "Al?"
Who wants to know?
Frankie Eyes. He's waiting for you. In the lobby.
What for? I didn't do nuthin'.
Then you have nothing to worry about.
You gotta be kidding me...
Now what?
Zeemo?
He's a day early. Keep playing, I'll try to stall them.
Nina? Is that you?
Who's this?
Nobody. Take a walk.
Where've you been keeping yourself, baby?
Do I know you?
Do you know me? Don't you remember that week in Miami? Ever see what she looks like in a bikini? Mama, mia...
When were you in Miami?
I don't know what he's talking about.
(to the blonde, re: Zeemo) Who's this? Your grandpa?
Frankie.
Cicci!
Now you've done it.
"Piece of cake."
Bury him.
I'm still waiting for my money, Frankie.
Tonight everyone's a winner.
Look, it's raining money.
Can I go now?
You're not going anywhere! Don't let him leave.
(urgently waving another guard over) Charlie, over here!
Take this gentleman to security.
But I want you to handle this.
I'm afraid I can't leave my post. (to Charlie, re: O'Brien) Strip search.
Strip search?
C'mon, now, there's no need for that.
I needed that money to buy a gift for my mother...
Strange way to run a casino.
What are you waiting for, Frankie? Take Mister Zeemo to the countroom.
You heard the lady.
I'm telling you, Mister Zeemo, buying this hotel was the smartest move you ever made. We've been making money hand over fist.
So you keep saying.
I just hope you brought a big enough briefcase...
Where's my money?
But Zeemo, honey -- we just got here!
And now we're leaving. I want to hear all about your trip to Miami.
I swear, I've never been there...
Now that's more like it.
Say good-bye to Frankie Eyes.
You can tell Felix we've shut the lid on his jack-in-the-box.
With pleasure.
Ladies and gentlemen, the bubbly's on me.
Where've you been?
I don't want to talk about it.
(to Bashir and O'Brien) The next time you two fight the battle of the Alamo... count me in. Coonskin cap and all.
You got it, pallie.
To the best friends a hologram ever had.
I owe you. Big time.
I just want to say, I never doubted for a second that you'd be back.
Neither did I.
(to Ezri and Worf, re: Bashir) Don't believe him. He was Mister Doom and Gloom the entire time you were away.
Maybe I was a little concerned.
We were all concerned. Your well- being was a constant source of conversation and speculation.
You see, I told you they'd miss us. So who won the betting pool?
Morn. He guessed the exact day when you'd be back and only missed your arrival time by two hours.
He's amazing.
I don't know how he does it.

I know what you're going to say and the answer is yes, I left the station without your permission, and yes, I lost a runabout, but I did rescue Worf from the Dominion... well, maybe rescue isn't the right term... but I did find him...
We'll evaluate your actions later, old man. Right now --
-- I want you to tell me everything you've learned about this Dominion-Breen Alliance.
I'm afraid we have very little information to share, captain.
Weyoun and the others were more interested in asking questions than answering them.
What about Damar? Why do you think he helped you escape?
I'm not sure, but I'll tell you one thing -- he hates Weyoun.
The Cardassians are a proud people. But the Dominion treats them as second-class citizens.
I think Damar's worried that this new alliance with the Breen is going to weaken Cardassia's status with the Dominion even more. But whatever his reasons, we owe him our lives.
Who knows, maybe someday you can return the favor. (to Bashir, re: Ezri and Worf) I want you to run a complete medical workup on both of them.
Yes, sir. I can't tell you how good it is to see you again. The both of you...
Kira to Sisko.
Go ahead.
We just received a priority-one transmission from Starfleet Command. The Breen have attacked Earth.
I had a lot of friends in those buildings.
scene: 3    INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - ON MATTE PAINTING (OPTICAL)

quote: Starfleet was able to destroy most of the Breen attack force, but by then the damage had been done.
scene: 3    INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - ON MATTE PAINTING (OPTICAL)

quote: We must give the enemy credit. To launch an attack against Starfleet Headquarters. Even my people never attempted that. We've learned one thing about the Breen today, captain. They're a race of warriors.
scene: 3    INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - ON MATTE PAINTING (OPTICAL)

quote: And that's about all we know. Our intelligence reports are sketchy at best.
scene: 3    INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - ON MATTE PAINTING (OPTICAL)

quote: Captain -- every species has its weakness. They're no exception.
scene: 3    INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - ON MATTE PAINTING (OPTICAL)

quote: Let's hope you're right. But whatever their weakness is... we'd better find it soon.
scene: 3    INT. CAPTAIN'S OFFICE - ON MATTE PAINTING (OPTICAL)

quote: (pointing at the readout) There. Do you see that? The news from Earth keeps getting better. The Federation casualty reports are being revised upward once again.
Well put. The casualties are merely a bonus. What matters is that we've struck fear into the hearts of our enemy and left them feeling weak and vulnerable. (very satisfied, to Thot Gor)
General, please congratulate your troops for us. They've done a superb job. Don't you agree, Damar?
Superb.
It's just unfortunate that so few of your ships survived the assault.
Leave it to you, Damar, to point out the one cloud in the sky.
My thoughts exactly. It's a very small price for such an important victory. Now, if you'll excuse me, I must make my report to the Founder.
By the way, in case Weyoun has neglected to mention it... the Dominion once sang Cardassia's praises as well.
It's really quite simple... they expected the war to be over long ago. It's not. And for that, they blame us. Now, if the war doesn't end soon, they'll shift the blame to you.
Maybe so, but win or lose, I wouldn't turn my back on Weyoun if I were you.
Enter.
The information you requested.
Excellent. Have a seat.
I'm not sure it's wise for me to stay. What if the Vorta decides to pay you a visit?
And what if he does? He'll find me in conference with one of my officers. There's nothing suspicious about that.
It doesn't seem right... all this plotting and secrecy. What are we? Romulans?
No, we're Cardassians. But right now, Cardassia is an occupied territory. And to defeat an occupying army takes careful planning and secrecy.
Can we really hope to defeat the Dominion? With the Breen on their side, they're stronger than ever.
But we'll be fighting to win back our homes and our freedom. That will make us even stronger.

I remember the day I heard the news that Cardassia had joined the Dominion... Like everyone else, I rejoiced. We were going to be rulers of the Alpha Quadrant. Instead, we're a conquered people... servants in our own land.
All that is about to change. Now you're sure we can trust these officers?
And the troops under their command. Still, it's not a very long list, is it?
It'll get longer. A victory or two and all of Cardassia will rise up with us.
We'll need to know the exact location of the Dominion weapon emplacements on Rondac Three.
Leave that to me. Now, I want you to send a message to every officer on this list...
Kas -- what happened?
That's what I'm trying to figure out.
What're you doing? You don't cook!
I know... I was just making sure.
My peppers?
I know how much you like roasted peppers in your casserole.
It took me three months to grow them.
(still can't believe it) No one touches my peppers.
I'm so sorry.
With all the bad news about Earth... I just wanted to do something nice for you. (handing him the apron) But from now on, you wear the apron in the family.
Good idea.
I'm glad you're not mad. I'd hate anything to ruin our last few nights together.
Last few nights?
My cargo run. I'm leaving early next week.
You're not going anywhere. It's too dangerous.
Ben -- the Breen attacked Earth. That's not exactly next door.
We don't know where they're going to strike next. I'd feel better having you close by.
That's sweet. But I'm going anyway.
I can't talk you out of it?
Not a chance.
C'mon -- help me clean out those pots.
Can't we just replicate new ones?
You really don't know anything about cooking, do you?
-- regarding your scheduled retreat to the Calash monastery.
Cancel it.
Very well. Now, about your appearance before the Vedek Assembly.
Cancel that, too.
Cancel an appearance before the Vedek Assembly?
Just do it. Cancel everything.
As you wish. May I ask what exactly you will be doing?
You certainly may not. (controlling her temper) But if you must know, I'll be devoting most of my time to study and meditation.
I see.
Solbor, I'll have my breakfast in here this morning. Eminence, would you care for anything?
I'm not hungry.
But you should eat. After all, Bajor is only as strong as its Kai --
I said I wasn't hungry.
Do as he asks. And please, write a note to the Vedeks, expressing my sincere apologies for having to postpone our meeting.
(pleased by her concern) I'll see to it immediately.
What a tiresome little man.
Sometimes, I think you forget your place, Anjohl.
Forgive me if I've offended you in any way. I am but a moon made warm by the light of your sun.
I hope you're a better farmer than you are a poet.
Something's wrong... tell me what's bothering you?
Everything! The prayers... the rituals... these robes -- I can't keep pretending I follow the path of the Prophets any longer!
You won't have to. The Pah- wraiths are waiting to embrace you.
So you keep saying -- but when is it going to happen?
As soon as we release them from the fire caves.
Release them? But... the prophecies...
What about them?
They warn that the release of the Pah-wraiths will mean the end of Bajor.
The old Bajor, perhaps. But a new Bajor will arise from its ashes and the Restoration will begin.
And who will be left to see it?
Those that the gods find worthy. It will be the dawn of paradise. And you... you are destined to rule it.
You're sure of this?
It is meant to be.
And what will become of you?
I will be by your side for as ong as you need me. But first, we have to release the Pah- wraiths...
And how do we do that?
The answer is in the text of the Kosst Amojan.
But it is forbidden for anyone to open that book.
Anyone except the Kai.
It is said to contain great evil...
You have nothing to fear. I'll be right there with you.
Did I say I was afraid?
Right here. The wooden palisade on the south wall...
If we could make that part of the compound less vulnerable...
What are you talking about, Julian? It wasn't the south wall that was a problem. They came over the north wall. By Travis's position.
I know where they came over, Miles -- I'm Travis, remember? I say we strengthen the south wall, the north wall, and anything else that'll help keep the enemy out.
But if we do that, it wouldn't be the battle of the Alamo, now would it?
I don't care. I just want to win -- just once.
Then be Santa Anna. He wins every time.
Maybe if we put more cannon in the long barracks...
What are you doing? Do you know how long it took me to build this thing?
I don't believe the two of you. Your homeworld has been attacked. The Breen have joined forces with the Dominion. And you sit there calmly playing games.
Haven't you ever heard of grace under pressure?
But shouldn't you be doing something more productive?
I just spent fourteen hours recalibrating the station's weapons array.
And I just finished a complete run-through of the emergency support team protocols.
Then you do expect an attack on the station?
Anything's possible. (to O'Brien, re: the model) What if we build a moat?
A moat? Around the Alamo?
All we have to do is widen that stream -- maybe make it a little deeper.
I say we build a moat around the station. Tell me the truth, do you think this place can withstand an attack by the Breen?
Good question.
How about a good answer -- like "yes, we can withstand an attack by the Breen"?
Quark... I could say that. But I'd be guessing.
Guessing?
What he means is that there's a good chance we're going to lose the station, lose the war, and wind up dead in the process.
Then how can you sit there enjoying yourselves pretending nothing's wrong.
Grace under pressure. Haven't you been listening?
He is a child.
Miles does have a certain cherubic quality...
I am talking about Doctor Bashir, and you know it. Are you certain he's the one?
I'm not certain about anything. But he is handsome.
You deserve more than "handsome." He gets excited playing with toys.
He knows how to have a good time. Besides, it's not exactly a toy... you heard Chief O'Brien, he spent hours building it.
I see it is hopeless to try to reason with you.
I know. Maybe I am in love with him. You think I should tell him how I feel?
If that will make you happy, yes.
You're a good friend, Worf.

I know. (then after a beat of looking back at Bashir) They are wasting their time. No matter how much planning they do, they cannot successfully defend that mission against an enemy numbering in the thousands. Not without more men.
If you want to go over there and help them...
Just a thought.
Damar? You're up early.
Am I?
Yes, you are. Unless you haven't gone to bed yet.
Actually, I had a very restful sleep.
Did you? How nice.
I had no idea the Breen could mobilize such a large fleet so quickly.
Our new allies are full of surprises, aren't they? You know those refrigeration suits they wear...
What about them?
I'm sure you've read the intelligence reports that say their homeworld is a frozen wasteland. Well, it's not true. The climate on their planet is quite comfortable.
Then why do they wear refrigeration suits?
They won't say. You see what I mean? They're full of surprises. There's something different about you today, Damar... I can't quite put my finger on it. It's like you're only half-dressed...
You don't have a bottle in your hand...
Don't you have anything better to do than to stand here and --
You've regained your confidence.
I wasn't aware I'd lost it.
Come now, Damar... you thought you'd backed the wrong side.
You thought the Dominion was going to lose this war... and drag Cardassia down with it.
You must admit, things were looking rather grim.
Perhaps for a moment or two... but that's no excuse to lose faith in oneself -- or in one's allies.

But now... it's as if you've groped your way through a dark tunnel and stepped into the light once again. And what does that light tell you? That the Dominion will prevail. That the Federation will be conquered and a new era of peace and prosperity will blanket the Alpha Quadrant.
You know me so well.
Really, Damar... I hope you won't allow that Cardassian-sized ego of yours to spoil our victory. And I do mean "our victory." Yours... mine...
And the Breen.
Yes, and the Breen.
We're just one big, happy family, aren't we?
I like it so much better when we agree on things, don't you?
The text of the Kosst Amojan. As you requested...
Very good.
Well? Put it on my desk.
Eminence. May I speak frankly?
If you must.
This book... it hasn't been removed from the archives -- not in seven hundred years.
Your point being?
The knowledge it contains... about the Pah-wraiths... it's said to be very dangerous.
Knowledge is never dangerous -- in the right hands.
There's an old saying... "He who studies evil, is studied by evil."
I'll keep that in mind. Now give me the book...
Your concern for her eminence is acknowledged and appreciated. Nevertheless, you must do as she says. I will see to it that no harm comes to her.
There. That should make you feel better.
I wish it did. But this man... he arrives one day on Deep Space Nine and the next, he's become your closest advisor. What do we know about him? Where does he come from? What does he want?
I want only to serve the Kai.
This is his idea, isn't it? To study that hateful book.
Anjohl was sent to me by the Prophets. That's all I need to know -- that's all anyone needs to know.
I have no idea why I was chosen. But who are we to question the ways of the Prophets?
Perhaps it would be best if you were to go to the temple and ask the Prophets forgiveness for questioning their wisdom.
Solbor --
The key.
Solbor doesn't approve of me.
He's served me well for many years.
And he may serve you for many more... if the Pah-wraiths find him worthy.
Well? Aren't you going to open it?
The Pah-wraiths aren't evil, but they are powerful.
And they're willing to share their power with you. The question is, do you want it?
This can't be...
It's a trick.
It's not a trick.
Then Solbor brought the wrong book.
He doesn't make those kinds of mistakes. The words are here... they've been hidden, that's all. Now it's up to us to find them.
Here are the new security protocols you requested.
giving them the once over) Very good.
Though frankly I'm not sure how effective they'll be against the Breen.
Neither am I. Let's hope we don't have to find out.
Benjamin!
You mind explaining this --
Constable, do you mind if we use your office a moment?
Looks like the Bajoran Freight and Shipping Authority wants you to take a vacation.
A month's paid vacation? This is your doing, isn't it? Let me guess, the Emissary asked for a little favor...
I never mentioned the word Emissary.
I'm just trying to keep you out of harm's way. Is that such a terrible thing for a husband to do?
I told you, I don't need or want that kind of protection. I want you to call whoever you called and have them put my name back on the active list.
Kas -- it's only for a month.
I don't care if it's only for a day. How'd you like it if I called Admiral Ross and said, "Do me a favor... please don't send my husband on any dangerous missions this month."
It's not the same thing.
It is from where I'm standing. My job is just as important to me as your job is to you.
I know that.
You don't act like you do. You crossed the line, Ben... this time you really crossed the line.
What's so funny?
Marriage. It changes everything. (re: Sisko and Kasidy) If you're not careful... that could be you and Kira.
Thank you. You can go now.
Eminence. I must inform you that the archivists are very concerned.
You heard the Kai, leave us.
They're wondering why you need to consult so many of these... dark texts.
Tell them that their Kai works for the good of Bajor. Now leave me, I have work to do.
(to Winn, re: Solbor) Something tells me that when the Restoration occurs, the Pah- wraiths are going to find that little man... unworthy.
Why are you still here?
What would you like me to do?
Go away.
I don't understand...
I need to concentrate.
But your eminence...
Not another word.
As you wish.
A Til'amin froth... thank you.
Actually, I had one waiting for you every day you were gone.
That's so sweet.
I know.
Do you have a minute?
Doctor -- Ezri and I were in the middle of a conversation.
I'm sorry. I'll wait for you to finish.
What were we talking about?
Forget it.
I guess we're finished. What can I do for you, Julian?
Have I offended you in any way?
What do you mean?
Ever since you and Worf returned to the station, it seems like you've been avoiding me.
I have?
It seems that way.
Julian... I'm not sure if I'm ready to talk about this right now.
I knew it. Something is wrong --
Would you stop saying that -- nothing's wrong. It's just... complicated.
Well, whatever it is -- I'm sure we can work it out.
You think so?
I'm positive.

Maybe you're right. Maybe we just need to bring this out in the open... talk it over like two adults. I mean, here we are... you over there, me over here... when you think about it, it's a perfect opportunity.
Ezri, please -- just tell me what's going on.
I'm getting to that...
Doctor Bashir, please report to the Infirmary.
On my way. Hold that thought.
They're beautiful...
Then you forgive me?
That depends. Have you talked to Bajoran Freight and Shipping?
You're back on the active list.
Then I forgive you. But from here on in...
(completing the thought) I won't interfere with your work again. Unless you ask me to. Or it's absolutely necessary.
I'm joking.
You better be.
What's that for?
The flowers. And for being big enough to admit when you're wrong.
That must be Quark with the necklace.
Necklace?
In case the flowers didn't work. Come in.
Ben, we just got word. The Breen have launched a counteroffensive against our forces in the Chin'toka System.
Have they broken through?
In two places.
When do I leave?
This is bad... very bad.
You say that every time we take the Defiant into battle.
Impulse manifold purged and clear. If we lose the Chin'toka System, we lose our only foothold in Dominion territory. I think that qualifies as "bad."
We haven't lost it yet. Initiating impulse pre-start sequence.
Microfusion generators on line. But the Breen... they seem unstoppable. First Earth, now Chin'toka.
Ensign -- no one is unstoppable. Collimate the nadion emitters.
Collimation sequence in progress.
What more can I say? I'm sorry.
Dilithium matrix is aligned and calibrated. From now on, be more careful. That's all I ask.
Opening antimatter injector ports. (re: O'Brien and Bashir's conversation) Trouble in paradise?
It's nothing. Emergency life support and damage control systems standing by.
Antimatter stream is stable. I wouldn't call it "nothing." (back to Kira and Ezri, re: Bashir) He lost Travis.
Sounds serious. Verify astrometric database.

Miles built this Alamo model, replete with little figures. Quite spectacular, actually. Datasets loaded and verified. Anyway, he was showing it to me in Quark's and somehow we -- or rather I misplaced Colonel Travis.
Phaser safeties engaged. Can't you make another one?
Why? So he can lose it again? Field stabilizers on-line.
That's what happens when you share your toys. Synchronizing warp plasma flow.
It's not a toy -- it's a model. Built to scale! Nacelles holding at pre-warp threshold.
He really did a fantastic job.
He plays with toys.
It's a model.
With little figures...
Autonomous guidance system initialized and active. (to Worf, re: Bashir) It's a form of therapy. He's under a lot of stress...
Look, when we get back, I'll go to Quark's and search every centimeter on my hands and knees. Satisfied?
It's a start.
Perhaps you should crawl around Quark's with him... if you find the Travis figure, I'm sure Doctor Bashir would be very grateful.
Would you please stop?
Commander.
The weapons array is on-line. Phasers are fully charged. Quantum torpedo launchers are loaded and standing by.
Colonel, set a course to rendezvous with the Federation assault fleet.
Course set.
Take us out.
Airlocks are sealed. Releasing docking clamps.
Where are you going with those?
I'm returning them to the archives.
On who's authority?
I believe her eminence has finished....
Put them back.
How dare you use that tone with me --
Very well, I'll put them back.
Wake up, my love. There's work to be done.
Anjohl? I must've dozed off...
You're tired. It's understandable.
I haven't made much progress...
You'll find the answers we're looking for. It's just a matter of time.
(taking comfort in his words) I'm glad you're here.
(smiling back at
According to the latest battle reports, it looks like the Dominion is going to retake Chin'toka.
A few months ago, the thought of driving the Federation from Cardassian soil would've been cause for celebration.
But their victories are no longer our victories.
Now, are the troops in position?
They're awaiting your command.
Excellent. We strike in seven hours.
We're going to lose many fine soldiers.
At least they will be dying for Cardassia -- not the Dominion.
The Federation reinforcements are approaching Chin'toka.
The more of them, the better.
Founder, it concerns me to have you this close to the front.
Your concern is noted. But this is one battle I intend to see firsthand.
Yes, it should be quite gratifying.
Sir, they've locked weapons on us.
Aye, sir.
Mister Worf -- quantum torpedoes.
Target acquired.
Fire!
What the hell -- ?
I've lost power to the helm.
The com's down.
So are weapons.
Primary computer systems are off-line!
Chief?
I can't get anything back on line. Somehow, they're draining all our power...
Sir -- the ablative armor is starting to buckle.
We have hull breaches on Decks Three and Four.
Without power for emergency forcefields, there's no way to seal them.
Abandon ship.
Captain...
She's a fine ship.
No one'll argue with that.
But like you said -- it's time to go.
Poor Captain Sisko... I believe he was quite fond of that ship. Founder... I'm happy to report that the Chin'toka System is ours once again.
A step in the right direction. Send my compliments to the Breen.
I'm sure that will please them greatly.
Really? I have no idea what pleases the Breen -- nor do I care, as long as they fight and win. I will not tolerate defeat any longer.
Nor will I.
Look at all those escape pods. So small... so vulnerable... I'll order their destruction immediately.
No. Let them return to the Federation. Those pods are filled with frightened, demoralized troops.
... troops that will spread fear throughout the Federation with tales of what happened here today. The Founder is wise.
There... don't you feel better?
Much. Thank you, Anjohl.
I'm here to serve you -- any way I can.
Get away from her! Eminence -- that man is not Anjohl Tennan.
What are you saying?
Anjohl Tennan died nine years ago in the labor camp at Batal. I warned you he wasn't to be trusted. I had a sample of his DNA sequenced -- he's not even a Bajoran, he's Cardassian!
We were brought together for a purpose -- a great purpose. Our destinies are linked.
Don't listen to him -- look in his eyes. Don't you recognize the face of your enemy? It's Gul Dukat!
It can't be...
He lied to you. Used you!
It's not true!
I don't know why you've done this -- for what evil purpose. But it's not going to work!
He doesn't understand -- he can't understand the love of the Pah- wraiths.
The love of the Pah-wraiths?
(shocked and appalled) You're trying to release them... that's why you wanted the text of the Kosst Amojan...
Solbor -- you must try to understand... all I want is to bring about the Restoration.
You've betrayed the Prophets... you've betrayed us all!
Listen to me -- the Pah-wraiths, they're the true gods.
You must be stopped...
Solbor -- I beg you.
No!
It's going to be all right.
Don't touch me. My life is over. The Pah-wraiths sent you to destroy me...
On the contrary. They sent me to save you.
Lies... nothing but Cardassian lies. To think I let you touch me...
The book... I have to destroy it!
The Pah-wraiths have judged you and found you worthy. Their secrets are now yours... to do with as you please.
Take their gift and use it -- seize the power they're offering you!
What about Solbor?
I'll take care of his body.
The Defiant was the finest ship I ever commanded. There'll never be another one like her...
It may take a little while, but we'll get you another ship. That's a promise. I just wish I knew how we were going to neutralize the Breen energy dissipaters.
We need to buy some time.
Time may be the one thing we don't have...
Captain. We're monitoring a transmission from Cardassian space. I think you're going to find it interesting.
... and so two years ago, our government signed a treaty with the Dominion.
In it, the Dominion promised to extend Cardassia's influence
We've gained no new territories... in fact, our influence throughout the Quadrant has diminished... and to make matters worse, we're no longer masters in our own home.
Travel anywhere in Cardassia and what do you find? Jem'Hadar, Vorta... and now Breen. Instead of being the invaders, we've become the invaded. Our "allies" have conquered us without firing a shot.
Well, no longer. This morning, detachments of the Cardassian First, Third, and Ninth Orders attacked the Dominion outposts on Rondac Three.

-- homeland from the true oppressors of the Alpha Quadrant -- the Dominion. So I call upon Cardassians everywhere -- resist! Resist today. Resist tomorrow! Resist until the last Dominion soldier has been driven from our soil. Resist!
It's confirmed. Our cloning facilities on Rondac Three have been destroyed. I could be the last Weyoun... That's why he picked that target.
I want Damar and the rest of these traitors found and eliminated.
I'll see to it immediately.
I don't care how many Cardassians you have to kill. Find Damar. Is that clear?
I'm going to hold you to that.
Captain, our listening posts have confirmed the attack on Rondac.
Damar may have just bought us some precious time... if the Dominion doesn't track him down too quickly.
We have to find a way to help him. Legate Damar may be the key to saving the Alpha Quadrant.
(moving to the replicator) How long was I asleep?
Almost two hours.
You dropped out of warp -- we must be getting close to home.
We entered the Bajoran system a few minutes ago.
What's that?
The shopkeeper I bought it from called it a knickknack.
I didn't know you collected knickknacks.
It's a present for Kira.
You don't think she'll like it?
I'm sure she will. It's just... I didn't get anything for Keiko.
(trying to make him feel better) The conference kept you pretty busy...
You made time to get something.
Not chocolates too?
Rigelian chocolates. Her favorite.
I'll buy them from you.
I beg your pardon?
I'll buy them from you. Come on, Odo, you don't need to give Kira two presents. We were only gone a day.
I'm sorry, but the answer's no.
There's something behind us.
And it's gaining fast.
You think it's friendly?
I hope so.
It certainly seems to have taken an interest in us.
Uh-oh.
It's gone.
What?
According to the sensors, there's nothing out there.
Where'd it go?
A changeling.
Stay where you are, or I'll fire.
You -- you're a Metamorph?
I'm a changeling, yes.
Tell the mono-form to put down its weapon.
Why did you board our ship?
Because I sensed you were here. I had to see if it was true -- if I'd finally found another Metamorph.
You've never met another Shape-shifter?
I've been trying to find others of my kind for a long time.
(brandishing his phaser) I told you to stay where you were.
How do we know he's not a Founder?
He isn't. (trusting his instincts) He's one of the hundred.
The hundred?
Over the centuries, our people sent a hundred "infant" changelings out into the galaxy. We were to learn about other species, and eventually return home to share what we'd experienced.
That would explain why I was alone on Varala. I didn't even know what I was at first... or that I could assume other forms.
I was the same way.
Odo, I hate to interrupt... but shouldn't we get him in a containment field until we're sure he's telling the truth?
I'll allow myself to be taken prisoner to show my good faith, but only if you vouch for my safety. I don't trust humanoids.
Where's is he now?
In a holding cell.
Captain, he's not a threat to us. He's just a changeling who's traveled a long way to find out where he came from.
So you believe his story?
Yes, sir.
How can we be sure he's not a Founder?
If he were, he'd be infected with the same disease that's afflicting the entire Link. I had Doctor Bashir scan him. His morphogenic matrix is as stable as mine.
Sir, with your permission, I'd like to release him.
Constable, I'm sure you can appreciate why I'd have reservations about that. We're at war with your people. And the Founders have deceived us before.
I realize that. But he's not a Founder. He's one of the hundred, I'm sure of it. Sir, I'm asking you to trust me on this.
All right, Constable.
I'm releasing him into your custody.
Thank you, sir.
-- when I found out our people were the leaders of the Dominion, I realized I had no place with them. This war they're fighting is wrong.
I can understand their distrust of humanoids, but why try to conquer them? (glancing at the passersby) Better to avoid them altogether.
You don't much care for humanoids.
I know from experience they don't much care for changelings.
I think you'll find the people here are different.
Oh?
They've accepted me.
Have they? Is that why you've stayed?
I told you, I want no part of the Founders.
But what about the hundred that were sent out -- haven't you ever tried to find any of them?
No.
It's a big galaxy. They could be anywhere.
I found you.
I have a life here, friends.
When did you first take humanoid form?
A little over thirty years ago.
So that's it. This is all still new to you. I spent the first part of my life living among humanoids, as well.
How long ago was that?
Over two hundred years. I must've been sent out earlier than you.
(trying to make sense of it) Or it could be that I was adrift for a long time before I was found.
Either way, it explains why you've chosen to stay here. I was fascinated by humanoid life in the beginning, too.
But you... lost interest.
I found it... limiting. The Varalans never accepted me as one of them. I wasn't able to fully mimic their appearance.
Faces aren't easy.
No. And humanoids aren't very tolerant of difference.
Some of them are. There are dozens of species living on this station, and they tolerate each other's differences quite well.
He has bumps on his forehead and she has a wrinkled nose -- but they're basically alike. They're bipeds that eat, sleep and breathe. You and I are nothing like them.
We're changelings. We can be like them when we choose.
I choose to do so as little as possible. That's where we differ.
Why don't I show you where you'll be staying?
You haven't told me your name.
The Varalans called me Laas. In their language it means "changeable." Not very imaginative, is it?
At least it's appropriate. My name means "unknown sample." The scientist who found me didn't know what I was.
These are my quarters. I'll be staying... (with Kira, but he'd rather not get into it) -- somewhere else. Feel free to shape-shift as you please.
Some of these forms are quite interesting.
This hasn't been used in some time.
I've been busy.
Who's this?
Her name's Kira.
I had a mate once.
Oh?
On Varala. Not long after I assumed humanoid form.
What happened?
We couldn't have children. That was important to her.
Is it something that matters to this Kira?
We've never discussed it.
Neither did we, at first.
Do our people reproduce?
It's a little more complicated than that. In our natural state, we don't exist as separate entities.
I don't understand.
Our people spend most of their time in the Link.
The Link?
It involves... a melding into one -- the merging of thought and form, idea and sensation.
You're speaking in riddles.
It's difficult to explain.
Then don't. Show me.
Of course.
Take it.
For the first time in my life... I understand how I was meant to exist...
You've given up a great deal to stay here.
I have. But I won't have anything to do with the Founders and their war.
Odo, we Linked. I know the truth. You've stayed because of Kira. If it wasn't for her, you'd be with our people. War or no war, you'd be a Founder.
Hi.
Hello, Nerys.
I can't believe it. Another changeling. What's he like?
He's... complicated.
Like you.
Are you all right?
I'm fine.
You seem... far away.
We Linked.
I see.
There's nothing to worry about. He's not a Founder, he's not trying to lure me to the Dominion.
The Link is part of what we are. It comes as naturally to us as talking does to humanoids.
It's a little more... personal than talking, isn't it?
I suppose...
So. Do I get to meet him?
If you like.
I would.
Then I'll arrange it.
There they are.
This is Laas.
Ezri.
Miles.
We've met.
Look, I'm sorry. We didn't know who you were at first. You gave us a bit of a scare when you rammed the runabout.
I've always wondered how it would feel to be able to fly through space like that.
It's a shame you're incapable of experiencing it.
Guess so...
Tell us about Varala.
No Federation ship's ever been there.

It's just like any other planet that's overrun with humanoids. Cities and farms everywhere -- other lifeforms displaced from their habitats. I once migrated to the southern continent with a herd of volg. By the time we returned to the breeding grounds the next summer, they'd been fenced off. The herd died out within two generations.
It's the same on any planet where humanoids thrive. They disrupt the natural balance.
Who ordered the vilm-steak?
Just... keep it warm for me.
Whatever you say...
The truth is, I prefer the so- called primitive lifeforms. They exist as they were meant to, following their instincts. No words to get in the way, no lies or deceptions.
We're not the ones who can disguise ourselves as anything we want.
Meaning?
Meaning Shape-shifters aren't to be trusted.
I trust Odo.
Of course you trust Odo. Look at him. You've convinced him that he's as limited as you are.
Laas.
He's seen through our evil plan.
Foiled again.
It's not funny.
No, I'm worried for him.
Odo can take care of himself.
Well. Thank you, colonel. It's been interesting. We should be going now. If you'll excuse us, colonel, counselor, chief, doctor. I'm glad we came by. (turning to the door) Laas...
Nice to see you again.
Was it really necessary to insult my friends?
I was merely speaking my mind.
You could call it that.
Humanoids are tragic creatures. They've lost the ability to take joy from simply existing... yet they haven't evolved to the next level -- where consciousness exists independent of form.
You're certainly not afraid to make grand generalizations.
I've been many things in my time. I speak from experience.
Enough talk. Link with me.
Here?
Why not?
I don't think that's a good idea.
You're embarrassed.
No...
You don't want to do anything to remind them that you're not truly a humanoid.
I don't go out of my way to point it out, no.
Why? Are you afraid they'll reject you?
I don't like to confront people with something that might make them uncomfortable.
So you deny your true nature in order to fit in.
You're reading too much into it.
Before I came here, when was the last time you assumed another form?
You can't even remember. You've been pretending to be a humanoid for so long, it doesn't occur to you that you can be anything else.
That's not true. I've been involved with other things lately.
Like what? Courting Kira? She can't even Link with you.
Leave her out of this.
It won't last.
The fact that your relationship failed doesn't mean mine will.
True. If you're lucky, you'll get to watch her grow old and die.
I think you should stay out of my affairs.
Odo, I don't want to see you make the same mistakes I made. You're wasting your time trying to be a humanoid. You're limiting yourself.

Let's leave, Odo. Let's find the others. A hundred were sent away -- they're out there somewhere, and if we can find even a few of them, we can form a new Link. Think of it. We can exist the way we were meant to. As Changelings.
I can't believe he actually thought you'd drop everything and leave with him.
He just can't understand why I'd want to stay.
How'd he take it when you said no? You did say no, didn't you?
I told him I'd think about it. I didn't want to dismiss it out of hand. He would've taken offense.
Why are you looking at me like that?
It bothers me that he thinks you're not happy here. It makes me wonder if he knows something I don't.
What makes you say that?
He Linked with you.
Something about it must've given him the impression that you might want to leave.
It was just wishful thinking on his part. The thought of the two of us going off together to find the others -- -- exploring the galaxy as changelings, it's very alluring. To him.
Sounds like it's alluring to you, too.
I'm happy here.
I'm sorry I can't Link with you.
It doesn't matter, Nerys... I love you...
Computer, activate fire suppression sys--
Laas... ?
You didn't realize it was me. Did you even know we could exist as fire?
I didn't think so. No matter. Once we're away from here, I'll teach you to become things you've never even dreamed of.
I'm not leaving. I'm staying here.
Why? So you can keep pretending to be one of them?
I'm sorry if you're disappointed.
I'll survive. When I find some of the others, I'll send for you. You'll change your mind and join us.
It could be a long time before you find another Changeling.
Is that supposed to discourage me?
All I'm saying is that you don't have to leave right away.
I wouldn't mind the company of another Changeling. I'm sure you wouldn't either.
All right, Odo, I won't abandon you to these mono-forms. As a favor to you, I'll stay for a while.
You might as well. If you can't get along with me, what makes you think you'll get along with any other Changeling?
True enough. Just remember, I have no interest in mono-forms, even if they are your "friends."
After what happened in Quark's, I don't think you have to worry about an overcrowded social schedule.
Good.
Great. The environmental system's out again.
There goes our holosuite reservation...
I'm going to find out what the problem is.
Don't bother, Chief. There's nothing wrong with the environmental system.
Then where's this fog coming from?
It's not fog. It's Laas.
Laas?
What's he doing?
Being fog, what's it look like?
Can't he be fog somewhere else?
Or at night, when no one's around?
He's not hurting anyone.
Still. It's... creepy.
Careful, Miles. He might hear you.
Good.
Laas.
Laas.
Congratulations. You managed to disrupt the entire Promenade.
I was just relaxing.
If you want to "relax," do it in private.
Did I embarrass you?
Ka'vek!
What is that Founder doing here?
He's not a Founder. Now move along.
Don't change form in my presence again.
I change form where I please.
Look at him. Look at the hate in his eyes.
Laas.
Your hands are stained with the blood of Klingon warriors.
(raising his hands palm up) But then, the stench would still be on them.
P'tak!
Mine's bigger.
Ke'chaw!
Doctor Bashir wasn't able to save the Klingon's life. General Martok has asked that Laas be detained until the magistrate has determined jurisdiction.
Jurisdiction?
The Klingons want to extradite him.
That's ridiculous. He killed that Klingon in self-defense.
That is in dispute.
He was about to draw his disruptor.
According to the other Klingon, he was reaching for his dagger.
Are you saying that's not true?
It happened too fast. But their intentions were obvious. One of them put a knife in his chest.
The Klingons are arguing that since Laas knew he couldn't be harmed by a knife, he wasn't justified in responding with deadly force.
Since when do Klingons resort to legal quibbling? They get involved in fights all the time and never file charges. It isn't "honorable."
In this case, they're choosing to exercise their rights under the law.
Sir, they're only doing this because they distrust changelings.
He should not have provoked them.
Provoked them? They attacked Laas.
They're claiming that he "surrounded them menacingly."
They felt menaced? By fog?
They weren't the only ones. Twelve other people filed complaints.
Is it a crime to shape-shift on the Promenade?
It may not be a crime, but obviously it's not a good idea.
You're going to allow the Klingons extradite him... knowing they won't give him a fair trial...
It's not my decision. It's up to the magistrate.
But you'd just as soon be rid of him. You didn't want him on the station in the first place. I practically had to beg you to let him out of that holding cell.
That's enough, Constable.
Now. General Martok has expressed concerns about our security arrangements.
Meaning?
He doesn't feel it's appropriate that you be in charge of the prisoner.
May I ask why?
Because you're a witness to the alleged crime.
That's a relief. For a moment I thought you were going to say it's because I'm a changeling.
Odo. I heard about your friend. Rumor has it the Klingons want to put him on trial.
They're the ones who should be on trial. If they'd attacked anyone other than a changeling, they would be.
You're probably right.
That fog episode certainly didn't help matters.
He was only doing what comes naturally to us.
You've never pulled a stunt like that.
You're smart enough to know people don't want to be reminded that you're different. Who wants to see someone turn into goo? I hope you don't do that around Kira.
Why shouldn't I?

If she's anything like me. She'd rather you didn't. We humanoids are the product of millions of years of evolution. Our ancestors learned the hard way that what you don't know might kill you. They wouldn't have survived if they hadn't jumped back when they encountered a snake coiled in the muck. And now millions of years later, that instinct is still there.

It's genetic. Our tolerance for other lifeforms doesn't extend beyond the two arm, two leg variety. I hate to break it to you, but when you're in your natural state, you're more than our poor old genes can handle.
What are you saying, Quark? That the Klingons couldn't help what they did because of their genes?
I'm not trying to excuse what they did. I'm only telling you why it happened.
(concerned for his friend) Watch your step, Odo. We're at war with your people. This is no time for a changeling pride demonstration on the Promenade.
Constable.
I'd like to have a few minutes alone with the prisoner.
Sorry, sir. I have my orders.
I don't know what to say...
You could say that you were wrong. That the people here are no different from any other humanoids.
Hopefully this will all get straightened out at your hearing.
I'm sure it will be fair and impartial.
Just tell them exactly what happened.
My word against a humanoid's? Who do you think this magistrate is going to believe?
I shouldn't have convinced you to stay here. If I'd let you go, none of this would've happened.

My only consolation is that this may finally make you understand you don't belong here. You saw the hatred in that Klingon's eyes. Maybe now you'll recognize it when you see it hiding in the faces of your so-called friends.

They tolerate you because you emulate them. What higher flattery is there? "I, who can be anything, choose to be like you." But even when you make yourself in their image, they know that you aren't truly one of them. What you appear to be doesn't reflect what you really are. It's only a mask.
What lies underneath is alien to them. So they fear it... and their fear can turn to hate in the blink of an eye...
They're going to extradite him.
You don't know that.
Yes, I do. And no one's going to do anything to stop it.
There's not much anyone can do.
If he weren't a changeling, the captain would find a way to intervene.
That's not fair.
Isn't it?
You're starting to sound like Laas.
Maybe that's because I'm starting to see things more clearly now.
What does that mean?
(taking her by the shoulders) Look at me, Nerys. What do you see?
I see you.
No. This is just a form I've borrowed. I could just as easily be someone else or something else.
I know that. But... (taking his shoulders) ... this is what you've chosen to be. A man whose good and honorable. And who I fell in love with. Are you telling me that man never really existed?
I don't know...

I care about you more than anyone I've ever known... these last few months have been the happiest of my life. (a difficult admission) But even so, a part of me wishes that Laas and I were out there right now -- searching for the others, existing as changelings. Because that's what I am. Not a humanoid, a changeling.
You're right. Maybe you should be out there...
Can I help you, colonel?
I need to talk to the prisoner. Alone.
Aye, sir.
Go to the third planet in the Koralis System. There's an orbital tether running down to an abandoned mining complex. I'll tell Odo to meet you there.
Is this some kind of trick?
Do you want to get out of here or not?
That vent. It'll lead you through some conduits to an airlock.
Why?
Because I love him.
Escaped? How did he get through the containment field?
I can't explain it, all I can tell you is what I saw. He turned himself into some kind of... plasma energy and forced his way through. Before I could stop him, he disappeared into an air vent.
According to the operations log, one of the airlocks was activated shortly after that.
If he left the station, why didn't our sensors detect him?
A Corvallen Freighter was leaving at about the same time. He must have shadowed it to keep from being spotted.
He could be anywhere by now.
General Martok's not going to be happy about this...
By fleeing, the changeling has demonstrated his guilt.
Either that, or his lack of faith in our justice system.
He must be apprehended and brought to trial.
Have all available runabouts begin a sector-wide search.
Aye, sir.
Good luck...
It may be a long shot, but I'm sure you agree that we should do everything we can to find him.
Of course.
Dismissed.
Level Nine.
You didn't hide it very well. That you're glad he got away.
I should've known he'd be able to escape. What's a forcefield to a changeling with his abilities?
You said you wish you were out there with him. It's not too late.
I don't understand...
He's waiting for you. At an abandoned mine on Koralis Three.
You helped him escape...
I don't want you to stay here out of some sense of obligation. Good luck. I hope you find what you're looking for.
Laas... ?
I knew you'd come. This is a new beginning for us, Odo. A new beginning for our people. You and I are about to embark on the adventure of our lives.
What's wrong?
I'm not going with you.
Then why are you here?
I came to say good-bye.
Don't be a fool. What are you holding on to? Kira? Even she knows this is what's best for you. Why else would she have helped me escape?
You really don't know, do you? You don't have any idea of what it means to love someone enough to let them go.
She let you go so you could find out where you belong.
I know where I belong. Humanoids aren't the petty, limited creatures you perceive them to be. What Nerys did should prove that even to you.
Love conquers all, is that it?
I'm sorry you don't understand. You've done many things, been many things -- but you've never known love.
Compared to the Link, it's a pale shadow -- a feeble attempt to compensate for the isolation mono-forms feel because they're trapped inside themselves.
Maybe the fact that it's not easy is what makes it worthwhile.
Odo, the Founders are dying. This could be your last chance to exist as you were meant to. Don't throw it away.
You'd better go. They're looking for you.
Good luck...
And to you, Odo. You'll need it more than I.
Watch over him... help him find his way.
Yes.
I didn't think I'd see you again...
I couldn't go...
Odo, if I've ever made you feel that you can't be yourself when you're with me, I'm sorry. I want to know you -- the way you really are.
... that's why the lady... that's why the lady... that's why the laaaaaady is a scamp.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: So? What do you think?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Not bad, but the lady is a tramp, not a scamp.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Tramp, right. So do I get the "gig?"
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Sorry, pallie.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: But Doctor Bashir said you're looking for an opening act and I love to sing.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: I can tell. But two singers on the same bill... that's a one-way ticket to deadsville. I need someone to warm-up the audience for me -- you know, a comic.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: A comic?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: A comedian -- someone who can make people laugh.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: I can do that. My brother tells me people are always laughing at me.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: That may be true -- but this is a holosuite program, capice?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: So?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: So you're not a hologram.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Life can be so unfair.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Hey, Vic -- you got a minute?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Forget it, he's not hiring.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: What's wrong with him?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Showbiz -- it can break your heart. So what can I do for you, pallie?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Did you get a chance to make those audio recordings for me?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: All your favorite hits.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: That's great, Vic. Thanks.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: My pleasure -- but these songs are four hundred years old... you sure the troops on the front lines want to hear them?
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: The songs may be old, but when you sing them, they sound brand new.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: When you put it that way, I wish I was going on the supply run with you... I could make some personal appearances... sing a few songs, tell a few jokes... you know, put together a regular USO show.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Sorry Vic, but I'm afraid there aren't any holosuites where we're going.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: Rom's right... life can be unfair. You know, pallie -- sometimes being a hologram can be a real pain in the asometric photons.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: I'll see you when I get back.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: You know where to find me.
scene: 1    INT. HOLOSUITE - LAS VEGAS LOUNGE - NIGHT

quote: I thought I might find you here...
The new security protocols you requested.

I think that's what I'm going to remember most about this war... looking through casualty reports. Sometimes it feels like that's all I do... stare at the names of the dead. When the war started, I used to read every name... I felt it was the least I could do to honor their sacrifice. But lately, all the names have begun to blur together...
That's understandable.
Maybe...
Ops to Captain Sisko.
(touching his com badge) Go ahead, colonel.
The Defiant is ready for departure.
On my way.
Why me? Why did he have to send me? I'm like a son to him...
Quark -- you're mumbling again.
I'm sorry. (a beat, then mumbling again) It's just not fair... I have responsibilities of my own... customers who depend on me...
But the Grand Nagus himself picked you for this assignment.
Some assignment... a fact-finding mission to the front lines. Zek's already inundated with Starfleet intelligence reports. What can I tell him that he doesn't know?
Maybe he wants to hear things from a Ferengi perspective.
Then let him ask Nog.
The Nagus trusts you.
What are you trying to do? Cheer me up?
It's my job. Remember the thirty- fourth Rule of Acquisition, "War is good for business."
Only from a distance. The closer you are to the front lines, the less profitable it gets.
What's that?
Stay here.
Wait. Don't leave.
This is no time to be wandering the corridors.
I thought the Chin'toka System was in Federation hands.
It is, but the Dominion is determined to take back their territory. The entire system is a battleground.
I should probably be writing this down.
Mister O'Brien -- keep an eye out for more Jem'Hadar ships.
Aye, sir.
What are you doing here, uncle?
I... ah... just visiting.
I'm working.
Quark, is there something we can do for you?
Not really. I just came by to say hello to my nephew.
All right, you've just said hello...
Anybody want to join me in the mess hall for a raktajino?
Quark!
(making a hasty retreat) I was just leaving...
Sir, I assure you that won't happen again.
Your uncle's just a little nervous... he's not used to being in combat situations.
That's no excuse.
Captain, the supplies are ready for transport.
AR-Five-Five-Eight has acknowledged our message. They're expecting you.
Good. Away Team, with me. Commander, she's all yours.
Not much to look at, is it?
scene: 11A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP (OPTICAL)

quote: Those are Federation phasers... Hold your fire! This is Captain Benjamin Sisko of the USS Defiant.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: You heard him -- cease fire, damn it!
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: We're coming in.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Who told you to open fire?
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: I saw movement. I thought it was the Jem'Hadar.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: They look like Jem'Hadar to you? I gave the word to hold your fire -- that Starfleet officers were beaming down with supplies.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Nobody told me.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Sorry, captain. A little breakdown in communications...
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: No harm done.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Where's Captain Loomis?
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: He was killed ten days ago. So was Commander Parker.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Then who's in command?
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: I am. Chief Nadia Larkin.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Ben Sisko. Where would you like your supplies?
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Vargas can show you.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Supplies -- that's just great. Don't they know we need to get off this rock?
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Take it easy, Vargas.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Take it easy? I'd love to take it easy. Just get me out of this vole-hole and I promise all I'll do, for the rest of my life, is take it easy! According to Starfleet regulations we're suppose to be rotated off the front lines after ninety days -- ninety days. We've been stuck here for five months!
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: Welcome to paradise, captain.
scene: 13A  EXT. ROCKY TERRAIN OUTSIDE BASE CAMP - CONTINUOUS

quote: There it is... the only reason anyone gives a damn about this place. It's the largest Dominion communications array in the sector.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: If we can figure out how it works, we should be able to tap into their entire com system.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: One thing's for sure, they're determined to get it back.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: You can't let that happen.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I know our orders, Captain. But maybe Starfleet Command isn't aware of our situation -- we've been holding this place for five months. That's five months of fighting off repeated Jem'Hadar attempts to take it back. When we landed here, there was a hundred and fifty of us... we're down to forty-three.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I can appreciate what you've been through. I'll make sure that Starfleet understands your situation. But from what I hear, our forces are spread pretty thin in this system. Chances are, you're going to be stuck here a while longer.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Lucky us.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Someone hand me a duonetic coupler.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Thanks.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: (regarding something on the array) Your frequency discriminator seems to be drifting. You might want to reset it.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: You an engineer?
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: No, but Tobin -- one of my previous hosts was.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Close enough. Grab a microdyne coupler and start recalibrating that transtator.
scene: 14   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Nog. Shouldn't you be helping Doctor Bashir unload the supplies?
We're pretty much finished.
Good. The sooner we can get out of here, the better.
That soldier over there... you see his necklace? Those are Ketracel White tubes.
So?
You know how he got them?
Mail order?
He took them off the bodies of dead Jem'Hadar -- Jem'Hadar he killed. It's his way of keeping score.
And you find that impressive?
Isn't it?
I don't think so. Take a look around you, Nog.
This isn't the Starfleet you know.

Sure it is. It's just that these people have been through a lot. They've been holed up here for a long time... seen two thirds of their unit killed... but they haven't surrendered. And you know why? Because they're heroes.

Maybe -- but I still don't want you anywhere near them. Let me tell you something about Hew- mons, Nog. They're a wonderful, friendly people -- as long as their bellies are full and their holosuites are working. But take away their creature comforts... deprive them of food, sleep, sonic showers... put their lives in jeopardy over an extended period of time... and those same friendly, intelligent, wonderful people will become as nasty and violent as the most bloodthirsty Klingon. You don't believe me? Just look at those faces... look in their eyes.
You know I'm right, don't you?
Well? Aren't you going to say something?
I feel sorry for the Jem'Hadar.
There you go... that should take care of your fever and chest congestion.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: And this should get rid of the dermal irritation on your back.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: Better?
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: Are you kidding? I haven't felt this good since the day I landed on this rock.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: What the hell are you doing?
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: Keep your hands off the bandage.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: I need to treat your wound.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: No one touches that bandage. Understood?
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: Why's that?
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: I asked you if you understood?
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: McGreevey put that bandage on me... ripped up his own uniform to make it.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: Sounds like a good friend.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: He was a jerk. I couldn't stand the guy -- he never shut up. Yap, yap, yap, yap. He thought he was the world's greatest authority on everything. I know he's dead and I should have more respect... but God, I hated him. One moment he's talking his head off tying the bandage around me... the next he's lying flat on his back with a hole in his chest.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: I just sat there looking at him... it was great -- he was so quiet. For the first time in his life he was quiet.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: I need to treat your wound.
scene: 20   INT. BASE CAMP - MAKESHIFT INFIRMARY - NIGHT

quote: I think you've set up a solid defense perimeter, but I would tighten this flank.
scene: 21   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Captain, can I have a minute?
scene: 21   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Go ahead.
scene: 21   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: These people... their physical and mental health are precarious at best. They need more than a few food replicators and some medical supplies... they need to be shipped out of here.
scene: 21   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I understand, but right now there's nothing I can do about it.
scene: 21   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Damn it --
scene: 21   INT. BASE CAMP - 2ND LEVEL/COMMAND BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I saw it happen... he was just walking along and the next minute...
You must've swept the compound for anti-personnel mines...
A hundred times. It doesn't help -- not with Houdinis.
"Houdinis?"
Find one and you disappear.
They "hide" in subspace and appear at random.
You can walk past the same spot a hundred times and nothing happens. And then... bang.
You're wasting your breath, Vargas. It's not the captain's problem. He's leaving.
I wish I could tell you that things are going to get easier for you...
Don't worry about us, captain.
Defiant to Captain Sisko.
Go ahead.
Stand by, Worf.
Take evasive action, Mister Worf. We're staying.
Captain, I must ask you to reconsider -- I don't know when we'll be able to come back for you.
You have your orders, commander.
Aye, sir. Good luck.
What are you looking at? We have work to do.
Yes, sir. You heard the captain.
I'm telling you, there's something about this place that makes people crazy
Sir, what are your orders?
There's only one order, lieutenant...
We hold.
We need to find out how many Jem'Hadar troops landed and where they are.
Well, you're not going to learn anything with a tricorder. We jam their sensors, they jam ours... that's how it works.
Except they have an advantage... they know where we are.
All things considered, I'd still rather be in their shoes.
Hear anything, Ensign?
Plenty. I can hear Vargas's stomach grumbling and Ezri tuning a phase amplifier with a coil spanner in the communications bunker...
Not a sound. If they're out there, they're being very quiet.
They're out there.
Keep your ears open, Ensign.
I will, sir.
That knife you're working on... it's not Starfleet issue.
Can I see it?
You're supposed to be listening for Jem'Hadar.
I know.
Then shut up and listen.
Here they come!
Something's wrong.
Hold your fire!
You heard the Captain. Cease firing!
They weren't here to begin with.
Holograms.
I don't understand...
It was a way to see what they're up against... determine our numbers.
And pinpoint our positions.
Without risking any casualties. Smart.
They're smart all right... and we're as good as dead.
Not yet we aren't.
Is it over?
For now. But next time they won't send holograms.
Does that mean we stop working on the communications array?
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: They'll have to get along without you for a while. We need to find
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I'm all for that. Those mines are a nasty piece of engineering...
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: They're also impossible to detect. I'm sorry, Captain, but I'm an engineer, not a magician.
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Larkin says you like a challenge...
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I thought I did. But after banging my head against that communications array for the last couple of months I'm not so sure anymore.
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: He's just being modest, Captain. Chief O'Brien would be proud to have him on his crew.
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: I can't think of higher praise.
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Now what?
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Now we get to pull a rabbit out of our hat.
scene: 49   INT. BASE CAMP - COMMUNICATIONS BUNKER - NIGHT

quote: Here -- you need to keep your strength up.
Thanks, uncle, but I can get my own food.
