Yeah, I've heard that one somewhere...
If you were hurt, I'd leave you behind.
Then I'm glad I'm not the one who's hurt. Major, you go across... Dax and I'll find a way around...
Major, I gave you a direct order.
Court-martial me.
I can't... you're not in Starfleet...
If I were your superior officer, I'd court-martial both of you...
Only a few meters more...
Hang on!
Benjamin!
They made it! I won! I had full confidence in you, Commander... there was never a moments doubt that you would prevail in this outrageous...
No. I'm afraid all your players were lost...
You mean we were never in any real danger?
It's only a game.
Time to move along home.
Not so fast. This may all have been a game to you... but we take first contact with a new species very seriously... and I don't appreciate...
Excuse me, Commander... before you blame them you might want to ask Quark just how all this started... ?
Quark... ?
I wish I could explain it... they just had a run of bad luck and they blamed me for their losses and...
That's not what you said when you were groveling on the floor...
Oh, that's right, you were here for the groveling...
You said something about cheating, didn't you?
Cheating?
I would have said anything to end the ordeal. It was too much for me to bear. You have no idea the pressure I was under, Commander...
You were under...
If you'll excuse us... perhaps someday... a rematch.
You know... This game could work here... it really could... excuse me...
Falow... Mister Falow... a word with you, sir...
Definitely Cardassian.
And in trouble. Its engines are completely disabled.
Open a hailing frequency. This is Commander Sisko of Deep Space Nine. Do you need assistance?
They're not answering. Their life-support systems are operating on reserve power.
Better lock on a tractor beam and pull them into Docking Bay Seven. Notify Chief O'Brien to meet me there.
I'm Benjamin Sisko, commander of Deep Space Nine. My chief of operations, Miles O'Brien. Do any of you need medical assistance?
I think we're all in good shape, considering. I'm Professor Natima Lang. (indicates the other Cardassians) These are two of my students, Rekelen and Hogue.
What happened to your ship?
We were caught in a meteor swarm. I'm a decent teacher, but I'm afraid I'm not much of a shuttle pilot. Do you think you'll be able to repair our ship?
I'll have to take a look. Excuse me.
We'd like to be on our way as soon as possible. We know having Cardassians on a Bajoran station may cause trouble. That's the last thing we want.
If anyone can fix your ship, it's Mister O'Brien. In the meantime, you're welcome to stay here. If you stick to the Promenade, I'm sure there won't be any trouble.
Are you saying you agree with General Yiri's decision to execute his brother?
Of course I agree. Yiri's brother was a traitor to the Trelonian government.
But the evidence is all circumstantial.
My dear Doctor... it all comes down to a question of loyalty. Yiri had to choose between protecting his brother or protecting the state. He chose the state... as would I, every time.
I suppose that's one way of looking at it. Then again, "Before you can be loyal to another, you must be loyal to yourself."
And who can we thank for those misguided words of wisdom? Sarek of Vulcan?
Actually, it was Julian Bashir of Earth. And it's not too bad considering I just made it up on the spot.
With sentiments like those, you wouldn't last five seconds on Cardassia.
Would you?
Fishing again, Doctor?
Well, assuming you're not a spy...
Assuming.
Then maybe you're an outcast?
Or maybe I'm an outcast spy?
How could you be both?
I never said I was either.
I heard an interesting rumor.
Only one? I started at least twelve.
Rumor has it you've managed to get your hands on a small cloaking device.
And you believe everything you hear?
When it's about you, yes. According to Bajoran law, such a device would be highly illegal.
If I had one. Which I don't.
I didn't expect you to admit it. I'm simply serving notice: You try to sell it and I'll see to it that you spend the next fifty years digging trenches in a penal colony.
(winces at the prospect, but:) I told you... you have nothing to worry about, because...
Excuse me.
Natima?
Quark.
I knew you'd come b...
I told you never to speak to me again.
Are you all right?
All right? This is the happiest day of my life.
Natima, wait. At least let me buy you and your friends a drink. I could make you a Samarian Sunset.
I don't drink Samarian Sunsets anymore.
Why not?
Because they remind me of you.
Is this... Ferengi bothering you?
This Ferengi happens to be Natima's old and cherished friend. Who are you?
These are my students.
Students. You don't say. You know, she always told me she wanted to teach one day. And now, you're doing it. Congratulations. It's so rare for someone to actually achieve their dreams.
Professor Lang isn't simply a teacher. She's our inspiration.
Really? I'd love to sit in on one of your classes. What do you teach?
Political Ethics.
Her teachings will change the future of Cardassia.
That's enough, Rekelen.
Not at all. I want to hear more.
I always knew that Natima was destined for greatness.
Quark...
Just one drink. It'll be like old times.
It'll never be like old times.
You're right. It'll be better.
I'll be right back with refreshments.
Your hands are shaking.
So how well does this woman know you? Just enough to dislike you, or well enough to really hate you.
She used to work here at the station. She was a correspondent for the Cardassian information service. It was before your time.
So which is it... dislike or hate?
It's none of your business, but if you have to know... I was the love of her life.
Must have been some life.
What about our drinks?
If you want a drink, the bar's right over there.
Your Samarian Sunset.
(there's no force behind her anger) I said I didn't drink these anymore.
Because they remind you of me. But since I'm here anyway, you may as well enjoy yourself. Besides, it's on the house.
You know, you're as beautiful as ever.
And you're as big a liar as ever.
You see... just like old times. I've missed you, Natima. And that's no lie.
(looking around the bar) You seem to have kept busy.
Oh, yes. I'm very successful. But as the two hundred and twenty-third Rule of Acquisition says...
Please. I haven't heard a Rule of Acquisition in seven years. And I don't want to hear one now. You never apologized, Quark. You never admitted you were wrong. I think that hurt more than anything.
Would it really have made any difference?
Maybe not. But it would've been nice if you'd tried.
All right. I'm sorry. I was wrong.
It's too late.
It's never too late. So how long are you going to be on the station?
Thank you for another enjoyable lunch. Doctor.
I didn't think there'd be any Cardassians left on the station.
He's the only one.
What do we do now?
Why? Is something wrong?
We have to leave... as soon as possible. Goodbye, Quark. Thanks for the drink.
But you didn't touch it.
How are your repairs coming?
The damage is more extensive than I thought. They were lucky to survive the attack.
The attack?
They weren't in any meteor swarm. Their ship was hit by Cardassian disrupters.
That doesn't make sense. Why would Cardassians fire on other Cardassians?
Maybe you should ask her.
I hate to be an imposition, Commander, but I need my ship.
That's not possible. Mister O'Brien is still working on it. Your ship sustained more damage than we originally thought, in fact...
You suspect our ship was damaged by Cardassian weapons. You're right, of course.
Professor...
It's all right, Hogue. I should've told them the truth in the first place.
Then why didn't you?
Because Cardassians don't involve outsiders in their internal politics. Especially Bajorans.
Being shot at by your own people goes a little beyond politics.
We take our politics very seriously. Commander, if I don't get my students to safety they're going to be killed. And if they die, the future of Cardassia may die with them.
To put it simply, not everyone inside the Cardassian Empire is satisfied with the way the Central Command governs.
Not everyone outside, either.
There are some who believe the future of Cardassia shouldn't remain in the hands of the military.
And you're among them?
Yes, we are.
Rekelen and Hogue are two of the most important leaders of our movement.
Which makes you fugitives.
The military's afraid to let us speak our minds.

We only want a better future for all Cardassians. A future based on peace and non-violence. But if we achieve peace, true peace, both inside and outside our borders, the military will no longer be able to justify their control of the Empire.
Military governments are notoriously reluctant to give up power.
Ours is no exception.
They've already tried to kill us once... they're sure to try again.
Which is why I have to get them off this station... as soon as possible.
I'll dispatch additional work crews to help repair your ship.
The sooner the better, Commander.
We saw another Cardassian aboard the station... in the bar.
Garak? He saw you?
I'm certain of it.
Then... we may have a problem. Mister Garak is a bit of a mystery to us. One of my officers is convinced he works for Cardassian Intelligence. For all I know he could be right.
Why don't you arrest him?
On what charge?
You're the commander. You don't need a reason.
That's not how we do things here.
Nor should it be.
I'll assign you some guest quarters. You'll be safe there until your ship is ready.
We appreciate your assistance, Commander.
Mister Quark, this is a surprise. I don't believe you've ever been in my establishment before.
You usually don't frequent mine, either... though I did see you in there today.
The Replimat was a little crowded. So what brings you here now?
Oh, I just wanted to see what you're offering.
What do you get for this?
Seventeen strips of latinum.
Tell you what, I'll give you twenty.
Twenty? How uncharacteristically generous... for a Ferengi.
Just one businessman trying to help out another. I figure we have to stick together.
This is the latest style on my homeworld. Do you like it?
I'm no expert on Cardassian fashions. What do you think?
I don't know. It's been so long since I've had a Cardassian customer.
Then you're in luck. There're some on the station right now.
Now that you mention it, I think your lady friend may find this style very appealing. You are old friends, aren't you?
You're very perceptive, for a Cardassian.
It would've been hard to miss the way you were looking at her.
It would've been hard to miss the way you were looking at her.
I always try to observe the fashions of visitors to the station.
Personally I find this style a bit too radical, but your friend seems the type who appreciates that sort of thing.
Different tastes for different people. Nothing wrong with that, is there?

You'd be surprised how detrimental a poor choice of fashion can be. Take this dress. It may be all the rage now... but it could quickly become tiresome, an affront to the eyes. Certain people may even find it... objectionable. And then... Nothing but rags.
I see.
Mister Quark, may I offer you some free advice?
As long as I'm under no obligation to follow it.
I've been in this business a long time.

And I know there's nothing worse than following the wrong trend. Now you're a smart fellow. (glances at Quark's clothing) With your own inimitable style. Perhaps you should mention that to your lady friend. I'd hate to see her become... a victim of fashion.
Would you like to explain that?
She's chosen to associate herself with some rather flamboyant companions. It would be a tragedy if she got in the way when her friends... went out of style.
(no longer dancing around) If anyone tries to hurt her, they're going to have to deal with me.
What're you going to do? Shortchange them at the dabo table?
I think I'll buy this dress after all. See that it's mended.
Professor, we have to do something.
If you want to do something constructive, stop pacing... the both of you.
We can't just sit here while everything we've worked for is slipping away.
Have faith. Your work is just beginning.
How can you say that? The movement is in shambles... we're fleeing for our lives... the military's hold is stronger than ever. Things are no better than when we started.
That's not true. Look at all you've accomplished. Five years ago there was no hope for progress. The military's rule wasn't even questioned. That's all changed now.
We could never have done it without your support.
What we've started can't be undone. Don't you see, they can kill me... they can kill you, but they can't kill our ideas... our hope for a better Cardassia.
(worried, but putting up a good front) You're right, Professor.

Don't worry, Hogue. I have no intention of letting you become martyrs. I'll get you out of this somehow. (venting her own frustration) If we could only get to Sadera Six and join up with the others...
(Quark's voice, disguised) Lieutenant Smith to Professor Lang. Commander Sisko is on his way to your quarters. He'd like to speak to you in private.
Thank you. I'll be waiting. Why don't you two go see if Chief O'Brien's made any progress with our ship?
Enter.
Quark. I can't talk now. I'm expecting Commander Sisko.
He's not coming.
What do you mean he's not coming?
Trust me.
Lieutenant Smith?
At your service.
You haven't changed a bit.
You're wrong, Natima. I haven't been the same since you left.
What is it you want from me?
I know you're in trouble. I want to help you.
I don't want your help.
But I owe you. You saved my life. If you had turned me over to the authorities, I'd've been executed.
I admired your courage. It was a brave thing you were doing... selling food to the Bajorans. I thought you were a man of honor.
I'm a Ferengi. You should've known better.
You're right. I should have. Instead...
Can't you even say it?
I can't even think it.
Okay, then I'll say it for you. We fell in love. And that month we spent together was the best time of our lives... and you know it.
I think you're confusing lust with love.
I admit... I'm capable of it. But not this time. I loved you, Natima.
Then how could you have betrayed me?
I didn't betray you.
Don't lie to me, Quark. I know better. You used my personal access codes to authorize payments for goods you never provided.
So I took a little money from the Cardassian Communication Service. They could afford it.
You stole that money.
I saw a chance for profit and I took it. Maybe that was wrong. I don't know. But what I really regret was betraying your trust. That was the worst mistake of my life.
And you'd do it again in a second. I believed in you, Quark. But you were using me. Like you use everyone. For profit.
Then let me make it up to you. Let me help you. I ask for nothing in return.
Nothing?
Except that you'll stay with me forever.
I can't stay here, Quark. My students need me.
Listen to me, Natima. You can't leave me. Not now. If you don't stay with me, I'll have to follow you. And I will. Wherever you go. Until you agree to take me back.
Quark, you don't even know me anymore. I'm part of the Cardassian underground. Following me will only get you killed.
I'll take that chance.
What about the bar?
I don't care about the bar. I'll turn it over to Rom. He'll run it into the ground in a month, but that doesn't matter. I have to be with you.
It won't work, Quark. You say you'd do anything for me. Maybe right now, you even believe it.
But I know better. In the end, you'd only care about yourself.
But I love you.
I don't love you.
Now which one of us is lying?
(trying not to let him get to her) You'd better go.
All right. But if there's anything you need... anything at all... I'll be waiting.
It'll be a long wait.
Professor Lang's ship should be ready to go in about an hour, Commander.
Good, I'll let her know.
We have a Cardassian warship approaching. Fast.
On screen.
Dax, hail them.
No response.
The ship's taking up an attack posture.
They're still ignoring us.
They're powering up their forward disrupters.
Shields!
Shields up.
Lock on phasers and photon torpedoes... Prepare to return fire if necessary.
Commander? We need to talk.
All right, Garak, you mind telling me why a Cardassian warship is threatening my station?
No one is threatening you. The Central Command merely wants to make sure that they have your undivided attention.
Well, they have it. I assume this has something to do with Professor Lang and her students?
"Students" is a rather benign term for them. "Terrorists" would be more accurate. The Cardassian government would very much like Hogue and Rekelen returned home immediately.
They haven't committed any crimes here. As long as they're on my station, they're free to do whatever they want.
This is all very embarrassing, Commander. The Central Command would hate to see the Federation pulled into such an insignificant and purely internal affair.
I would hardly call it insignificant. Judging from the behavior of that ship out there, it appears the Central Command considers Hogue and Rekelen to be extremely dangerous.
Not at all. Annoying, perhaps. Inconvenient, maybe. But dangerous? Hardly. If they were dangerous, would the Central Command entrust the situation to me, a simple tailor?
Which only confirms what I've suspected all along. You, Mister Garak, are no simple tailor.
Really, Commander, that's another discussion, entirely. All you need to know right now is that the return of Hogue and Rekelen is in the best interests of the Cardassian Empire.
Or at least in the best interest of the Cardassian military.
Is there a difference?
Do you really expect a Bajoran station, under Federation command, to turn over Cardassian political refugees... on your say-so?
The ultimate decision is yours of course. I'm simply relaying a message.
Then relay this. Tell the Central Command that if anyone attempts to take Hogue and Rekelen by force, I will respond in kind. Am I clear, Mister Garak?
Absolutely. Thank you for your time.
Here, you go. Two mugs of Kanar... on the house.
We didn't order these.
They're the drinks I promised you the first time you were in here. Sorry they took so long but things have been a little hectic. Do you mind?
I'm afraid we do.
Professor Lang told us you couldn't be trusted.
You Cardassians do hold grudges. Seven years ago Natima and I had some silly lovers' quarrel and... Well, all I can say is... I'm willing to let bygones be bygones.
But Professor Lang isn't.
I have to say I find your loyalty to her extremely touching.
There's nothing we wouldn't do for her. And if she says not to talk to you, then we don't talk to you.
I understand. She's your teacher... you're her students... you have to listen to her.
So, if you don't want to talk to the only person who can get you off this station in one piece, that's fine with me.
Wait.
You say you can help us get away?
It's possible.
How?
One second.
The station's security chief's a shape-shifter. You can never be too careful. (moving closer to speak in confidence) I take it you know what a cloaking device is?
Well, I have one. It's not in the best of condition... but it'll work for about fifteen minutes. Long enough to get you away from here.
Sounds expensive.
We don't have much in the way of latinum, but whatever we do have is yours.
Exactly how much latinum are we talking about?
Forget I said that. I don't want your money. Consider the cloaking device a gift.
I'm surprised. Ferengis aren't known for their generosity.
We're a deeply misunderstood race.
You may've saved our lives. Our movement owes you a debt of gratitude.
And I know exactly how you can repay me. You have to convince Natima to stay here.
Would you please stop doing that.
The Professor will never agree to stay behind.
No Natima... no cloaking device and no way off this station.
She won't do it.
You'll have to talk her into it. After all, you're the ones the Cardassians are after.
He's right. She shouldn't have to risk her life for our crimes.
I suppose we could ask her.
Don't ask her. Tell her.
We'll do our best.
I'm sure you will. I shudder to think what would happen if the military gets its hands on you.
Meet us at our quarters in an hour.
I'll be there.
Come in.
Where are Rekelen and Hogue?
They're waiting at the ship.
Perfect. I know my quarters might seem a little crowded at first, but tomorrow morning, I'll put in a request for something bigger.
That won't be necessary.
All right, if you want your own quarters to start out with, I can arrange that, too.
I mean I'm not staying.
Now hold on. Your students and I had an agreement. They get the cloaking device... (indicates the object under his arm) And you stay with me. That way everyone's happy.
Quark, you say you love me... then give me the cloaking device and let me be on my way.
And let you disappear out of my life again?
I'm not a part of your life, Quark.
But you are. You always have been.
Don't you understand, since you left me, not a day goes by that I don't regret what I did. And now you're asking me to lose you again.
You lost me a long time ago.
All right, then say it... let me hear you say that there isn't a spark of love left in you.
There isn't a spark of love left in me.
I heard that.
What?
You hesitated. Admit it, you still care.
Quark, I don't have time for this. Give me that cloaking device.
I can't. I won't let you go.
I didn't want to have to get it this way, but I need that device... Give it to me. Now.
Or what? You'll shoot me?
If I have to.
Then go ahead and shoot.
Quark... Quark, are you all right.
(still doesn't believe it) You shot me.
I didn't mean to. It was an accident. (holding up the gun for Quark to see) I never fired a phaser before. I barely touched the trigger...
Careful.
Owww.
It hurts?
She wants to know if it hurts? Of course it hurts. It's supposed to hurt. It's a phaser.
I made sure it was only on the first setting.
How considerate of you.
Should I get a doctor?
That's okay. Maybe if you rub it a little.
Oh, Quark... I'm sorry.
Really?
Yes, for everything... all those horrible things I said...
You really didn't mean them?
I love you, Quark. I've always loved you. Even when I hated you.
Natima.
I've missed you... I've missed you so much. Being with you was the happiest time of my life.
And now we're together again, and we have the rest of our lives to be happy.
I wish it was that easy.
But it can be... if you let it.
I'm not the same person I was seven years ago. I have responsibilities...
I'll share them with you.
The movement is my life now. I don't have time for anything else.
We'll make the time. You're a woman, Natima. Believe me, I know. And it's not right for you to be alone.
I'm not alone. I have my students... my dreams of a better Cardassia.
But are dreams enough? Can dreams make you laugh? Can dreams hold you close at night?
No. But my life demands that I make certain sacrifices...
And you've made them. But that doesn't mean you can't be happy.
We did have fun together, didn't we?
Remember the day I installed my first holosuite.
I'd never been in one before.
I still have that program... the picnic on Rhymus Major. Two suns in the sky...
The sound of the waterfalls.
The whisper of flitterbird wings over our heads...
You painted my face with honey...
And a Mordian butterfly landed on your nose...
A Mordian butterfly got stuck on my nose.
His wings were beating almost as fast as my heart.
Those were good times.
The best. And we can have them back again. I'll give the cloaking device to your students. Once they're gone, you'll be safe, and we can be together.
I can't just abandon them, Quark. They need me.
I need you. Don't you see, Natima, you've done enough for the movement. You lit the match. Now let them carry the torch.
Or are you saying the movement won't survive without you?
Of course it will.
Then let it. And let us have the happiness we deserve.
You really do love me, don't you?
With all that I am, Natima. Forever.
Will you stay?
Yes, Quark. I'll stay.
You don't know how I've waited to hear that.
Enter.
Professor Lang?
Not now, Odo. Can't you see we're busy?
I apologize for the interruption, but I'm afraid, madam... You're under arrest.
I'm... what?
On what charge?
Commander Sisko will explain. I am truly sorry.
Now hold on.
It's all right, Quark.
Commander, would you please explain what we're doing here?
I'm afraid the three of you are going to be turned over to the Cardassian government.
You can't do that.
I wish I didn't have to. But Cardassia has offered to hand over a half-dozen Bajoran prisoners in exchange for you.
And you've agreed to this?
The Bajoran Provisional Government agreed to it.
A Cardassian transport will deliver the Bajoran prisoners in a little over five hours.
Commander, you have no idea what they're going to do to us.
We're the ones they're after. At least let Professor Lang go.

I'd like nothing better. But the provisional government has ordered that you all be turned over. I'm fighting this every way I can... and I'm not ready to give up yet. I'm due to address the Chamber of Ministers on subspace in half an hour. I'll do everything I can to convince them that they're wrong. But in the end... this is a Bajoran station, and I have to abide by their decision. No matter how much I disagree with it.
How the mighty have fallen.
Toran.
It's Gul Toran now.
They've made you a Gul. I didn't realize the situation on Cardassia had gotten so desperate.
I find your bitterness extremely... gratifying. I'm glad to see that you're adjusting so poorly to exile.
Actually, I'm finding my time here to be most illuminating.
Then I don't suppose you'd be interested in going home again?
Am I to be rewarded for informing the Central Command about Hogue and Rekelen's presence on the station?
Perhaps. But only after you see to it that they don't leave this station alive.
But I suggested a prisoner exchange... the Central Command agreed...
I convinced them otherwise.
They listened to you?
My voice is less tarnished than yours.
Kill them and all you'll be creating are martyrs.
You overestimate their importance.
So how do you propose to arrange this unfortunate incident?
I'm sure you'll think of something. You always did in the past. Don't you see? Lang's death will benefit us both. Unless of course, you intend to spend the rest of your life as a tailor.
I see your point.
I knew you would.
Odo, we have to talk.
I'm busy. Come back later.
Later will be too late.
"I, the Jury" by Mickey Spillane?
Chief O'Brien loaned it to me.
This had better be important, Quark.
It is. Odo, you have to let Natima and her students go.
Do I?
Those students could be the key to a new Cardassia. A Cardassia free from military rule and oppression.
Since when have you become so interested in Cardassian politics?
A freer more open society on Cardassia would benefit this entire sector... And it'd be great for business.
So wanting me to free Natima and those students is strictly a financial consideration on your part?
Now, Odo... Don't allow my greed to keep you from doing the right thing.
I know you better than you think, Quark. This isn't about Cardassia. And for once, it isn't even about profit. This is about Professor Lang.
You're right. It is. Her life is in jeopardy as long as Rekelen and Hogue are on the station.
Why didn't you tell me that before.

What was I supposed to say? That I love her? That I'd do anything for her? That without her, my life would be meaningless? Sure I could say that, but what good would it do? How could I expect you to understand? You've never had those feelings. You don't know what it means to really care about another person. You've never been in love. You've got all the emotions of a stone. No offense.
Go on.

Listen to me, Odo, you do this for me, and I promise you... there will be no more secrets between us. I will tell you about every underhanded deal... every lying scheme... every dirty trick... my brother Rom's involved in.
Well when you put it that way... I'm not interested.
Okay, let me put it another way. Do it for me...
For you?

That's right. For all the years we've known each other... for everything we've been through together. You say you know me better than anyone... well, I know you. Sure sometimes we're on opposite sides, but that doesn't mean we aren't close. I've never told you this, Odo, but I consider you as dear to me as my brother.
And I've seen how well you treat him.
Odo, look at me. I'm on my knees... I'm begging you. I don't care why you do it... pick any reason you want. But please, let Natima and the others go.
All right. I'll do it.
You will.
But not for you. Turning Hogue and Rekelen over to the Cardassians will
Justice... that was going to be my next suggestion. So, you're really not doing this for me?
That's right.
Then I don't owe you a thing. Thank you.
You'll never know how much this means to me.
Let go.
I'm sorry. Now let's hurry before you change your mind.
Just one question. How do you expect Rekelen and Hogue to get past that warship? I knew you had a cloaking device.
I always said you were too smart for me, Odo.
Quark. What are you doing here?
Getting you out.
Thank you.
Good luck.

I've installed the cloaking device in your central engine core. You can activate it from the bridge as soon as the mooring clamps are released. Then I suggest you take your ship to warp eight and don't look back.
(continuing, to all of them) Now please, make your good-byes brief.
What's the rush?
You've betrayed us.
No.
Don't. I'd hate to ruin such a nice suit.
Why are you doing this?
Exile tends to wear thin after a while, even when the surroundings are as pleasant as these.
Fine. Take them, but leave Natima alone.
Quark.
No. He's right. We're the fugitives, not you.
You see, they agree with me.
Unfortunately, it's not their decision to make. Nor mine. Professor Lang, however minor her role in this matter, has come to the attention of the Central Command.
Do you think killing us is going to change anything? Cardassia is slipping out of the military's grasp. And nothing you do can prevent it.
Madam, I am not here to debate you.
Garak, if you harm these people, I'll see to it that Commander Sisko prosecutes you to the fullest extent of the law.
Which brings up another issue. Quark, things would've been much simpler if you'd taken my advice and not gotten involved with these people.
I was already involved.
I know. A pity, really. Personally, I rather like you, Quark.
You mean, you're going to shoot me too.
Before I became a tailor, I lived by a simple motto: "Never allow sentiment to interfere with your work." A bit of a cliche, but true nonetheless.
I'll keep that in mind.
Well, then... Though I admit it's against my better judgement, I'm afraid I must carry out the verdict of the Central Command.
But you admit that they're wrong. Why don't you stand up for what you believe in?
More to the point...
What do you believe in, Garak?
What are you doing here, Toran?
Making sure that you carry out your assignment. I suspected that two years living among Bajorans would make you soft. I see I was right.
You've never been right about anything, Toran. Now step aside and let me finish this sorry business.
I'll take over from here.
Why? So you can take the credit and make sure I remain in disgrace.
I can't believe that you were once considered clever.
Did you really think that completing this one simple task would restore your reputation with the Central Command?
I suppose not.
Go back to your sewing kit, tailor.
Some people should never be promoted.
(continuing, to Hogue and Rekelen) Well, don't just stand there. Your ship's waiting.
I'm going to see to it that every Ferengi on the station shops at your store.
That alone makes this all worthwhile.
You heard the man. Get moving.
Thank you... both of you.
Yes, yes, yes. Now go. Quickly. And keep up the good work.
Quark, I've got to say good-bye.
Just let them go. It'll be less painful that way.
You don't understand. I have to say good-bye... to you. I'm going with them.
But we had a deal.
I can't stay here. Maybe one day, I can come back, and we'll be together again. But not until my work is done.
So all I have to do to get you back is wait until Cardassia becomes a free and democratic society.
I promise, I'll make it worth the wait.
I don't suppose I could come with you.

No. It's not your fight. And I could never live with myself if something happened to you. I need to know that you're here, safe. That way, part of me will always be safe, too. I love you, Quark. I always will.
I love you, too.
I suggest we return to the Promenade without delay.
You have to tell me... why'd you do it? Shoot Toran?
Why did you let Professor Lang go?
I had no choice. I love her.
And I love Cardassia. Which is why I had to do what I did.
I don't understand.
That's the thing about love. No one really understands it, do they?
(anxious, mid- conversation) ... only paid for one hour... and he's been in there for three... fighting the Battle of Klachdachbrach or some such thing over and over...
The Battle of Klach D'kel Brakt was a legendary Klingon victory over the Romulans almost a century ago...
Well, he's been losing it all afternoon and he says he's not coming out until he wins... I banged on the door, he sealed himself in. I threatened to shut off the power, he threatened to kill me.
("You'll be remembered
Kkhap-LA! ShusH-kin'Hurra!
Since when did you add ancient Klingon battles to the holosuite programs?
The Captain of the last Klingon ship that went through the wormhole sold some to me. I know, I know -- it's brutal, it's violent, it's bloody but to the Klingons, it's entertainment.
Shut off the power.
He'll kill you.
No, he said he'd kill you. Shut it off.
chay'pen Aha'bA?
(senseless threatening roar) AR GOT K'NEL D'KULLUH MARG RAH GOL LOOOOOOOOW!!!!!
You dare interrupt the Battle of Klach D'kel Brakt, you Ferengi k'pekt!
The battle has been won. The people are waiting to celebrate your victory.
They are?
Lead the way then!
Hear me! I am Kor! Dahar Master of the Klingons!
And now I need somewhere to rest.
I have just the place.
No, this will do just fine.
How did you get in here?
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I am Koloth.
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: That doesn't answer my question.
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Yes. It does.
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: What are the charges against him...
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Charges? No charges. He's today's guest of honor.
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: (with a very cold threat) You must be a very brave man to attempt humor at the expense of a Klingon Dahar Master.
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I... apologize. No offense intended.
scene: 6    INT. SECURITY OFFICE - ON A MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Kor!
scene: 8    INT. HOLDING CELL - CLOSE ON KOR'S FACE

quote: Sir, if you'll wake up, I'll release you into your friend's custody.
scene: 8    INT. HOLDING CELL - CLOSE ON KOR'S FACE

quote: Koloth! wIj jup... My old friend. I knew you'd be here.
scene: 8    INT. HOLDING CELL - CLOSE ON KOR'S FACE

quote: You disgrace yourself and our purpose. I do not go into battle with one whose honor is washed away in Breshtanti ale... Keep him.
scene: 8    INT. HOLDING CELL - CLOSE ON KOR'S FACE

quote: The security reassignments, Major. I'm sorry it took so long. It's been a Klingon afternoon.
A "Klingon afternoon"?
Every time Klingons come to the station, I wind up with a Klingon afternoon. But this was definitely one that I'll cherish forever.

There's a drunk Klingon in my holding cell who must be a hundred years old singing battle songs. Even his best friend who's probably a hundred and fifty years old won't have anything to do with him... so I get the pleasure of listening to his repertoire. "Kor! Dahar Master of the Klingons."
Did you say "Kor"?
That's what he announced right after he won the Battle of Klach D'kel Brakt in Quark's...
What's he doing here... did you get his friend's name, Odo? Was it Kang?
No, it was...
...Koloth.
Come with me, Odo.
B'aski't Kor, B'askr'ip Kor, KoHman-a-ti, B'aski't Kor.
Hello, Kor.
I'm thirsty.
Let him out.
Lieutenant...
I'll take responsibility.
I am very thirsty.
Kor, do you remember Curzon Dax?
Curzon? My dear friend Curzon? I lift my ghoptu to Curzon Dax!
And I, who was Curzon Dax lift my ghoptu to you. (off his look of disbelief) Scorcher burn on your fourteenth rib, and your left QiVon aches every time your ship hits warp eight.
Dax! My Curzon! After eighty-one years I find you a Kyamo-looking woman. Kiss me!
How about just a nice, big hug...
Curzon; my beloved old friend!
I'm... Jadzia now.
Jadzia; my beloved old friend!
Come on, Kor, let's go find Koloth.
Koloth's here too?
Look at him. He practices cuts and thrusts even with his food. Little children do that!
A sharp knife is nothing without a sharp eye.
It's been forty years since even his good eye was sharp. It is luck when you hit the plate!
I see the Federation insults us by sending a Lieutenant to greet us.
(with a different but still affectionate response) You never did have much use for the Federation, did you, Koloth?

I used to call you D'akturak. "Ice man." Because no proposal, no matter how reasonable, no matter how much it favored the Klingon Empire would satisfy you. You were the hardest man I ever faced across the negotiating table.
(delighted at Koloth's confusion) Do you not recognize our old friend Dax?
Dax?
Curzon is dead. But Dax is alive as part of me.
This is a mistake. Kang must not have known.
But what a beautiful mistake.
Then Kang is coming?
Of course, he's coming. He's brought the four of us back together after eighty-one years...
Could it possibly mean that he's...
Yes. That is exactly what it means.
I have found the Albino.
May I offer you some warm Bahgol... the replicators are Cardassian but we've been upgrading their...
That will not be necessary.
Would you dishonor me by refusing my offer?
Very well.
Would you sit, Kang?
I would.
Four Bahgols. Warm.
Do you remember the first time we sat together over Bahgol, Kang? It was at the Korvat colony. The Federation and the Klingon Empire were still enemies...
I have never sat with you before today.
I am Dax, the godfather of your son.
You are no one's godfather.
I am Dax, the godfather of your son.
So, you are the same Dax who took a
Don't mistake a new face for a new soul, Kang. I feel at one with your family. Just as I felt eight decades ago.
I hope in time you will embrace me as a brother again.
(scoffs under his breath) Brother. Ha!
Brother, sister... what's the difference. We're here now. Speak to us, Kang. Where is he? Where did you find the Albino? Do you have anything stronger perhaps?
You drink another klorn of ale and I will open a hole in your belly to drain it out.
Your eyes cannot even see my belly.
Seven years ago, on Dayos Four, I met one of the Albino's discarded wives.

I fed and clothed her and told her the story of our sons. She still feared him too much to tell me anything. But three months ago, she died. A week afterwards, an amulet that she wore around her neck arrived by messenger. Inside: the location of the Albino's sanctuary.
You're certain he's still there?
I have confirmed it with traders who supply him. It is on the fourth planet in the Secarus System. He has been hiding there for almost a quarter of a century.
Hiding from us, no doubt. We almost had him at Galdonterre...
I've worried for years that he might die before we found him again.
Or that we might...
What is your plan...
I am told his compound is protected by only forty men. Apparently, he has grown careless in his waning years.
The fool.
I wouldn't count on reports from traders. The Albino may have told them what to say if anyone asked questions.
She's right. These traders may have already warned him that we're coming.
They will warn no one ever again. This time, nothing will prevent us from reaching the Albino. And when we do, I will cut out his heart and eat it as he watches me with his dying breath.
I did not know of course.
About Curzon... ?
I was unwilling to risk contacting you by subspace.
I don't blame you. That's how the Albino learned we were coming to Galdonterre...
His ears reach across the galaxy. I don't know how. Tell me about my friend Curzon. Did he die an honorable death?
(sighs, shakes her head) In a hospital room. Yelling at the doctors and friends who were trying to keep him alive for one more miserable day.
A pity. He was a good man. He deserved to die in battle. It pains me that I will not see him again in this life.
Curzon was decorated often for his diplomatic achievements... but no honor touched him as deeply as yours. For a Klingon to choose a Federation official to be the godfather to his son...
Curzon Dax opened the door to peace. He was the first Federation diplomat I ever met who seemed to... truly appreciate the Klingon nature.
Well, there was always a bit of the Klingon nature in Curzon.
His blood oath with you was very important to him.
Would you eat from the heart of the Albino, Jadzia Dax?
I learned about Trills during my long friendship with Curzon. And I know that each new host has no obligation to past commitments.
And I know that a Klingon blood oath can never be broken.

The old Klingon ways are passing. When I was a young man, the mere mention of the Klingon Empire made other worlds tremble. Today, warriors open restaurants to serve racht to the grandchildren of men I slaughtered in battle. Nothing is what it used to be. Including a blood oath.
I know you, Kang. You don't believe that.
What I believe is no longer relevant. You are released from Curzon's oath. You owe nothing to any of us.
Are you still reading that plasma leak in Lower Pylon One... ? I can't seem to find it now...
It's been intermittent... let me do a high-resolution scan...
Kira...
Hmm...
How many people did you kill?
What?
While you were in the underground...
Too many.
Were they all just... faceless Cardassians or did you know who you were killing?
Why are we talking about this?
If it bothers you, we can stop.
It bothers me.
Sorry.
Why, are you thinking about killing somebody?
(looks up, smiles, good try) Me?
Tell me.
I don't know what you're talking about.
Tell me.

Eighty years ago, there was a band of depredators, led by an Albino, raiding Klingon colonies. Three Klingon warships were sent out to stop him. One of the captains was a close friend of Curzon's. The mission was successful. Most of them were captured. But the Albino escaped. In his last message to the Klingons, he promised to take his revenge on the firstborn of each of the three captains. A few years later, he kept his word. Somehow, he infected three innocent children with a genetic virus that killed them. One of them was my godson.
I'm sorry. But Jadzia, that was Curzon's godson.
I took a blood oath to revenge his death.
Curzon took a blood oath.
(a tear rolls down her cheek) I can still remember the boy's funeral. He was named Dax. For me.
You've found this Albino?
We know where he is. The three Klingons came here to tell me...
Look; you've said yourself that every new life for a Trill has to be new. If not you'd wind up paying off old debts forever. These Klingons can't possibly expect you to keep this oath.
No, they don't. That's just it. They say I have no obligation to them. But I do. I know it. I feel it. If not to them, I owe it to Curzon.
Jadzia... Your questions... about my experience with killing... If you're wondering what it's like... When you take someone else's life, you lose a part of your own as well.
I need another arm! Or am I doomed to choose between... ...perfection... ... and palate.
Let me spare you that terrible decision.
majQa'! To the rescue. Dax, may I present these, uh... ... two students of Klingon history.
Will you excuse us for a minute?
Only a minute, my students! Well, you certainly don't share Curzon's priorities.
About going after the Albino I do.
Kang and Koloth don't want me to come with you.
(semi-occupied with girls) Kang thinks too much; Koloth doesn't feel enough.
Where do you stand?
Of course you should come! The splendor of fighting and killing; a bloodbath in the cause of vengeance; who wouldn't want to come!
Will you speak to them about it? It means far more to me than I thought.
Koloth spends his time practicing in the holosuite; he listens to no one. And if Kang's made up his mind, there is nothing I can do.
And you call yourself a history teacher? What of your own history? You are Kor, Dahar Master. They cheered you at Klach D'kel Brakt. Your voice weighed heavily on the course of Klingon events.
You shame me.
No, no, please don't feel that...
The only weight I carry now, dear comrade... is my own bulbous body. I was once, if you remember... ... far less than you see, and... ... far more than I have become.
I'm sorry.
My memories are still of Kor... a great warrior.
Quark, you devious little Ha'DIbaH! Bring wine!
Nice of you to stop. I'm going with you.
Curzon Dax was a politician. It was a diplomatic ploy to bond himself to us in a blood oath.
That's a lie.
I am practicing here. Leave while you can.
When you agree that I can fulfill my part of the oath.
Your presence would only jeopardize the rest of us. Leave me.

Computer. I want a Klingon bat'leth: tip to tip one hundred and sixteen centimeters, weight five-point-three kilos with exterior handgripping diameter of five centimeters. Blades of composite Baakonite.
A warrior's configuration. Now what do you do with it?
I fight you with it.
If my hand should slip, and you should die?
Your hand would never slip... unless you've become old and feeble.
Come now, Koloth... surely you can take me down...
There's tension on your face, Koloth. You ought to drink more.
Stand up.
Your presence against the Albino will honor our cause.
Now that's a surprise from the great stone face.
Releasing you from Curzon's oath was not enough; I can see that now.
It is agreed then!
No.
I tell you now that you will not be a part of this quest.
Why do you dismiss her like some useless t'ooho'mIrah? (abruptly starts COUGHING)
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: We cannot go into an enemy stronghold with your sickly chest announcing us.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: There is nothing wrong with my chest.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: Nothing that won't get us killed before we reach battle. Come.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I need no nurse's hand.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: You can't deny my right for vengeance.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: You try to speak as a Klingon but the words do not fit in your mouth.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: You've said that to me before. Remember, Kang?
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I do not care to discuss it further.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: The Korvat colony. The first day of negotiations. I walked out on you that day. Right in the middle of that long-winded speech of yours. You should have seen the look on your face. Nobody ever had the kajunpak't to show his back to the great Kang until Curzon did.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I almost killed Curzon that day.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I know. I half-expected to feel a Klingon dagger in my back before I reached the door. I was afraid you could hear my knees knocking together.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: Is that what that noise was?
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I knew I had to get you very very angry if my mission was to succeed. Getting you angry at me was the only way to begin to create the bond between us.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: Curzon understood Klingons.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: And he understood what he was doing when he took a Klingon blood oath.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: You can't expect me to stay here and not avenge my own godson's murder. You can't ask me to live with that dishonor.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I cannot dishonor myself by permitting you to die in Curzon's place.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: Who's talking about dying. I have no intention of dying.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: You dishonor yourself already, Kang... by placing your own honor above mine. No Klingon warrior would leave a comrade behind while he goes off to battle. Perhaps you're right. Klingon honor isn't what it used to be.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: You wish to anger me again! You think the old trick will work twice?!
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: I understand Klingons.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: Fine then! Let it work! Come and fight with us. Come and be damned.
scene: 44   INT. QUARK'S - UPPER LEVEL - OUTSIDE HOLOSUITE

quote: Come in.
I was just about to come see you.
No.
No what.
No leave of absence.
Kira shouldn't have told you.
She's my first officer.
I don't have to tell you what this oath meant to Curzon.
Jadzia Dax took an oath too... when she joined Starfleet. You're subject to orders, Lieutenant.
Don't do it, Benjamin. Don't make me disobey a direct order.

I never understood this. I mean, whatever else he was, Curzon did have a fundamental morality. He wouldn't condone murder any more than I would. And yet he swore to kill this Albino. And now you plan to go out and kill in his name. What about the laws of the Federation?
The Klingons have their own set of laws, Benjamin... this is justice to them...
And to you... ?
I've chosen to respect their codes of honor in this matter, yes.
You really think you're capable of this?
I don't know. There's only one way to find out, isn't there.
Let's say you are. Let's say you even survive this insanity. You expect to just come back here and resume your duties as though nothing's happened... ?
I guess that'll be up to you.
The compound is constructed of riddinite. Several walls separate the main residence from the rest of the grounds... His main power source is here... that's an armory there...
Any information about the position of the sentries?
They're posted at standing intervals, seventy-five meters apart, along the perimeter.
Standing? No patrols?
That's what I was told.
Perhaps he thinks we are already dead and have stopped chasing him.
Or perhaps he has made his defenses look weak for our benefit.
She may be right.
We have to assume the guards patrol the perimeter... but at seventy-five meters apart, they'd be out of eye contact with each other...
He wouldn't be that stupid. We should expect them to be no farther than fifty meters apart.
Fine. It makes no difference...
Doesn't it? If we accept that he has adequate defenses, with a minimum of fifty guards, then we ought to use a N'yengoren strategy.
No!
I will not sneak into his bedroom and murder him like a kah'plakt. I want him to see us coming for him.
I say we attack here... a bold assault right at the main threshold. The guards will be too scattered to respond in time. We will overwhelm the defenders and fight on to a glorious victory.
Or to a glorious death.
It is a good day to die.
It is a good day to die.
Come on, old comrade. For the last time, we'll sharpen our blades.
So. We're talking about dying again.
A Klingon warrior is always prepared to die.
Yes. But to invite death with a direct assault against a superior force... ? (he avoids her look, a beat) What are you doing, Kang... What is really going on here...
Loyalty blinds Kor and Koloth, but not me. This is not a plan for battle -- it is a plan for suicide. If it were someone else, I would almost think you'd been paid to lure us here.
How can you say that to me? I took a blood oath with you.
Is this the reason you didn't want me to come? Because you knew you were coming here to die?
When the amulet arrived with the location of the Albino, I went to the Secarus system to see if it was true. Somehow, the instant I arrived the Albino knew I was there.
How did you know?

He contacted me. He sent an invitation... to one last glorious battle. He said he is tired of this lifelong pursuit. He swore to send forty of his strongest and most skilled guards against us in honorable combat. And I agreed.
But why?
This is our last chance. If we cannot reach the Albino, we can at least die an honorable death trying to reach him. A death a Klingon Dahar Master deserves!
You know what, Kang? You Klingons embrace death too easily. You treat death as a lover. I think living is a lot more attractive. I think an honorable victory is a lot better than an honorable defeat.
I know the Albino's defenses. There is no chance of victory here.
What if they had no phasers. That might make our odds a little better, don't you think?
How do you intend to disarm them all?
Once we establish a low orbit, we modulate your disruptor banks to bombard the compound with tetryon particles... every directed energy weapon will be neutralized...
You're certain such a thing can be done?
If Curzon were here, you'd be out of luck. But Jadzia Dax is a science officer.
We would also be unable to use our disruptors. But who among them could match our skills with the bat'leth?
Not many.
We're forty minutes away from the Secarus System. I suggest we cloak and then you and I, old friend, should sharpen our blades too.
Perhaps... it is a good day to live!
Several alien guards with ominous masked faces (perhaps akin to Ninja masks) on patrol.
You say he promised you an honorable battle...
That's right.
Hand to hand combat at the main threshold... ?
Take a look at this.
That looks like a gravitic mine planted under the main threshold.
He plans to detonate it the moment we enter the compound.
That's what you get for making a deal with the devil, Kang.
On the other hand, this gives us an advantage we wouldn't have had
How do we know he's even inside?
Good question.
Wait here.
Where are you going?
To find out if he's inside.
How do you intend to do that?
Ask someone.
We would be wise to shut down his sensor array before we attack. It's controlled from this power station...
Yes, but a power failure will signal our presence. At the same time you shut down the sensors, I will create a diversion at the armory to misdirect their response...
A good strategy. But whoever creates that diversion will have to run all the way across this field to escape...
... with all due respect, none of you are as quick as you once were. I'll volunteer for that job.
Agreed.
It seems our best entry would be here...
I encountered a helpful lookout. The Albino is inside.
His overconfidence will be the death of him.
This is where he is now. But when the attack begins, he will move to a secured command post... here...
It will be midday in one hour... can you create the diversion at the armory by then... ?
I think so...
We will be in position at the power station...
May Kahless guide us on this day of vengeance.
Excuse me...
I seem to be lost. Which way to the tennis courts?
Report.
The armory's been sabotaged... I'm diverting the forward patrols to that area...
Cancel those orders... move all guards to the inner defense line... make sure the power station is secure...
None of the phasers are functioning...
Not functioning?
We're running diagnostics now...
Use long range sensors to check for interference from a cloaked ship in orbit... In the meantime, have the guards fix kuttars to their rifles and prepare for hand-to-...

Kang, Koloth and Kor barge out of the station -- leaving billowing smoke emanating from the structure behind them. Two guards arrive late. Koloth and Kang take them out with their bat'leths with ease. Dax arrives at a corner and joins them ... they move toward the house.
scene: 68   EXT. COMPOUND - AREA INCLUDING STEPS TO POWER

quote: I can't make contact with the power station...
They must have already broken through the inner defense line. Move the perimeter guards into the house...
Sir, without power, we have no communications...
Then get out there and tell them yourself. I don't want that Klingon filth to get in this...
Look upon your executioners, killer of children.
Get them!
Koloth!
That's right. Gang up on the fat old man...
I didn't see him coming...
Even you can't have eyes in the back of your head, my friend... quiet now, rest... I still have work to do...
You will die far quicker than your son did, Kang.
I will not die before you, you thunderous bulk.
The story of your courage will never die... I will sing the story... the children of all Klingons will know of this day...
No vengeance today, Kang.
And who are you, girl?
You knew me as Curzon Dax.
The Trill. Of course. You're far too young and lovely to sport such a deadly weapon.

All right, then, use it if that's what you came to do. Kill me in cold blood. Run me through the belly and cut out my heart... isn't that what your blood oath promised? Or have you lost your appetite, my dear.
Thank you... for saving the death blow for me... you have honored me, one last time... godfather to my son.
Koloth... ?
... He's dead.
I was right, Dax. It is a good day to die.
But never a good day to lose a friend.
(chanting, repeat as needed) Ki-naH-naH, lo-maytoo; Ki-nah-nah, lo-maytaH; ko-no-ma... Ko-no-mayy...
Ko-no-ma... Ko-no... MAAAY...
Hey Jake, I've got a terrific surprise for you.
Oh yeah, what is it?
The two of us are going to Bajor... for the start of the Gratitude Festival.
What's the Gratitude Festival?
It's the biggest Bajoran holiday of the year. Major Kira says it's pretty spectacular.
(the icing on the cake) And, I figured while we were on the surface, we could visit those fire caverns you've been wanting to see.
Sounds great. When do we leave?
This afternoon. Right after school.
For how long?
Three days.
Three days!
Orange juice.

quote: Do I have to go?
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: Well... no... not if you don't want to.
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: Thanks, Dad.
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: Nog and I kinda have plans for tomorrow.

quote: What kind of plans?
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: There's an Andorian freighter due in for a maintenance check tomorrow night.
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: So?
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: It's supposed to be carrying a shipment of those new anti-grav tractors and we're hoping we'll get a chance to see one.
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: Let me get this straight. You'd rather hang around a cargo bay with Nog than visit the Bajoran fire caverns with your old man?
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: Nog's my friend.
scene: 3A   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - THE LIVING ROOM

quote: No need to thank me, Madam. Here at Quark's customer satisfaction is our primary concern. Now you run along back to the dabo table.
(gesturing towards the Bajoran woman) Rom, that lady tells me she misplaced a fat currency pouch.
Yes, brother.
And that you found it.
Yes, brother.
And that you returned it to her intact.
I was dazzled by her beauty.
You worthless, tiny eared fool! Don't you know the First Rule of Acquisition?
Yes, brother.
Then say it.
"Once you have their money... you never give it back."
Exactly. You can ponder its meaning this evening while polishing every rail in the place. Now get out of my sight before I toss you out the nearest airlock.
Nog!
Is this what they teach you at that human school of yours? Sloth and indolence...
No, father.
We'll see about that. Tonight you'll polish every rail in the place until they sparkle. Is that clear?
Yes, father. Tonight, every rail.
... And so the Andorian says... "your brother? I thought it was your wife"... Get it... "wife!"
Had to think about that one, didn't you?
I'm looking for Quark.
You found him.
I am Krax... and this is my father... Grand Nagus Zek.
It really is him.
Tell me, is the Grand Nagus here on business or pleasure?
Is there a difference?
No, of course not.
My father will reveal the purpose of his visit when he sees fit. As for now, he desires the use of a Holosuite. He's heard that some of your programs are quite... alluring.
Oh, they are. But they may prove a touch... energetic... for his advanced years.
Are you refusing his request?
Not at all. Not at all. Is there a particular... activity... he'd like to sample?
The Nagus dislikes having to choose between so many delightful possibilities.
In that case, here's a list of five programs that rank among my personal favorites. I'd be happy to select one for him.
That won't be necessary. The Nagus has decided to try all five.
Sorry I'm late. But the Transporter in Ops needed a minor adjustment in its upper molecular imaging scanner...
... but never mind that. Alright, let's settle down.
Jake... Nog...
Nog!
Thank you.
Now, we only have to get through another two weeks before Mrs. O'Brien returns from Earth. That shouldn't be too difficult, right?
Right. Let's take out our homework padds. We'll begin with the older students. Your last assignment was to write an essay defining the term "ethics." We'll begin with...
Nog.
I don't have my essay.
Why not?
(without missing a beat) My padd was stolen.
Is that a fact? Any idea who did it?
It happened in Quark's. I left it on a table... and there were some Vulcans nearby...
Hold on... are you claiming Vulcans stole your homework?!
Yes, sir.
And why would they do that?
Because they have no ethics?
All right, that's enough.
It's the truth. Ask Jake... he was with me.
Go on. Tell him.
I guess so.
You guess so?
Yeah... they took it. I was there.
All right, but I want that essay turned in tomorrow. Is that understood?
Yes.
I hope so.
Did the Nagus happen to mention how long he'd be using the holosuite?
The Nagus will be done when he is done.
But what if he injured himself?
My father left specific instructions not to be disturbed. Are you suggesting we disobey him?
Forget I ever said anything.
The Grand Nagus, here under our roof. I've never been so proud.
I hope you can live on pride because that's all we'll have left once he's through with us.
You think he's here to take over the bar?
Why else would he come all this way. He's going to buy me out... and for a fraction of what the place is worth.
You can always refuse to sell.
Why didn't I think of that. Idiot, the Nagus doesn't take no for an answer.
Quark!
Good program.
My father requires rest.
I would imagine. Please feel free to use my own... brother's quarters for as long as you're with us.
That should be satisfactory.
Now is there anything else I can do to make your stay a pleasant one?
Invite me to dinner.
I would be honored.
Chief, I just heard that Airlock Nine is jammed again...
I'll put a crew on it immediately, Commander. Ensign Jonas.
So how's school?
We'll muddle through, I imagine. Though I'm counting the days until the missus returns.
The students giving you a hard time?
You know how it is, sir. Kids like nothing better than to take advantage of a substitute teacher. I always did.
I hope Jake's behaving himself.
Jake? He's a fine lad... It's just... well...
Just what?
Just if he were my son, I'd find a friend for him other than Nog.
I'm afraid that's easier said than done. The two of them have become inseparable.
Well, I'd find a way to separate them. That Nog's a bad influence.
I appreciate the advice, Chief. But I trust my son. Besides, if I were to get between them now, it would become me versus Nog. And I'm not going to force Jake to choose between us.
Why not?
Because I'd probably lose.
I doubt that, sir.
That's because your daughter's only three. Wait until she's fourteen.
My compliments, Quark. These tube grubs are chilled to perfection.
Did I say I was finished?
Please, help yourself.
I saw your cousin Barbo recently.
Barbo? I thought he was still in that Tarahong detention center.
They finally released him.
How fortunate.
He told me how the two of you sold those defective warp drives to the Tarahong government. Very clever.
It was nothing really. The Tarahongians are an incredibly gullible people.
He also spoke of how you betrayed him to the authorities and left him to rot behind bars while you kept all the profits...
The sixth rule of Acquisition expressly states...
"Never allow family to stand in the way of opportunity." I certainly never have. You see, I told you he had brains...
You've done well for yourself, Quark.
Not that well...
Never contradict your elders. It's impolite.
Well, I suppose I'm doing... quite well at that.
It was a stroke of brilliance to open a bar so close to a stable wormhole.
But he didn't even know the wormhole existed...
That's what makes it so impressive. He had the instinct... the ears to make the smart move before anyone else did. You could learn from his example.
Boy!
Can I go now? I have homework.
Did he say homework?
(leaning over to his father) There's a Federation school here. Run, by a human. A fee-male.
And you allow your son to attend such a place.
I... I... I... ... never want you to step foot in there again. Now go to your room. And no studying.
My apologies Nagus. It's those Federation do-gooders... always sticking their ugly noses in other peoples business.
Most distressing. Now speaking of business... Quark, I've come to ask you a favor. One that would mean a great deal to me. I need your bar...
I knew it.
And your services as host, for a very important conference to be held here tomorrow.
I would consider it a privilege. And the purpose of this conference... ?
The future. And for Ferengi business interests the future is already here. And its name is the Gamma Quadrant.
Alright, class please turn on your computers. Jake, Luta, I want to see your algebra homework.
scene: 19   INT. SCHOOL ROOM - THE NEXT MORNING (DAY TWO)

quote: Jake. Jake!
scene: 19   INT. SCHOOL ROOM - THE NEXT MORNING (DAY TWO)

quote: Your homework.
scene: 19   INT. SCHOOL ROOM - THE NEXT MORNING (DAY TWO)

quote: Ferengi transport Sepulo has put in at docking bay five.
That's the third Ferengi ship to arrive here in the last eighteen hours.
Maybe it's Quark's birthday.
My advice is to lock up the silverware.
I don't think we have to go that far. Sisko to Odo.
Go ahead, Commander
About all these Ferengi visitors we've been getting...
I'm already on it.
No, no, no...
Is something wrong?
You can't seat Turot next to Hoex. They've been bitter rivals ever since Hoex bought out Turot's controlling interest in the cargo ports on Volchok Prime.
Rom... change this seating arrangement immediately.
Quickly, you fool, before I toss you out the nearest airlock.
I thought you understood this was to be a private meeting.
We're closed. Go away.
What's the delay?
We await the Grand Nagus.
Well he better show his ears soon or I'm leaving.
No one leaves until the conference has concluded.
Still hiding in your father's shadow.
The Nagus casts a very long shadow. Careful you don't disappear in it.
I see we're all here.
Enough drinks.
All right. I'm going.
Quickly.
No!
You stay.
Gentlemen, be seated.
Hey, Nog...
Where were you this morning?
I'm through with school.
What do you mean, "through"?
I mean I don't have to attend those boring classes anymore.
Is this your father's idea?
It's the right decision.
Look, if you want I can talk to Mister O'Brien.
No. I don't belong there.
Don't you want to learn things?
You mean like ethics?
Yeah, and other stuff.
You don't understand. I'm a Ferengi - for me school is a waste of time.
Why's that?
Because there's no profit in it.
So why are you getting mad at me?
Because you're a stupid human. I don't know why I bother with you.
I'm stupid. You're the one not goin' to school. See if I care.
And lastly, I would like to salute Nava, whose takeover of the Arcybite mining refineries in the Clarius system is now complete.
Gentlemen, I congratulate you all. Profits are better than ever...
Nevertheless, it is becoming more and more difficult to find truly lucrative business opportunities here in the Alpha Quadrant.

And why? Because no matter where we go, our reputation precedes us. A reputation that has been tainted by the lies of our competitors who maliciously spread the erroneous impression that we are not to be trusted.

But now thanks to the discovery of the wormhole we can finally avoid such falsehoods. The Gamma Quadrant, gentlemen. Millions of new worlds on our very doorstep. The potential for Ferengi business expansion is staggering.
And best of all, no one there has ever heard the name Ferengi.
Our reputations will be absolutely stainless.
Our word can be our bond.
Until we decide to break it.
It'll be the good old days all over again.
And who shall lead us in this great endeavor?
Who else but my father.
The Nagus. Yes, the Grand Nagus.
I thank you for your confidence... but I must decline the offer.
But father...
I'm old. The fire dims. I'm just not as greedy as I used to be.
Untrue... untrue.
My mind is made up. I've already picked my successor. A leader whose vision, imagination, and avarice will oversee Ferengi ventures in the Gamma Quadrant.
The new Grand Nagus... Quark!
Quark?
He's a lobeless amateur.
Father, have you lost your mind?!
I won't stand for it... It's a mockery... This is outrageous...
Congratulations. I know you'll do a wonderful job.
Oatmeal lumpy again?
scene: 35   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - MORNING - DAY THREE

quote: Nah, just not hungry.

quote: Want to talk about it?

quote: It's Nog. His father's pulled him out of school.

quote: I see...

quote: But you're the one always saying we should make friends with other cultures.

quote: I believe that. And I'm glad you believe it too. But human values and Ferengi values are very different. We've never been able to form a common bond.

quote: So Nog goes his way and I go mine.
scene: 35   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - MORNING - DAY THREE

quote: These things happen.

quote: Hey, how about after school we play a little baseball?

quote: I can't... I have something to do.
scene: 35   INT. SISKO'S QUARTERS - MORNING - DAY THREE

quote: Grand Nagus Quark.
I love the sound of that.
I'm afraid we were never formally introduced. I am Gral... your new best friend.
You wish to serve me?
I wish to protect you.
Protect me?
From those who are jealous of your position and wish to take your place. They can be very dangerous.
How do I stop them?
Leave it to me. I'm not going to allow anybody to hurt such a... grateful friend as yourself.
How grateful am I?
Grateful enough to make sure I have my pick of the most lucrative Gamma Quadrant opportunities.
And if I refuse.
You won't.
Nagus, I'm in desperate trouble.
So am I, and please... call me Zek. Now which would you choose... Risa or Balosnee Six?
I don't quite follow.

For my vacation. My first in eighty- five years. I'm told on Balosnee the soothing harmonies of the tide can cause the most stimulating hallucinations... but when I think of those voluptuous Risian females...
Nagus... Please... Gral just threatened my life...
So he's the first, is he? Well he won't be the last.
But what am I to do? You picked me as your successor... surely you must have some advice...
To survive, you must surround yourself with loyal men.
That's good...
But not too loyal... Never trust anyone who places your prosperity above their own...
I see...
And remember, when in doubt... be ruthless.
Zek... Zek.
I didn't do anything.
Rom... Rom...
Rom... It's Zek... !
What about my father?
Twenty bars of gold press latinum? I'll need to think about it.
In a year it will be worth twice as much.
All right. I'll take it.
You want me to be your bodyguard?
Think of it as a promotion.
But why me?
Because you're the only one left I can trust. You're my closest associate... my friend... my brother.
But I thought since you'll be so busy being Grand Nagus, I could take over running the bar.
You? Run my bar?
Not exactly overcome by grief, are we?
This is a private funeral service.
You have my sympathies for your loss. Nevertheless, when someone dies on my station there are questions I have to ask.
There was nothing suspicious about my father's death. It was caused by a massive infection of the tympanic membrane. A chronic condition.
I hope you won't mind if I have Doctor Bashir examine the body.
That would be difficult.
What is it?
My piece of Zek.
You see, when a Ferengi of my father's stature dies, the body is immediately vacuum-desiccated and sold as a prized collectible.
How touching.
Go ahead.
It wasn't important.
I guess humans and Ferengis don't have a lot to talk about.
That's what my father says.
Mine too. That doesn't mean they're right.
We always had stuff to talk about before.
So what do you say, you still wanna be friends?
Yes. When my father finds out he won't be happy.
Neither will mine. Come on, I have a great idea.
What is it.
So what exactly does it mean... becoming Grand Nagus?
It means that from now on if you wish to speak with me you must first make an appointment with Rom.
Don't be ludicrous.
It's also customary to show respect by kissing my scepter.
I suppose I could make an exception in your case.
You see the discoloration around the impact perimeter? These are sorium and argine traces.
Aren't they Ferengi explosives?
Exactly. What we have here is a Ferengi locator bomb. They're designed to lock on to a target's pheromones.
You mean it's attracted to body odor?
Very accurate. And very deadly. If Quark hadn't lowered his head at the last second...
Commander...
Yes Doctor?
I've given Quark a thorough examination. He's a bit shaken up, nothing more.
In that case, I think it's time we had a little chat with the Grand Nagus.
I'd be delighted.
When are you going to get it through your twisted little brain that we're trying to save your life.
You're trying to interfere in Ferengi affairs of state which are none of your concern.
Now look here, Quark...
Grand Nagus Quark.
Those locator bombs are damn near foolproof. You were lucky once. Next time we could be scraping you off the walls.
The Grand Nagus does not ask for help from outsiders.
I'm sure whoever tried to kill you is counting on that. You must have some suspicions who that could be?
I'm suspicious of everybody.
But who would you say stands to benefit the most from your death?
Let's see... that would have to be Krax. Yes, if anything were to happen to me, he'd become Nagus.
True, but let's not forget that it was Gral who threatened you.
Threatened you? How?
That's none of your concern. Besides, both Krax and Gral were at the funeral when the bomb went off. Which means neither one of them could have set it.
Whoever planned this could have had an accomplice.
You're sure all of Zek's associates attended the funeral?
Yes, yes... they were all there. Look... this is getting us nowhere.
What about Zek's servant?
You mean Maihar'du?
What about him?
Was he at the funeral?
I don't recall seeing him there. Do you?
Now that you mention it... no, I don't.
Interesting. Hupyrian servants are famous for their devotion to their employers.
For Maihar'du not to have shown up at Zek's funeral is very odd indeed.
You were out pretty late last night.
I was?
You came in after midnight.
I guess I got kinda busy doing stuff.
What kind of stuff?
Nothing important. Just hanging around...
With Nog?
We weren't doing anything wrong.
Good. Then you can tell me all about it.
I can't... It's private.
Private?
I gotta go or I'll be late for school.
I want you home in time for dinner. Understood?
Understood.
The thing is... Nagus... I feel I've done all I can in the field of gouge mining.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: You wish to find profit elsewhere.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: Yes, Nagus.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: And where would that be?

quote: I'd like the chance to introduce synthehol to the Gamma Quadrant.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: A very lucrative opportunity. Tell me Nava, when Zek announced I was to succeed him, were you pleased?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: No, Nagus.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: Did you come to me and offer your support.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: No, Nagus.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: Yet, now you call me Nagus. Is it out of true friendship? No.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: You only pretend to show me respect so that I will grant you this immense opportunity.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: Which I am willing to split with you fifty-fifty.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: (without missing a beat) In that case, let's hope the Gamma Quadrant develops a taste for synthehol.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: A very smart deal, Nagus.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: I seem to have a knack for it, don't I. The rest will have to come back tomorrow. All this benevolence wearies me.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: I think I'll head over to the bar and check the receipts.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: Yes, Nagus.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: If he keeps handing out such choice opportunities, he's going to become very popular.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: We'll just have to come up with a new plan. Something more reliable than a locator bomb... something that can't possibly fail to kill my dear brother.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON NAVA

quote: Come in.
I was going to ask you to join me for a round of Jokarian Chess... but I see you're just sitting down to dinner.
I sat down a half-hour ago... about the time Jake was supposed to be home.
Aubergine stew... looks delicious. So where's Jake?
Where else.
With Nog.
Going through my own adolescence was difficult enough. Surviving my son's is going to take a miracle.
Maybe it's time you and Jake had a little talk.
Children need to know their boundaries. I should know, I've been a mother three times and a father twice.
Which was easier?
Actually, I wasn't very successful either way... so feel free to reject what I'm about to say... but if I were you, I'd go find Jake and bring him back here to eat his dinner.
You would?
Absolutely.
Computer. Locate Jake Sisko.
Jake Sisko is in Cargo Bay Fourteen.
Thanks, old man.
Commander, we've finished unloading that Ukan...
Later, Chief...
"There are four -- teen pla -- pla... "
... "planets"
... "planets in the Ba -- jor -- an... " what's that word?
"System."
"Sys -- tem."
That was pretty good.
Want to try some more?
"The lar -- largest ppp -- laa -- net is Bajor. It has th-ree... " (looks to Jake for confirmation) Moons?
You got it. Keep going.
You clumsy idiot...
Do you want to strangle me?
My apologies, Nagus.
Stop daydreaming and pay attention to your work.
Yes, Nagus.
When do we leave?
As soon as you're ready, Nagus.
I always wanted to take a trip through the wormhole. Still it's odd, Zek never mentioned that he'd traveled to the Gamma Quadrant... let alone opened negotiations with one of its worlds.
