Negotiations that you will have the honor of completing. According to Krax, Stakoron Two contains rich deposits of miszinite ore.
A very lucrative opportunity.
Quark... ?
What now?
About the bar... you have so much, and I have so little...
Which is exactly how it was meant to be.
Come, let's not keep our new partners waiting.
May I say, Nagus, that my father himself never looked more commanding.
I've been thinking, maybe it would be wise to take a dabo girl along with us.
Whatever for?
A pretty woman by my side would only add to my prestige. Never underestimate the importance of a first impression.
One look at your imposing features, and the Stakoron negotiators will give us everything we ask for.
All right, if you really think I won't need her...
Believe me. You won't.
Shall we?
This is an historic moment.
Nagus...
There must be some mistake...
There's no ship docked here...
Wait.
Rom, you idiot... Krax, what are you standing there for... ?
... What's the matter with you two? Open this door.
Do you hear me? Open up. You must obey your Nagus.
Sorry, Quark, but you've just been voted out of office.
Rom... Brother... open the door...
So you were going to toss me out an airlock.
I never meant it.
Well I do. "Rom's"... nice name for a bar... don't you think?
Enough talk. Let's get this over with.
Would you like to do the honors or should I?
Release him.
Nagus!
Father?
Looks like you needed my help after all.
But you died.
I saw it happen.
You saw me enter a Hupyrian sleeping trance. Maihar'du taught it to me.
But... why, Father?
It was a test. To see if you were ready to take my place. And you failed miserably.
But you saw for yourself... I was about to grab power...
You don't grab power. You accumulate it... quietly... without anyone noticing.
I don't understand.
The bar, you fool. That was the key. All those visitors stopping on their way to and from the wormhole.
You could have sat there at your leisure and gathered up all the information you needed about the Gamma Quadrant.
But what about him?
You could have let "him" carry the scepter... while you controlled everything from the shadows. Then, when things were running smoothly... only then would you take over.
But, Father...
I'm not interested in excuses. Go back to the ship. We'll be leaving here shortly.
Yes, Father.
It's like talking to a Klingon.
I guess this still belongs to you.
Yes, it looks like I'll have to remain Grand Nagus long enough to establish a Ferengi presence in the Gamma Quadrant. And I was really looking forward to retirement.
If I hear of any good Gamma Quadrant deals you'd be right for, I'll let you know.
You know where to find me.
(looking around one last time) You've done a very profitable job with this place. Who knows, maybe one day I'll come back and buy it from you.
So, you were going to toss me out an airlock.
Forgive me, Brother.
Forgive you? Why Brother, I didn't think you had the lobes.
Such wonderful treachery deserves a reward. I'm making you the assistant manager of policy and clientele here at Quark's.
What exactly does that mean?
How should I know, I just made it up.
Come on, I'll buy you a drink.
So, what time tomorrow?
How about as soon as you get out of school...
Jake.
Dad, what are you doing here?
Waiting for you.
Dad...
You're a great kid, you know that? Now, go be with your friend.
Look, save your energy. We'll have you out of there as soon as possible. (muttering under his breath) I hope.
Try re-routing the power coupling...
Mister O'Brien...
(to repair crew; ignoring the tap.) ... See if you can activate the interlock servos.
Mister O'Brien...
Captain, Jaheel, those people have been stuck in that air lock for over an hour. Now if you'll just wait until we get that door opened, I'll be happy to discuss any problem you might have.
But I've already been waiting two days for your people to readjust my ship's antimatter flow converter.
I'm afraid we've fallen a bit behind in our maintenance schedule.
I'm not interested in hearing excuses. I have a shipment of Tamen Sasheer waiting to be delivered to Largo Five, and I'll need to do better than warp one to get there before it spoils.
I'll try to get a repair crew on it before the end of the day. Now that's the best I can do.
Your best, Mister O'Brien, hardly seems good enough.
Dax to O'Brien.
O'Brien here.
Can you spare a minute, Chief. I have a little problem here at the lab.
On my way.
Thanks for coming, Chief.
What are you doing out here?
Have you checked the EPS convertor?
Yes. First thing.
How about the intensity grid?
It's fine.
Then it's probably the secondary phase modulator. We had trouble with them last week in the main power core.
This should do it.
Anything else I can do for you?
The navigational computer hasn't been working reliably for three days. I ask for the star charts of the Argosian sector and the Glessene sector comes up instead.
Uh-huh.
That's when I can even coax the system on line.
Try it now.
That's more like it.
You look like you could use some
Who has time for sleep... ?
Coffee.
I'd settle for five minutes of peace and quiet.
Chief, I thought you were going to fix the replicators.
You're absolutely right, Sir. I knew I'd forgotten something. Can't have the operations chief sitting around daydreaming when there's work to be done, can we? I'll get right on it.
Fix the Replicators, Chief... My console's off line, Chief... I should've transferred to a cargo drone... no people, no complaints...
Hot coffee black, double sweet.
Tell me, Quark, am I mistaken or is business a little slow today?
Slow? It's been almost nonexistent for the past three days.
Who knows, if things don't improve you may have to close down altogether.
You'd like that, wouldn't you?
Let's just say that without you around, my job would be considerably easier.
Without me around you'd be forced to find some other, poor innocent to persecute. Think about that while you sit here gloating at my misfortune.
Quark!
You call this Kohlanese stew?
If your meal isn't satisfactory I'm sure we could exchange it for something more to your liking.
Aren't you the least bit curious how it tastes?
Oh no you don't. You served it. You're going to eat it.
All right. That's enough.
You heard me. Eat.
I said leave him alone.
Another satisfied customer.
It's these replicators. If I don't get them repaired soon, they'll destroy my business.
Why not get O'Brien to fix them. He has the replicators on the command level working perfectly.
I'm on his waiting list. He assures me he'll get to them as soon as he can.
No telling when that will be. The Chief's a very busy man.
Computer... display a station layout. Highlight locations of all repaired replicators on the command level.
Information restricted to security clearance five and above. Please enter security verification.
Clearance verified.
Here you go, Sir. I think you'll find it more to your liking.
Much appreciated, Mister O'Brien.
Don't mention it, Sir. Unfortunately, there are still plenty of replicators around the station that need looking after...
You all right, Chief?
Bit warm, that's all. Environmental controls must be acting up again.
Please send my regards to Mrs. O'Brien. Jake tells me she's a wonderful teacher.
That's nice to hear, Sir. She's flower units about the lad herself.
Excuse me?
Sir?
What was that you just said?
She's quite fond of the lad herself.
Glad to hear it.
Very good, Sir.
Lieutenant Dax.
Ladies.
Hello, Lieutenant.
I'd forgotten how different it was.
How different what was?
Being female. I haven't been one for over eighty years.
All this attention.
I imagine it must take some getting use to.
Actually I find it quite enjoyable.
Major Kira... Lieutenant Dax...
I'd be honored to have you join my little party. As my guests, of course.
What's all this, Quark? You cheat your one-thousandth customer?

Who says Bajorans have no sense of humor? (pointing to the activity taking place behind him) Actually we're celebrating the repair of the bar's replicator system. Perhaps I could interest you in a nice double-whipped I'danian spice pudding.
What do you think?
I think I'm due back at Ops. But go on, enjoy yourself.
Please, make yourself comfortable, Lieutenant. I did say a double whipped spice pudding, didn't I?
It's lovely. I almost hate to eat it.
By all means, take the time to admire its beauty... While I admire yours.
Chief... ?
(trying to cover, but failing) How can I help you, Major?
You're the one who could use a little help.
I'm fine, really.
I guess this isn't a good time to tell you the number three Turbolift has broken down again.

I'm joking, Chief. (Note: From here on dialogue spoken by characters with aphasia will appear as gibberish in the script. A translation will be provided upon request, but it would probably be more effective if the actors really were unable to communicate.)
Major. Cat's lark pepper.
What?
Let birds go further loose maybe. Shout easy play.
Chief, you're not making any sense.
Round the turbulent quick.
Close the reverse harbor.
Ankle try sound reset gleaming?
Dinner to bug. When.
Chief... wait...
Computer continue neural imaging scan. Stimulate visual cortex.
All visual responses normal.
Computer begin auditory stimuli.
No physiological damage. All brain functions within normal parameters.
Nurse, pull up Mister O'Brien's neuro- physiological history.
Yes, Doctor.
What is it? What's he writing?
Flame the dark true salt.
Please, Chief, have a seat.
Way link complete. Way link.
What's wrong with him?

He appears to be suffering from a form of aphasia. It's a perceptual dysfunction in which aural and visual stimuli are incorrectly processed by the brain. His actual thinking hasn't been affected. But he's incapable of expressing himself or understanding others.
Strike limits victory frosted wake. Simple hesitation.
I'm not sure I follow you, Doctor. You say Mister O'Brien is aphasic, but all of his tests come up negative.
Isn't aphasia typically associated with some kind of cranial trauma?
Yes. It can occur as a result of a stroke or blow to the head. But there's no evidence of that here.
Have you checked the medical library for precedents?
And re-checked. Nothing so far.
Have you any theories?
Not yet.
Find one. Major, get hold of the Chief's personal duty log.
I want to know where he's been and what he's done for the past fifty- two hours.
I've already examine it, Commander. He's been all over this station.
Retrace his steps. See what you come up with. Dax, you will temporarily assume Mister O'Brien's duties.
Yes... I'll...
Is there a problem, Lieutenant?
Lieutenant.
I'm sorry, Benjamin, but... I'm unable to... foolish assembled regal... control weather.

Commander, spontaneous development of aphasia is virtually impossible. But we saw Lieutenant Dax become aphasic before our eyes. That told me we were dealing with a disease that only mimics aphasia. So I ran a full neuro-synaptic comparison of Dax and O'Brien. And found this in the temporal lobes of both patients.
A virus?

It imposes itself within established synaptic pathways and then randomly reroutes them. For example, when I look at this... ... a process occurs in my brain which connects this stimulus to the word "tricorder." The virus disrupts that process.
I'd see the tricorder but I would say something ridiculous like... window.
Exactly.
Doctor, I think you better get over here.
Doctor, I want this station put under emergency quarantine immediately.
Quark, what is going on here?
What's it look like?
It looks like business as usual. But that's impossible, because all shops and business have been closed until further notice.
Except, of course, for essential station operations.
For which this place hardly qualifies.
I don't think they would agree. This quarantine has everyone on edge, Constable. Would you deprive them of a little harmless diversion?
They'd be safer in their quarters.
Quark, that Kohlanese stew... magnificent.
Fortunately my assistant, Rom, was able to fix the replicators.
Yes, very fortunate.
Jake!
I expected you home an hour ago.
Sorry. I was over at Nog's.
Dad, about this quarantine, it's going to be okay, isn't it?
It's just a precaution. Nothing more.
I wish I shared your confidence Commander.
Go on home, son. I'll see you at dinner.
Captain Jaheel, all visitors have been confined to their ships.
Believe me, there is no place I'd rather be.
Then what are you doing here?
Searching for you. Commander, I officially request permission to leave this station.
Request denied.
But none of my crew has been affected by this virus of yours, and unless I depart at once my entire cargo will be ruined...
Captain, I suggest you return to your ship. Now.
Please... I don't want to get sick.
I'm sorry, but until we find a cure for this thing no one's going anywhere.
Let's start with one Ferengi Stardrifter, please. Extra strong.
I thought the front wheels were sticking a bit.
Unauthorized access to crew quarters is a crime, Quark. You could have just asked to use the replicators.
There's an old Ferengi saying, "Never ask when you can take." (trying to hide his annoyance) How did you figure it out, anyway?
You claimed Rom fixed your replicators.
So?
Rom's an idiot. He couldn't fix a straw if it was bent.
You're right. He is an idiot. Remind me to get rid of him tomorrow.
Based on the levels of the virus found in the patients' blood, I believe it's being absorbed through ingestion.
You're saying it's in our food?
That's not possible. All the food on the station is replicated and all the replicators use bio-filters. They automatically screen out contaminants, including viruses.
Major, I have analyzed samples from all over the station. All of the food on the command level is contaminated with the virus.
But all of us here have eaten from those replicators. How come we're not aphasic?
This virus is highly adaptable. Its gestation period seems to vary within each individual.
According to O'Brien's duty log the last thing he did before become aphasic was fix the command level replicators. But I had a repair crew inspect the site. They found nothing suspicious.
Look again. Closer.
Let's shut down the command level replicators. At the very least we can contain this thing.
I'm not sure that's going to do it, sir. I've been getting aphasic patients from all over the station...
But how is that possible...
You can thank Quark.
I caught him using a replicator in one of the vacant crew quarters. He was producing his entire menu out of there.
And contaminating all his customers.
If this virus is present in a large enough segment of the population, it could mean...
What is it, Doctor?
I just took an air sample.
The virus?
It's mutated into an airborne variety.
Which means?
Which means the whole station is infected.

Station log Stardate 46423.7. Nearly sixty percent of DS Nine's population has now contracted the aphasia virus. We are advising all incoming ships to maintain their distance from the station until further notice.
I found it inside the replicator's pattern generator.
O'Brien must have accidently triggered it when he repaired the system.
According to Bashir, it introduced an anomalous programming sequence into the materialization subroutine. In effect it built the virus directly into the replicated food at a molecular level.
So what we have here is sabotage.
Cardassian sabotage.
How can you be sure?
It has a diboridium core for a power source. That's Cardassian technology.
Bashir to Sisko.
Sisko here.
I think you'd better get down here to the Infirmary, Commander.
On my way.
You wanted to see me, Doctor?
Jake?
It's okay, son. It's okay. I'm here.
Left become better control entire hope.
We've converted some empty crew quarters into a hospital ward. He'll be well looked after.
I'll take him there myself.
Commander, when you have a moment... I've found something I'd like to show you.
Money... hand... mine... give.
Well, Quark, I see even you couldn't weasel your way clear of this one.
You underestimate the Ferengi immune system, Commander. I'm merely here to visit some of my less fortunate customers...
To make certain they're not faking the illness to avoid paying their bills.
No one's that devious Quark.
I am.
You... gold... owe... me.
We're doing everything possible.
I'll be back as soon as I can.
The virus is synthetic, Commander. Its nucleotide sequence is too perfect. It's clearly not natural.
You're saying the Cardassians genetically engineered this thing?
That's what I thought at first. But I've studied Cardassian genetic engineering. They always build distinctive monoclonial links into their DNA. This virus has none of those features.
All right, then who made it.
That's what I wanted to find out. So I referenced all known DNA construction techniques in the Federation records...
This protein series was the key. It indicates that...
Doctor, who created this virus?
The Bajorans, sir. I believe this must have been a terrorist plot to sabotage the Cardassians while they were here.
The energy decay of this power core indicates that it dates back to the building of the station.
That's eighteen years ago. I suppose the Bajoran underground could have smuggled it aboard during construction. Before I took over as head of security.
But why would the underground go to all the trouble of planting a booby trap and then not set it off?
Maybe they forgot.
More likely they were captured or killed before they could release it.
We need to find out who created the virus. You're our best hope.
Eighteen years is a long time.
Besides, even if she finds this person... that's no guarantee he can help us.
We just have to hope he remembers the antidote.
That's assuming he ever bothered to create one.
... Had to be someone in the underground familiar with genetic engineering.
Eighteen years ago... sounds like something Dekon Elig might have thought up.
How can I find him?
Last I heard he was in a Cardassian prison.
Where was he being held?
The Velos Seven Internment Camp. But that was nine years ago.
And you have no idea where he is now? Think, Galis. This is important.
I'm sorry Kira, but it was all so long ago.
Roll linger when life. Roll linger when.
What is it, Jake?
Other support strong courage.
He's running a high fever.
Open way long. Openway.
Doctor, we have an emergency here in the crew quarters.
I'll be right there.
How is he, Doctor?
Not good, I'm afraid. It seems the virus has attacked his autonomic nervous system.
Can he be stabilized?
He hasn't responded to neural stimulation. I've given him thirty c.c.'s of corophizine to avoid secondary infection, but so far I've been unable to lower his fever.
What are his chances?
Unless I find some way to counteract the virus, he'll be dead in twelve hours.
(gently; knows Bashir is doing his best) Have you made any progress?

No... I've tried base pair de- stabilizers, sequential disruption, nothing seems to affect it. Sir, I have seven other aphasic patients displaying the same symptoms as O'Brien here. And I'm afraid it's only the beginning.
Keep searching, Doctor. And let's hope Major Kira can find whoever's responsible for creating this virus.
I'd like to meet that person myself. This virus is a work of genius.
I'll try and arrange it for you.
Link established with the Bajoran Archival Records.
Locate files on Velos Seven Internment camp.
Ready.
Do you show a record of an inmate named Dekon Elig?
Affirmative.
Biographical data...
Dekon Elig. Geneticist...
Former member of the Higa Metar Sect of the Bajoran underground. Killed while attempting escape Stardate 39355. Certificate of Death on file.
No need to ask how you're doing.
I'm chasing after ghosts.
You have twelve hours to catch one.
And then?
People start dying.
Computer, display Dekon Elig's Certificate of Death.
Identify signature of witness.
Certificate of Death was witnessed by Surmak Ren, Bajoran Medical Assistant.
Show me biographical data on Surmak Ren.
Doctor Surmak Ren. Former member of the Higa Metar sect of the Bajoran underground. Repatriated to Bajor upon closing of the Velos Seven Internment Camp, Stardate 46302. Current status... unknown.
Dabo!
Having any luck?
I haven't won a spin in hours. Care to place a friendly wager? If it's your reputation you're thinking about... no one need ever know.
It has nothing to do with my reputation. The truth is I've never... ... learned the game.
That's correct.
No wonder you always look so bored. The rules are quite simple, actually. I would be happy to teach them to you...
Some other time perhaps. Sisko needs me in Ops. And with the entire security force stricken with aphasia, that leaves the promenade in a very vulnerable position.
How... unfortunate.
Consider it a warning, Quark. Because I'm holding you personally responsible for anything that turns up missing. Is that understood?
Perfectly.
Dabo!
Computer, analyze test sample thirty- seven delta. Detail effects on viral containment.
Working... Analysis complete. Sample thirty- seven delta ineffective...
... viral protein sheath is unaffected... Nucleotide sequence remains intact...
Computer... Replay morning.
Command unclear. Please repeat.
Glass lunch judge a bin to let it...
Command unclear. Please repeat.
Computer, establish link with the Bajoran Medical Index for Northwestern District...
Link established.
Access all information on Doctor Surmak Ren.
There are no records matching that name.
Try the Northeastern District. Same search.
Doctor Surmak Ren, currently serving as Chief Administrator of the Ilvian Medical Complex.
Computer, open a channel to the Ilvian Medical Complex... Administrators office.
This is Doctor Surmak. And you are?
Major Kira Nerys. Bajoran liaison to Deep Space Nine.
Ah yes, the old Cardassian mining station. How can I help you?
That depends.
On what?
On whether or not you helped Dekon Elig plant an aphasia virus here, eighteen years ago.
I have no idea what you're talking about.
Look here, Sisko. I'm a security officer. A good one. But that doesn't make me qualified to help you run station operations.
You're probably right, Constable...
But as you can see, you're all I've got.
Commander, I think I found our scientist.
Does he have an antidote?
I don't know. He broke the connection the minute I mentioned the virus.
Major, you mind telling me where you're going?
To continue my conversation with Doctor Surmak.
Major, I can't allow you to break quarantine. We can't risk spreading the virus to Bajor.
I'm well aware of that, Commander. As a matter of fact, I don't intend to step foot on the planet.
Better let her go, Sisko.
She's all we've got.
I just hope there's someone left to greet her when she returns.
Jake!
How's it going, fella?

I've missed you, son. I know things don't look too good right now. But they'll get better. You have to believe that. Because... I'm not going to lose you, Jake. You hear me? I'm not going to lose you.
You better take a look at this... We have activity on Docking Port Five. I think a ship's about to depart.
Docking Port Five? That's Jaheel's ship. Put him on screen.
Captain, your ship has not been cleared for departure. The mooring clamps are locked. And I don't intend to release them.
I suggest you change your mind. I'm taking aft thrusters to one half.
Captain, cut your engines before you rip your ship apart.
He's not reducing power.
Jaheel, I'm ordering you to stand down.
Your orders are no concern of mine. My entire crew has been confined to your hospital. I must leave now while I can still function.
Look, I understand you're frightened. But believe me, you're better off here. You don't want to be out there alone and get hit by the virus.
Don't worry about me. I'm fine and I intend to stay that way.
Damn.
What's wrong?
There's too much stress on the mooring clamps. They're not retracting.
His aft isolation plate buckled.
The main power core's been ruptured. If the internal fuel cells collapse the whole ship will explode.
And take half the docking ring with it.
Computer, isolate a comline to the Ilvian Medical Complex. Administrator's office.
Line isolated.
Scan the office for lifeforms.
One life form present.
Lock on and stand by to transport.
This is Doctor Surmak.
Hello again, Doctor. Just wanted to make sure you were in your office.
I have nothing to say to you...
Welcome aboard.
This is outrageous. I demand you return me to my office immediately.
Relax, Doctor. You won't be gone long.
Where are you taking me?
To the space station.
Try to re-establish visual contact with Jaheel's ship.
No response. His com lines are down.
Bypass communications through his secondary grid. See if you can switch to external pickups.
Got it.
His fire control systems don't appear to be working.
We have about fifteen minutes before the fuel cells collapse.
I hope you feel better than you look.
It must be that damn virus. This is Sisko.
Any station personnel who can understand what I'm saying should come to Ops immediately. We need help up here. We have to get that ship away from the station.
Why don't we explode the mooring clamps. The blast should push the ship away from the docking ring.
We'll have to get down there and blow them manually.
I'll do it.
All right... you can cross barrels all job appalled.
What was that you...
Bread the arrive seen earlier.
Oh, I see...
Major, this is kidnapping. Turn this ship around or I swear you'll spend the rest of your life in Kran- Tobol Prison.
Fine. But first we need your help. The aphasia virus is spreading through the station.
But why come to me.
You helped create the virus didn't you.

No! I had practically nothing to do with it. Dekon Elig created the virus. I was merely his medical assistant. It all seems like a life time ago. I was only with the underground six months before we were captured. I am not responsible for this.
I'm not looking to place blame. All I want is the antidote.
But I don't know of any antidote. If Dekon made one, he never told me.
Look, all I know is I have a station full of dying people, and you're the closest thing to an expert on this virus.
I sympathize, Major. But I don't think I can help you.
All right, then how about helping yourself?
Meaning what?
(leaning toward him for emphasis) Meaning I've been infected with your virus, Doctor. So now you're infected too.
To anyone who can hear me... this is Odo. Sisko's infected. I could really use some help in Ops.
Do I detect a note of panic in your voice?
Quark, am I to believe you're volunteering to help?
Who said anything about volunteering? But we can haggle over price later. Now how may I be of service?
I need to get to Docking Port Five, now. That ship is going to explode in five minutes.
I'll beam you over.
Relax. I served on a Ferengi freighter for eight years.
(carefully, studying panel) I must have witnessed this procedure hundreds of times.
Witnessed? You mean to say you never handled the controls yourself?
Energizing.
Kira to Ops. Approaching landing pad seven. Request clearance to initiate docking procedure.
Welcome back Major. I could use some help up here.
Quark what are you doing in Ops?
First thing I need to see is your Doctors' viral characterization research.
He was beginning to develop an antidote series. Let's take a look at that.
I'll be in Ops. If you need me use the string...
... impact lots show red intense.
I think you'd better sit down, Major.
Dog fellow distance.
Tell me about it.
Odo, that ship's going to explode in one minute.
scene: 91   INT. OPS - TIGHT ON QUARK AT OPERATIONS TABLE

quote: Virum protein sheath... uh-huh... Nucleotide sequence... yes... That's right, it's an adaptive synaptic inhibitor... Dekon was brilliant, there's no doubt of that.
Forty seconds.
Thirty seconds. Hurry.
Twenty seconds.
I know. I know.
Quark to Odo. You still with us?
Try not to sound too disappointed.
Now, about that little matter of my hazard pay...
Your doctor came very close to finding the antidote himself. The answer is in a progressive base substitution.
Now I just need to take a blood sample.
Station log, Stardate 46425.8. We're continuing to administer Doctor Surmak's antidote throughout the station. Things are slowly returning to normal.
Good to have you back, Chief.
Thank you, sir.
Hot coffee, black.
O'Brien... !
What can I get for you?
A Til'amin froth for me.
Romulan ale.
A glass of springwine.
Since when do you drink springwine -- or anything else, for that matter?
It's for Kira. She should be getting out of services any minute.
Here she is.
How was it?
Beautiful.
Ranjen Telna gave a very moving sermon.
What was it about?
How important it is to be able to forgive people who've wronged us.
Two hours on forgiveness?
It's a big subject.
What's wrong?
Nothing. It's just... you spend so much time in services. Sometimes it makes me wish I was a believer so we could go together.
That's so sweet...
I'd love for you to come, but you wouldn't get much out of it if you don't believe in the Prophets.
Maybe if I had an Orb experience... ?
That's not the way it works. Faith has to come first.
Too bad. I have a feeling it must be very... comforting to believe in something more powerful than yourself.
If you really feel that way, there are other faiths.
Would it bother you if Odo became a believer in... -- Klingon religion?
Not as long as he gets something out of it.
He'd get to eat the hearts of his enemies.
And go to Sto'Vo'Kor when he dies.
But I wouldn't get to go to services with Kira, would I? And that's the whole point.
(unaccountably moved) That really is so sweet...
Yes.
(surprised and glad to see him) Vedek Fala...
Nerys.
I can't believe it. What are you doing here?
I came to see you.
Come in, sit down. Let me get you some tea.
I contacted the University a few months ago -- they said you were on some sort of spiritual retreat?
You know me -- always searching for answers.
That's what makes you different from other vedeks I've known. For you, Faith is a journey.
One that never ends...
So you're a colonel now... It seems like only yesterday you were just a little girl, squirming in her chair during instruction.
(smiling as she corrects him) There were no chairs in the camp -- we sat on the floor.
Which was good for discipline -- it made me seem more imposing.
As if you needed help. (in a stern teachers voice) "Nerys, what are the three keys to enlightenment?"
And the answer?
Charity, humility and faith.
You remember.
You were a good teacher. Without you, I'm not sure I would've survived that camp.
I brought you something.
What is it?
Welcome to Empok Nor...
Empok Nor? That's impossible.
I know it's a long way from Deep Space Nine -- This transponder allowed us to beam you here.
Those armbands... you belong to the cult of the Pah-wraiths...
We worship the True Prophets, yes.
Why did you bring me here?
That's a question best answered by the Master.
And who, exactly, is "The Master?"
I am.
Dukat... ?
You -- you're the leader of the Pah-wraith cult?
I'm sure you have many questions, Nerys, and I intend to answer them all.
Leave us, please.
First of all, let me apologize for bringing you here without your permission.
It's all right, I've always wanted to see Empok Nor. Is the Dominion aware you've set up a... "temple" here?
The station has been abandoned a long time. They have no reason to object to our making use of it.
Your hair... you changed it.
Your ear... you pierced it.
(touching the dangling chain) A symbol of the Covenant I've made with my new family...
Your new family... Well, I guess it makes sense that these people would choose you as their leader -- they worship evil.
The Pah-wraiths aren't what you think. And neither am I.

Let me ask you something. Have you ever wondered why the Prophets stood by and did nothing when the Cardassians took over Bajor? Have you ever asked yourself why they would allow your people to suffer?
The Prophets have a plan for us -- but it's not always easy to see what it is.
Even as you say those words, you must know how hollow they sound. There's a better explanation. One that makes perfect sense. The Prophets aren't the true gods of Bajor, the Pah-wraiths are.

They were cast from the Celestial Temple because they wanted to take an active role in Bajoran life. Their only crime was that they cared about your people. But they weren't allowed to help you because they lost the battle for heaven and were forced to flee.
I guess the Ancient Texts have it all wrong, then.
We both know that history is always written by the victors. But rest assured, there'll be another chapter.
The Pah-wraiths are determined to regain their place in heaven.
And how would you know that?
They speak to me in visions. I am their Emissary.
I don't know if you believe what you're saying, if you're faking it, or if you're just insane.
I was touched by the hand of a god. I'm a changed man.

Oh, I admit, when I allowed myself to become a vessel for the Pah-wraith, I did it for self- serving reasons. I wanted to help it enter the wormhole so it could force the Prophets out. It was nothing more than a way to exact vengeance on Sisko. But I had no idea the effect it would have on me. It was only inside me for a short time, but it opened my heart.
Would that be before or after you killed Jadzia?
That was most unfortunate, but it couldn't be helped. The Celestial Temple itself was at stake, and she was in the way.

Nerys, I wish I had the words to describe what it was like to have the Pah-wraith within me. I could feel its love -- for me, and for the Bajoran people. it made me realize that I still had a role to play in Bajor's destiny.
You mean besides overseeing an occupation that killed tens of millions?
You have no idea how much it pains me to know that I caused so much suffering. But I'm not responsible for the Occupation, the Prophets are.
You have no right to say that.
They abandoned Bajor. I was only walking the path they laid down for me. Now I walk with the true Prophets.
I'm building a community here, Nerys. I brought these people to Empok Nor so we could purify ourselves in preparation for the day the Pah-wraiths reclaim the Celestial Temple.
And what's supposed to happen when that day comes?
The Pah-wraiths have a plan for Bajor. When the time is right, they'll reveal it to me.
Something tells me their plan is going to involve you becoming ruler of Bajor again.

You're still so full of anger toward me. I can only hope that in time, you'll let it go. I brought you here because I want you to be part of our community. I want you to share in the love these people have for each other -- in the love they have for me.
These people don't love you. You have some kind of hold over them, but love?
Open your heart to me, Nerys. We're bound together by destiny. You belong at my side.
When did you realize she was missing?
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: This morning -- she usually comes by my office before she goes to Ops.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Did you check the entry log?
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: She had a visitor a little after nineteen hundred hours. Whoever it was only stayed about ten minutes.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Anything?
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: According to the Ops report, only one ship has left the station since last night -- the morning transport to Bajor. Kira was not aboard.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Sir, I'm picking up traces of tachyon energy.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: A transporter beam?
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: With a Dominion signature.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Is there any way to trace it?
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Afraid not, the signal's already dissipated.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Their transporters operate over longer distances than ours -- what's their maximum range?
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: If a homing transponder is in place, up to three light years.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: There was a homing transponder, all right.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: It was wrapped inside this.
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: Three light years... for all we know, she could be deep inside Dominion space by now...
scene: 8    INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - KIRA'S QUARTERS

quote: I had a feeling you'd turn up sooner of later.
I know you're angry with me --
Angry? I feel sorry for you. Letting yourself be duped by Dukat into joining this cult.
I was a member of this "cult," as you call it, long before Dukat.
I came to it toward the end of the Occupation. It's helped me make sense of the suffering we all had to endure.
In the camp, you kept us together -- it was your faith in the Prophets that got us through. I can't believe that you -- of all people -- would turn your back on them.
They turned their backs on us long ago.
The path they've laid out for us may not be easy, but that's no reason to turn to hate and fear.
"Hate and fear" -- do you know how often I've heard those words used to describe us? Nothing could be further from the truth.
The Pah-wraith cult tried to kill the Emissary.
Dukat had nothing to do with that. The boy who attacked Captain Sisko was acting out of his own misguided beliefs.
We're peaceful people.
Prove it. Let me go.
Nerys, the Master brought you here because he cares about your spiritual well-being.
The "Master" -- he's using you. He's taking your beliefs and twisting them to suit his own purposes.
You're so stubborn -- that's always been your problem.
Your problem is that you've always been too trusting.
When Dukat first came to us, I didn't want to accept him. But I came to realize that the Pah-wraiths had taken this man of evil and washed him clean. What could be more wondrous than that?
How can you forget all the friends we lost during the Occupation? How can you forget the millions Dukat murdered?
You disappoint me. Of all the things I tried to teach you, the most important was the need to forgive.
There are some things that can't be forgiven.
Nerys, let me show you how we live. I want you to see the community we're building here so that you'll know that you have nothing to fear from Dukat -- or from us.
-- only one of the fusion generators is operational, so we don't have power for things like replicators.
Where do you get your food?
We've turned several of the lower levels into hydroponic bays.
What about things like medical supplies -- do you bring them from Bajor?
We have a few cargo shuttles. We're well aware that you might try to leave us. You should know that the docking bays are being guarded. As is the transporter we used to bring you here.
As long as we're on the subject, am I free to move around, talk to people?
Of course. It's the Master's hope that you'll come to see this as your home.
Mika, this is Nerys.
Welcome.
You're getting close.
It could be any time now.
Mika and her husband have the honor of being the first to receive the Master's blessing to bear children.
You need Dukat's permission to have a baby?
Vows of abstinence are part of our Covenant with him. Exceptions are granted only when he sees that a wife and her husband have demonstrated a true spiritual bond.
I see...
You don't approve. In ancient times, Bajorans understood the value of denying worldly pleasures. Ironic, isn't it, that a Cardassian would lead us back to the old ways?
Especially a Cardassian who's appetite for worldly pleasures is legendary.
That was a long time ago, before he felt the kiss of the Pah-wraith.
Must've been some kiss.
Striking, isn't it?
Benyan is Mika's husband.
Congratulations. I understand it isn't easy to get... permission to have a baby.
The Master told us you wouldn't approve of our ways. He said we should be patient with you.
Don't go out of your way.
I don't understand why he brought you here.
Benyan --
No, it's all right.
We've all worked hard for what we have. We don't need you or anyone else to approve of us.
Fair enough.
Don't misunderstand. I hope you come to feel the love of the Pah-wraiths. But if you don't... that's your loss. No offense.
None taken. In fact, I've always found that people who try to convince others of their beliefs are usually trying to convince themselves.
I know what I believe.
That's what scares me. No offense.
-- ba'ja kor'ek, no'la ba'lani, pah'nom ko'se plusso ma'kora. Ba'ja kor'ek, no'la ba'lani, pah'nom ko'se plusso ma'kora.
Kosst no'valt Amojan, my children. (The love of the Pah- wraiths be with you.)
Kosst no'valt Amojan.
Let us open our hearts and pray.
Ba'ja kor'ek, no'la ba'lani, pah'nom ko'se plusso ma'kora. Ba'ja kor'ek, no'la ba'lani, pah'nom ko'se plusso ma'kora.
Don't.
Dukat.
Stay where you are.
The rest of you -- get down on the floor.
I said on the floor.
Move aside.
No.
Enough, Nerys, unless you're willing to kill us all.
Now do you understand how much they love me... ?
Careful, no sudden moves.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: (indicating her JACKET lying nearby) I removed it so I could tend to your bruise.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: (indicating a nearby TRAY) I had a meal prepared for you.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I'm not hungry.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Go ahead, you haven't eaten since you arrived.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I know what you're thinking. But really, what good would it do to try to kill me? Even if you succeeded, it wouldn't get you off Empok Nor. You'd only be making me a martyr.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: If it wasn't for me, the occupation would've been much worse.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: And you want a thank you? You were working people to death in the ore processing centers, but that didn't stop you from strutting around Terok Nor, picking out Bajoran women to take to your bed. And actually believing they wanted to be there.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Your mother wanted to be there.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: You took her away from her children. She did what she had to in order to make sure we survived.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: She loved me.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Maybe she convinced herself she did -- and that's a very different thing.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Perhaps you're right. And if I caused your mother any pain, I regret it.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Just as I regret many other things I did in those years. Thankfully, the Pah-wraiths have given me an opportunity to redeem myself in the eyes of your people.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: How? By recreating some idealized version of the Occupation? Because that's exactly what you're doing here. You have your station back, Bajorans to serve your every whim. And the best part is, this time they really do love you. As misguided as it is, they love you.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I'm so glad you're here, Nerys.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: You embody everything I admire most about the Bajoran people. Your passion, your spirit. I see now why the Pah-wraiths want you at my side.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: And why's that?
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Because if I can open your heart to them, then surely I can open the heart of any Bajoran. Yes, your anger is a challenge. But I welcome it. Because in the end, it will help me better serve the Pah-wraiths.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Yes.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: It's Mika. She's gone into labor.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Come, Nerys. I want you to be a witness to this blessed event.
scene: 20   INT. EMPOK NOR - DUKAT'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I've been told Mika is on her way out. This is a great day for us, Benyan. You should be honored to have fathered the first child born to our community.
The Pah-wraiths... they've sent us a sign...

My children, something wondrous has happened. This infant -- born of the love between Benyan and Mika -- was transformed in her womb into a living symbol of the Covenant I've made with you. What a blessed day this is -- there can no longer be any doubt that the Pah-wraiths are smiling upon us.
Let us give thanks and praise.
Ka'li bor'ek, no'ma ten'su, fah- jah nori bentu'sa. Ka'li bor'ek, no'ma ten'su, fah-jah nori bentu'sa.
You're an intelligent man. How can you believe Dukat's story? It's obvious he's the baby's father.
What's obvious is that you hate him so much, you can't even entertain the possibility that a miracle occurred.
Are you so blind you'll believe anything he says?

I have faith. I would think you'd understand what that means. Nerys, is it so beyond the realm of possibility that the Pah- wraiths sent that child to us as a sign? They have powers beyond our understanding. Your Prophets made an entire fleet of Dominion ships vanish into thin air! What's one child compared to a miracle like that?

You know what the miracle was? That Mika was able to keep from breaking into tears in front of her husband. She was terrified he wouldn't believe Dukat's little performance. I could see it in her eyes.
You saw what you wanted to see.
If you really believe it was a miracle, then you won't mind if I talk to the happy couple.
What's wrong? Are you afraid to find out the truth?
I know the truth. I just don't want you making unfounded accusations.
I'll be discreet.
It's coming along nicely...
Maybe you should make one of the children half-Cardassian?
To commemorate what's happened.
If I'd known, I would've.
(neutral but leading) It must be quite an honor to be part of such a miraculous event...
It is.
Obviously Dukat did the right thing when he gave you permission to have a baby.
We prayed together many times... he wanted to be sure.
Did you ever pray with him alone?
Yes.
Did Mika?
Yes.
Nerys, we should let Benyan get back to work.
You saw his face.
He was angry -- he knew what you were implying.
There's Mika.
When we find her, I trust you'll be more discreet than you were with Benyan.
I'm sorry.
Why didn't you tell me the baby was mine?
I didn't know. I was hoping it wasn't.
Mika, I'm so sorry about what happened that night. I was weak... and you were so beautiful.
I've forgiven you. You know that.
Have you told anyone?
No...
Not even Benyan?
He wants to believe it was a miracle, but I know he has doubts. If he ever asks me, I don't know if I can lie to him.
He says he saw her come this way.
Don't worry, everything's going to be all right...
Wait here until I'm gone, then go back to you quarters and pray for strength.
Mika?
Mika.
You got to her just in time.
How is she?
The depressurization caused swelling in her meningeal tissues -- I'm going to keep her sedated until morning.
But she's going to recover?
She'll be fine.
Seal the docking ring and have all the airlocks inspected -- let's make sure we never have another accident like this.
Accident?
What happened, Dukat? Was she going to tell everyone that you're the father of her child?
Kira --
Is that why you tried to kill her?
Enough.
It's all right, Fala. Nerys is obviously upset. She doesn't know what she's saying.
Mika won't lie for you anymore.
Take her to her quarters. She needs to rest.
Don't let him near her --
Let us pray for Mika's recovery.
Ka'la mo'sek, teru-benso, Kosst Amojan golis rej.

I failed you. Forgive my weakness. Forgive me for letting temptation obscure the path you've laid out for me. When Mika awakes -- and I pray she does -- your children will learn the truth. They'll turn away from me... they'll turn away from you. The Covenant will be broken. Don't let that happen. Tell me what to do. Please.
It's not time for services...
I'll stay with her if you want to go.
You go.
Kosst no'valt Amojan, my children.
Kosst no'valt Amojan.
Tonight, while I prayed, the Pah- wraiths sent me a vision.
They told me it was the last I'd ever receive from them.
There's a reason for this... a wondrous reason.
My children, the Pah-wraiths have asked us to join them in their Holy quest to reclaim the Celestial Temple.
To become warriors in this great battle, we must transform ourselves... our corporeal bodies are not suitable for the task ahead... so we must leave them behind.
In a few hours, at the start of the new day, we'll gather together here for the last time. We will shed the flesh that ties us to this world...
And deliver ourselves into the waiting arms of the Pah- wraiths...
Ka'li bor'ek, no'ma ten'su, fah- jah nori bentu'sa.
Ka'li bor'ek, no'ma ten'su, fah- jah nori bentu'sa.
I sent a message to Deep Space Nine. They should be able to get someone here for you within a day or so.
I know you're desperate to keep your followers from turning against you. It doesn't surprise me that you're willing to kill them. But I can't believe you're willing to die yourself.
You don't understand, Nerys.
The Pah-wraiths are calling me home. You should be happy.
Happy? Fifty people are going to die.
I assure you, our deaths will be painless.

Promazine. It was developed by the Obsidian Order for its operatives to use in case of capture. Not only is death swift, it reduces the body to dust within hours, making it unidentifiable to the enemy. Dust... that's all that'll be left of my passage through this misbegotten universe. But it doesn't bother me. Because I know that I'm going to be with the Pah-wraiths.
You really believe that.
Good-bye, Nerys.
My children, the time has come for us to leave this world behind...
-- as we embark on this journey, our hearts are not heavy, but joyful. Because we know we'll be together in the holy light of the Pah-wraiths.
This is a great day for us...
scene: 67DD INT. EMPOK NOR - PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL

quote: We have proven ourselves worthy of them. They're calling us home.
This is the means of our deliverance...
Kosst no'valt Amojan, my children.
Kosst no'valt Amojan.
Don't be afraid... I love you all...
Dukat.
Don't you see why he's doing this?
He doesn't want you to find out the truth!
Are you all right?
Everyone, please. Let's not allow anything to disrupt this holy moment.
What's wrong, Dukat? Take it.
Go ahead. They're all the same, aren't they?
My children, listen to me.
Tell them, Dukat -- tell them you never had any intention of dying with them.
My time here is not finished.
The Pah-wraiths want me to continue bringing others into their light.
This is your child, isn't it? That's why you tried to kill Mika.
(desperate to explain) The Pah-wraiths have forgiven my sins. They've given me their absolution.
Who are you to presume they're wrong? Who are you to judge me?
Then it's done. Our Covenant is broken.
None of you will ever know the love of the Pah-wraiths. None of you!
Fala, no.
Why?
Faith, Nerys. Faith...
I'm sorry about Vedek Fala...
I keep going over what he said when he died. I don't know if he was trying to tell me that he never lost his faith... or that he felt betrayed by it.
I suppose you'll never know... One thing's for certain, these people were betrayed. And now they have to find a way to pick up the pieces and move on.
I thought Dukat was just claiming to share their faith because he wanted them to love him. But it was more than that. He's changed.
Has he? If you hadn't stopped him, he would've killed them all, and no one would've known that his body wasn't among the remains. That sounds like the same old Dukat to me.
I know this is going to sound crazy... but I think he convinced himself that he was doing what the Pah-wraiths wanted.
Who knows, maybe he was.
Either way, he believes. And that makes him more dangerous than ever...

Ah, Romulus. How well I remember it. You will find the predominant color to be gray. The buildings. The clothes. The people. Did you know that the Romulan heart itself is gray? It's true. And entirely appropriate for such an unimaginative race.
I take it you didn't enjoy your brief stint on Romulus. You were posing as a... gardener weren't you?
One of the few instances where my cover proved to be more enjoyable than the actual assignment.
What was that assignment by the way?
I'm afraid I can't talk about that. Back to the subject at hand. What will your role be at the conference?
I'll be giving a talk on Dominion biogenic weapons, chairing a seminar on Ketracel White, and attending a meeting on a proposal to transfer twenty-five Federation hospital ships to Romulan control.
How dull.
Sorry to disappoint you. Admiral Ross and his staff will be discussing the "exciting" military issues.
I see. I trust Starfleet Intelligence will be sending someone along to make good use of this opportunity.
What do you mean?
Isn't it obvious? This is a golden opportunity to gather intelligence on Romulan intentions and military capabilities.
They're our allies, Garak. And with a bit of luck, this could be the beginning of a entirely new relationship between our peoples.
The eternal optimist.
Guilty as charged.

How sad. I must tell you it's a bit disappointing to hear you mouthing the usual platitudes about peace and friendship regarding an implacable foe like the Romulans. But, I live in hope that someday you'll see the universe as it truly is, rather than as you wish it to be.
I shall endeavor to become more cynical with each passing day.
To look gift horses in the mouth and find clouds in every silver lining.
If only you meant it.
Lights.
Sloan...
Hello, Doctor. It's good to see you. I hope you're well-rested. Section Thirty-one has an assignment for you.
You're taking quite a risk. I could have a security team here in thirty seconds.
I suspect you'd be unable to communicate with anyone outside this room.
I could scream for help.
Possible, but uncharacteristic. Screaming for help is too undignified for you. But don't let me stop you -- I enjoy being wrong.
What is it you want?
I told you -- you have an assignment.
I don't work for you.
You passed the test. You were accepted into the organization.
I wasn't asking to be accepted.
You were nevertheless. Now it's time to go to work. I'm sure you're dying to know what your mission is, but you won't give me the satisfaction of admitting it. So I'll just tell you.
Lucky me.

Section Thirty-one is extremely interested in this conference of yours. However, the Tal'Shiar will be handling the security arrangements, so we have virtually no chance of using any technical assets to gather intelligence. As a result, we'll be forced to rely on organic assets like you. Your assignment is to gather data on the Romulan leadership. In essence, we want you to take the pulse of their government, no pun intended.
You're asking me to spy on an ally.

To evaluate an ally -- and a temporary ally at that. I say that because when the war's over, the following will happen in short order: The Dominion will be forced back to the Gamma Quadrant. The Cardassian Empire will be occupied. The Klingon Empire will spend the next ten years recovering from the war and won't pose a major threat to anyone. That leaves two powers to vie for control of the quadrant -- the Federation and the Romulans.
This war isn't even over and you're already planning for the next one.
Well put. I hope your report is equally succinct.
I don't know how many more times I can say this, but I don't work for you.
You will. It's in your nature.
You're a man who loves secrets. Medical. Personal. Fictional. I am a man of secrets. You want to know what I know. And the only way to do that... is to accept the assignment.
Easy Julian!
What's going on?
Item seven -- warbird repair and maintenance. Senator?
Repairs on our ships are continually being delayed in favor of Klingon and Federation vessels.
The Dividices and the Genorex have been waiting almost three weeks while more than a dozen Klingon ships have been given first priority.
I make up the repair schedule according to my assessment of which ships have the greatest need.
Odd that the Klingons seem to always have the greatest need.
They are usually more damaged because Klingon warships are relentless in pressing home their attacks.
Reckless would be another way of putting it.
The fight must be taken to the enemy. The war cannot be won if --
We're not here to debate combat tactics. Chief, how soon can you get those warbirds to a docking bay?
I suppose I could bring them in tomorrow and delay repairs to the Hornet and the Rotarran. But someone's going to have to explain to General Martok why his flagship got bumped.
Worf, you just volunteered for that assignment.

This brings up the question of shore leave. At the moment, we have the crews from two Klingon ships on the station. I'd rather not have that many Klingons and Romulans on the Promenade at the same time.
We'll forgo shore leave until the Klingons depart.
Our soldiers are professionals. They're here to fight, not to get drunk in Quark's.
Then that's it for today. Same time next week? Oh -- sorry, senator, you'll be attending the conference on Romulus won't you?
Yes. But Subcommander Velal will be here in my place.
Fine. Have a safe trip.
Thank you.
Odo's checked all the security logs -- there's no indication of how Sloan got aboard or where he went.

Can't say I'm surprised. From what we've seen of them, Section Thirty-one is meticulous about covering their tracks. I spoke with Admiral Ross this afternoon. He and I agree that the Romulan conference is too important to cancel.
What about me?
Starfleet promised to send its expert on Dominion biogenic weapons and Ketracel White to the conference. Since that's you -- you go.
And we want you to carry out your "assignment." Make a few discreet observations on the Romulan leadership and wait for Sloan to contact you again.
Somehow, I don't think giving Sloan information is a good idea

That was my instinct as well, but after talking to Ross I think we might have an opportunity here we can turn to our advantage. Officially, Starfleet Command has said they're appalled at the very notion that an organization like Section Thirty-one might exist and that they plan to get to the bottom of this entire business.
But unofficially... ?

They've quietly pushed the investigation aside. Which means they either don't take Section Thirty-one seriously... or someone at Starfleet Command is protecting them. Either way, we now have a chance to get someone inside and I think we should take it.
So I play along... pretend I've decided to work for Sloan after all.
When he contacts you to find out what you learned at the conference, make it seem like you've reluctantly come around to his way of thinking. Let him believe he's seduced you into helping him.
That shouldn't be too difficult. Sloan already thinks I'm so tempted by his offer that I can barely see straight. I better get packed. The Bellerophon leaves in three hours.
One more thing, Doctor. Remember that this isn't a game. Section Thirty-one is dangerous. If Sloan suspects that you're really working for us...
I understand.
Good hunting.
A glass of Romulan ale, Doctor?
The trade embargo has been officially lifted, in case you're wondering.
It hadn't crossed my mind, actually.
To one of the many benefits of the Alliance.
Shall I call for a medical team?
No, thank you.
Don't tell me this is your first taste of Romulan ale.
It... was... illegal...
That never stopped most of your colleagues.
I know. I may be... the only officer in the fleet... who didn't indulge on occasion.
Would you like something else?
I'll manage.
That's the spirit, sir. Never say die.
What an odd expression. What does it mean?
It's a line from an old Earth poem.
Forgive me for breaking in, but I couldn't help overhearing and etymology is one of my hobbies.

The phrase "never say die" was originally from a nineteenth century poem based on Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice." It has since passed into the vernacular as an exhortation never to give up, no matter what the cost.
Interesting.
Wendell Greer, Assistant Director, UFP Department of Cartography.
A pleasure. I'm Admiral William Ross... this is Senator Cretak..
Admiral... Senator...
And Doctor Julian Bashir...
Ah. The physician from Deep Space Nine.
That's right.
I've been hoping to meet you. I have so many questions about the Bajoran sector, the navigational anomalies, the transport patterns... could you spare a moment? Unless I'm interrupting... ?
Not at all.
Try to play your cards a little closer to the vest, doctor. You're lucky they didn't see that look of shock on your face.
If you've managed to attach yourself to the delegation, why do you need me?
All in due time. Now -- you have a lot of work do before we arrive at Romulus. There's a PADD in your quarters. Read it and I'll join you at twenty-two hundred.
"Mister Greer" certainly has all his ducks in a row. According to the Department of Cartography, he's been a mid-level bureaucrat for almost fifteen years.
It doesn't surprise me that he has a solid cover story. But I think it's too dangerous to allow him to participate in the conference or even to set foot on Romulus. We don't know what he's up to.
On the other hand, if we move against him now, we'll lose any hope of penetrating Section Thirty-one.

His access at the conference will be limited to a few low-level briefings and seminars. It shouldn't be difficult to keep tabs on him... If Sloan's here it suggests more than a simple intelligence- gathering mission. He's up to something and I think it's imperative to find out what that something is. We go forward.
Neral. Formerly Proconsul and now Praetor of the Romulan Star Empire.

Neral's ascension to the top post was confirmed by the Continuing Committee a little over a year ago. His immediate family was killed in a Klingon raid approximately twenty-five years ago. His hobbies include archeology and sociology. His favorite food is Delvan pudding and his pet set'leth's name is Pensho.
Very good. Total recall is a useful attribute for an operative.
Koval. Chairman of the Tal'Shiar. Section Thirty-one believes that he was involved in the death of Vice Admiral Fujisaki last year, but there's no proof.

The proof is buried somewhere in Koval's personal database, which puts it out of our reach for now. But believe me Doctor, the Deputy Chief of Starfleet Intelligence doesn't just die of "food poisoning."
I have to give him credit, though, it was a textbook operation. No sign of foul play, and certainly no sign of Romulan involvement. Very tidy...
Koval's political status?

Ambiguous. He hasn't been elevated to the Continuing Committee, which is usually a given for the head of the Tal'Shiar. His nomination is probably being held up due to Koval's opposition to the Federation Alliance, which is supported by a majority of the Committee.

Which, in turn, opens the door for your friend, Senator Cretak. She's an advocate for the alliance and she's been lobbying for that open seat. There's another rumor about Koval not contained in his file. We've heard he's ill. Something called Tuvan Syndrome.
I'm familiar with it. It's a neurological disease affecting mostly Romulans, Vulcans and Rigelians. It's degenerative and incurable at present.
If Koval is ill, he'll try to hide it. It's a weakness, one that could hamper his chances of being appointed to the Committee.
Is that what you want from me? A diagnosis? What's the matter Sloan, doesn't Section Thirty-one have its own doctors?
Our physicians weren't genetically enhanced. They need equipment to make a diagnosis -- equipment that the Romulans won't permit at the conference.
I'm not capable of making a diagnosis by simply looking at a man.
Your genetically enhanced friends determined that Gul Damar killed woman just by watching him give political speech. I'm sure you can do even better.
You're going to move against Koval, aren't you? You want to find a way to use his illness to keep him off the Committee...
I suppose it would be naive of me to point out that interfering in the internal affairs of a sovereign power is explicitly forbidden by the Federation charter.

Without confirming or denying your speculation, I will say that if Koval comes to power, it'll be a disaster for the Federation. He'll argue for the Romulans to abrogate the alliance and negotiate a separate peace with the Dominion. And I shouldn't have to tell you what that would do to the course of the war.
That doesn't justify manipulating a --

Let's make a deal, doctor. I'll spare you the ends-justify-the-means speech and you spare me the we-must- do-what's-right speech. You and I are not going to see eye to eye on this subject so I suggest we stop discussing it. Our mission is reconnaissance. We won't be called upon to do anything more than that. So I suggest you get some rest. We'll be in orbit of Romulus by oh-six hundred and you'll need to have your wits about you.
Doctor Julian Bashir?
Yes.
I understand you were the officer who first identified the biogenic weapon known as the "Quickening."
That's right. On Boranis Three, in the Gamma Quadrant.
I... don't believe we've been introduced.
Koval.
Ah. It's a pleasure to meet you.
Why?
Well, you've got me there. I suppose it's simply an expression.
And like most human expressions, entirely devoid of meaning. Can the Dominion's Quickening virus be replicated?

We've had difficulty recreating the exact RNA sequence of the virus, which is one of the reasons we've been unable to develop a vaccine. However, there are alternate methods of making vaccines which --
I'm not interested in the vaccine, I'm interested in the virus. Do you know how to introduce the Quickening into a population?
Basically...
Good. I look forward to hearing your lecture.
You're going to make a fine operative, doctor.
Pardon me?
The Chairman of the Tal'Shiar rarely speaks with anyone in public -- much less anyone wearing that uniform. Starfleet Intelligence should recruit you immediately.
What makes you think I'm not working for them already?
Somehow, it wouldn't surprise me if half the people in this room turned out to be operatives.
You are joking... ?
It may be impolitic to say this... but there're those who see this alliance as merely a... momentary truce.
Are you one of those people?
I could ask you the same question.
In my case, you would get a firm, "no." But you've answered my question with a question.
I try not to predict the future.
What about Chairman Koval?
You tell me. You just spoke with him -- that's more than I've done in six months.
I take it you don't get along?
We have different views.
Which are... ?
State secrets.
Good afternoon. I'm Doctor Julian Bashir from Deep Space Nine and I'll be speaking to you on the subject of Dominion biogenic weapons.
I'd, uh... I'd like to start with an overview of the weapon that's become known as... the Quickening.
This is an adult female inhabitant of Boranis Three. The markings on her face are typical of a humanoid infected by the disease, but not yet in the terminal stage.
You can see in this next photograph, by the necrotic character of the lesions that she has entered the terminal stage... this is also marked by an increase in leukocyte production...
Very enlightening. You almost made it comprehensible.
Next time I'll do a lecture with hand puppets just for you.
I'm glad to see you still have your sense of humor.
I trust you noticed who was sitting in the front row.
He approached me this morning, between sessions.
He wanted to know more about the Quickening. Specifically, whether I knew how to replicate the virus... and how to introduce it into a population.
What did you think of his health?
Didn't you hear what I just said?

I heard you. Koval wants to get his hands on the Quickening. It's not news to me that the head of the Tal'Shiar is interested in biogenic weapons. Pull your head out of the sand, and take a look around, doctor. These are not nice people we're dealing with here. Now, answer my question.
His eyelids were slightly displaced, and there was noticeable weakness in his facial muscles -- possibly a result of compromised neuromuscular function. Also his respiration seemed irregular.
Bottom line?
He may have Tuvan Syndrome, but if he does it's in the very early stages.
How long does he have?
If he fits the normal profile... he'll begin experiencing a loss of motor skills in the next ten to fifteen years... with life expectancy somewhere in the twenty to twenty-five year range.
Are there any instances in which the disease accelerates without warning?
It happens, but in less than five percent of the cases.
Is there anything that could trigger the acceleration?
I'm not sure what you're asking me.
Never mind. Thank you, doctor, you've been very helpful.

This is unbelievable. Let's put aside -- for the moment -- that he's contemplating the murder of a high-ranking official. What the hell makes him think that the next head of the Tal'Shiar will be any better than Koval?
Sloan's more concerned with who gets the empty seat on the Continuing Committee. He's hoping that Cretak gets it.
Hmm. Well, I have to agree with him there. Cretak, for all her abrasiveness, is at least a patriot.
How does that make her any different than Koval?

If you saw the reports from Starfleet Intelligence that I see, you wouldn't ask that question. Koval would like nothing better than to see the Romulan banner waving over Earth. Believe me, doctor -- Chairman Koval is not someone we want at the Praetor's right hand.
I'll have Sloan confined to quarters immediately. But that may not solve our problem.
Sir?
Has it occurred to you, that you and Sloan may not be the only ones here working for Section Thirty-one? For all we know, he could have a confederate somewhere in the delegation.

Sloan said that "our" mission would be strictly reconnaissance... and that "we" wouldn't be called on to do anything else. That could suggest another operative... someone whose mission isn't limited to reconnaissance...
If that's true, it could be anyone. Even a member of the Bellerophon crew.
Or a Romulan.
What?
I think Sloan has an accomplice somewhere on Romulus.
What makes you say that?

Two things. First, Sloan has too much information on the inner workings of their government, too many insights into their political process. Second, Sloan's plan is to kill Koval while making it appear to be an accelerated case of Tuvan Syndrome. To do that, he'd have to expose Koval to a short burst of nadion radiation. The simplest plan would be to maneuver Koval near a phaser relay and surreptitiously irradiate him. Since I doubt very much that Sloan will have a chance to do that, it stands to reason that someone else will have to do it for him.
A Romulan...
Exactly. Sir, Sloan may have already set things in motion. We have to warn them.

And how am I supposed to explain Section Thirty-one to the Romulans? All hell would break loose if they hear that a rogue Federation agency is running around plotting assassinations. It could bring down the Alliance. Besides, all we have is speculation at this point.
Admiral --
The answer is no. Now, after I have Sloan arrested, I'll break radio silence and inform Starfleet Command of the situation. Your orders are to sit tight and do nothing until you hear from me.
Aye, sir.
I don't know. Jepella said she went in to deliver a report and found him slumped over his desk.
Do they have any idea what happened?
Doctor Frame said it looked like an aneurysm, but they're still running tests.
An aneurysm. I saw the admiral this morning -- he looked fine.
They say that's the way it happens. One minute you're --
Which admiral are you talking about?
Uh -- Admiral Ross, sir. He collapsed at his desk.
Where is he?
Sickbay.
Senator... may I speak with you for a moment?
I can't trust anyone on the Bellerophon and I can't contact D.S. Nine -- for security reasons there's a communications blackout. I have no one else to turn to, senator. I need your help.
To do what?
I have reason to believe that Sloan has an accomplice within the Romulan government. Someone that's going to help him carry out the assassination.
Koval's been saying... that there's a traitor in the senate... someone working for Starfleet Intelligence...
Section Thirty-one is not part of Starfleet Intelligence.
They're Federation citizens working to advance your interests. That makes them your responsibility.
You're absolutely right. And that's why I'm doing everything I can to stop them.

I'm going to try to convince Sloan that Koval doesn't have Tuvan Syndrome. But he may have already told his accomplice to proceed. So the only way to be sure we stop the assassination... is to find Sloan's Romulan accomplice.
And you expect me to find this... traitor.

Sloan mentioned something about Koval having a "personal database." It stands to reason that it contains a list of potential suspects. Is there any possible way you can get me a copy of that database? I could run an analysis of all the suspects and compare them to --
You're asking me to hand over secret documents!

I'm asking you to put aside three centuries of mutual mistrust and help me stop a murder! Senator, if we can't reach out and bridge the gulf that separates our people, if we can't trust each other... a man will die. And we will be partially responsible. Help me. Please.
What's on your mind, Doctor?
Two things. First... do you find anything... odd about Ross suddenly having an aneurysm?
You went to medical school, you tell me.
I haven't examined him, but... the timing strikes me as very... convenient.
What are you saying?
That it may have been artificially induced.
Think about it. We're in the middle of a very sensitive military conference. What if the Romulans saw him as an obstacle to their war objectives? What if they wanted to remove that obstacle by --
Doctor. I know how much you love cloak and dagger, but you're starting to see conspiracies everywhere. Ross is ill, that's all there is to it.
You're probably right.
Now what else is on your mind?
I'm not convinced that Koval actually has Tuvan Syndrome. His "symptoms" could be the result of any of fifty other health problems.
You didn't say that before.
I'm not an expert on Romulan physiology. Most of my knowledge regarding Tuvan Syndrome comes from studies done on Vulcan patients.
I thought Vulcans and Romulans were virtually identical.
Yes, but there are some important genetic differences. And the more I study the available data on Romulan physiology, the less sure I am that I've correctly diagnosed his condition.
How could you find out for sure?
The best way would be to do an examination, but I doubt he's going to agree to that.
What if you obtained a sample of his skin cells? Could you run an analysis?
Possibly... but how do you propose --
We'll treat your palm with a microcellular adhesive. The next time you shake his hand, you'll have your sample.
All right.
Mister Chairman?
It's a pleasure to see you again.
I'd be happy to resume our discussion of the Quickening at some point before the conference is adjourned.
I believe you answered all my questions.
Well, then. I'm glad I was able to help.
Doctor... I would like to have a word with you on another matter... in private.
Of course. I believe the lecture hall is empty...
We have other, more comfortable facilities available. If you please...
Sit down.
I can assure you that you will be sitting in that chair one way or the other, Doctor.
Now we'll have our private talk.
What shall we talk about?
Why you're really on Romulus. Who you're working for. And, of course, who's helping you. Don't worry. I won't waste your time with pointless questions.
I prefer to take the information directly from the source.
This can be painful or not. That's up to you, doctor. Either way, I will know what you know.
It appears that your brain's neurocellular structure is not susceptible to our scanning techniques, evidently a result of the genetic enhancements made to your parietal cortex.
Sorry.
I do have other methods at my disposal, but... it would save everyone a great deal of trouble if you would simply tell me what I want to know.
You... haven't asked me... any questions...
I think you know what I'm interested in.
Who are you working for?
Why are you here?
Bring him.

Doctor Julian Bashir, you are appearing before the Continuing Committee of the Romulan People. Any statements will be made part of the official record. Senator Cretak has been charged with attempting to access a Tal'Shiar database without proper authorization. She has told the Committee a... remarkable story. Since you're a key figure in her story, we are most eager to hear your version of the events.

What I'm about to tell you may sound... shocking. It may even damage relations between our peoples... but it is the truth. A few days ago, I became aware of a plot to assassinate Chairman Koval. It was conceived by a man I know only as "Sloan." He works for an organization called Section Thirty-one. They see themselves as protecting the interests of the Federation, but they have absolutely no official standing. After I realized what Sloan was attempting to do, I contacted Senator Cretak and tried to enlist her help in stopping him.
Why her?
I had no one else to turn to. I was unable to contact Deep Space Nine, and I couldn't trust anyone aboard the Bellerophon.
But you felt that you could trust a Romulan senator?
Yes. For all our differences, I do respect her.
Continue.

Well... for reasons that are extremely complicated... I came to believe that there's a traitor in your government working for Section Thirty-one. I asked the Senator to obtain the database so we could unmask this person and prevent the assassination.
Why didn't you come to me with this information?
I... was afraid that if word of this... plot got out it would destroy the Alliance. So I decided to keep my own counsel. I regret that decision.
As well you should, Kimara.
It's an interesting story. But it's not the whole story. if I may be permitted to bring in another witness... ?
Bring in Prisoner Five-two-seven.

Praetor, this is the man known as Sloan. Unlike the Doctor, his mind is quite susceptible to our data retrieval methods. Under questioning, he has confirmed much of what the doctor and the senator have told you. With one important exception. There is no Section Thirty-one.

Sloan, in fact, works for Starfleet Intelligence. Far from being the master of a rogue agency, he is simply one of many operatives in the employ of the Federation. He's had a long career, most of which is still unknown to us. However, there is one interesting element that we do know -- he was the protege of The late Vice Admiral Fujisaki.

Sloan did not take the death of his mentor well. He came to believe that he was murdered -- by the Tal'Shiar. In his eyes, the assassination of a Starfleet admiral was... "stepping over the line." Isn't that the phrase?

After Fujisaki's death, he was confronted with a dilemma: how could he seek vengeance without violating Federation law? His answer was to invent Section Thirty-one -- a "rogue" organization that answered to no one.

If they killed the head of the Tal'Shiar, Starfleet Intelligence would be held blameless As the Committee knows, I have been diagnosed with Tuvan Syndrome.
