Sloan became aware of my condition and hoped to make my death look like a sudden acceleration of the disease. To do that, he needed a doctor. So ten days after Fujisaki's death, Sloan arranged to "recruit" Doctor Bashir into Section Thirty- one. After that, Sloan bided his time, and waited for an opportunity to present itself. He found one when he learned of this conference. He then arranged for Bashir to be invited. Everything was going perfectly. But then he made a fatal mistake -- he decided to come to Romulus himself. He was unaware that his identity had become known to us. Once we recognized him in the delegation, we knew immediately that an intelligence operation was underway.
What I don't understand is why? Why come here and take the risk of being discovered?
I had to make sure nothing went wrong. And... I wanted to watch you die.
You broke the cardinal rule of our profession -- you allowed business to become personal.
Then there was an assassination plan?

Most definitely. As to the involvement of the doctor and the senator... Doctor Bashir may have intended to kill me, or he may have intended to save me. There's no way to know for certain. As for Senator Cretak... we all know she's an ambitious woman. It is entirely possible that she would welcome my death... especially if it meant her being elevated to the Continuing Committee in my place.
That is a lie. I was trying to save your life, Koval.
Then you're simply a fool. You let a Starfleet Intelligence officer manipulate you into committing an act of treason.

It is the finding of this Committee that Senator Cretak has conspired to commit treason against the state; sentence to be determined at a later date. Doctor Bashir will be returned to the Bellerophon. Mister Sloan is remanded to the custody of the Tal'Shiar for further interrogation.
No!
Come in.
Feeling better, sir?
Much. Doctor Frame says I should take it easy for a few days, but... paperwork waits for no man. What can I do for you?
I have a question. Where's Sloan?
Sloan's dead.
Admiral... where's Sloan?
If we're going to have this discussion, then it's off-the- record.
Before I answer your question, answer mine. How did you know?

The man Koval described wasn't the same man who recruited me into Section Thirty-one. Anyone clever enough to pull the wool over my eyes so completely wouldn't get caught by the Romulans that easily. There had to be another explanation. Then I remembered that you were the one who planted the idea in my head of Sloan having an accomplice.

You were the one who didn't want to tell the Romulans about the assassination plot. You were the one who gave the orders preventing me from contacting D.S. Nine. And when I told you about the assassination plot, you conveniently had an aneurysm -- leaving me alone and unable to turn to anyone for help... except Cretak. Once I realized your involvement, the rest began to fall into place. Where is he?
I don't know.
But he is alive, isn't he?
He was supposed to be beamed away a split second before the phaser beam hit him. Whether it worked or not, I couldn't tell you.
How long has Koval been working for Section Thirty-one?
He's been providing the Federation with crucial military information for over a year. I don't know when he started working with Section Thirty-one.
But in any case, we have a mole working for us at the highest levels of the Romulan government.
Good for us. And what about your "friend" Senator Cretak? What will happen to her?
Dismissed from the Senate -- definitely. Imprisoned -- most likely.
Executed?
I hope not.
You set her up! She was an innocent woman and you let Sloan destroy her! Why? She believed in the Alliance -- she was on our side!

No. She wasn't. I told you before, Julian, she's a patriot. Which means that if it served the interests of the Romulans to negotiate a separate peace with the Dominion... Cretak would've pushed for that option. And, believe me, the Dominion would like nothing better than to make a deal with the Romulans right now.
So Koval becomes your guarantee that that won't happen. As a man who was nearly "killed" for his anti-Federation activities, his recommendation to stay in the war will be all the more convincing.
That's the general idea.
And how long have you worked for Section Thirty-one?
I don't.
Just a "temporary" alliance?
Something like that.
And you don't see anything wrong with what happened?
I don't like it. But I've spent the last year and a half of my life ordering young men and women to die. I like that even less.
That's a glib answer. And it's a cheap way of avoiding the fact that you've trampled on the very thing those men and women are out there dying to protect. Doesn't that mean anything to you?
Inter arma enim silent leges.
"In time of war, the law falls silent." Cicero. So is that what we've become -- a twenty- fourth century Rome? Driven by nothing more than the certainty that Caesar can do no wrong?
This conversation never happened. You're dismissed.
Good evening.
Are you expecting applause? Did you come to take a bow?
I just wanted to say thank you.
For what? My allowing you to manipulate me so completely.
For being a decent human being. That's why we selected you in the first place, Doctor.

We needed someone who wanted to play the game, but who'd only go so far. When the time came, you stood your ground and did the right thing -- you reached out to an enemy, told her the truth, and tried to stop a murder. The Federation needs men like you, doctor. Men of conscience. Men of principle. Men who can sleep at night. You're also the reason Section Thirty-one exists -- someone has to protect men like you from a universe that doesn't share your sense of right and wrong.
Am I supposed to feel sorry for you, Sloan? Should I weep over the burdens you're forced to carry to protect the rest of us?
It's an honor to know you. Sweet dreams.
Bashir to Security.
Odo here.
Nevermind. My mistake.

-- basically we stumbled onto it by accident. At Chin'toka, our entire fleet was disabled when the Breen engaged their energy- dampening weapon. Three hundred and eleven ships -- Federation, Romulan, and Klingon -- all lost power.
But one didn't -- a Bird of Prey called the Ki'tang.
Why, what was different about the Ki'tang?
We're not exactly sure. The only thing we can figure is that right before the engagement, her Chief Engineer adjusted the tritium
I've ordered every ship in the Klingon fleet to adjust its reactor the same way.
Our vessels are of a different design -- can this technique be adapted to protect them as well?
Unfortunately, no. Your ships are still vulnerable. And so are ours.

I've sent what we know about the Breen weapon to the Romulan Ministry of Science and to Starfleet Engineering, but realistically, it's going to be a while before they can come up with a way to protect our ships.
Thank you, Chief.
Well, Gentlemen, it would seem that the Klingon fleet is the only thing standing between us and the Dominion.
What have we come to... ?
By tomorrow, we'll have eleven hundred Klingon vessels ready for deployment.
With the Breen, the Cardassians and the Jem'Hadar you're still outnumbered twenty-to-one.
I'm aware of that, general.
Obviously the Klingons can't go head-to-head with the Dominion. But they might be able to keep them distracted.
We'll operate in small battle groups -- moving in under cloak, engaging the enemy, then trying to provoke them into pursuit.
With any luck, they'll be able to keep the Dominion off balance and prevent them from launching an offensive.
For how long? They can't keep them at bay forever.
No, they can't. But fortunately we're not the only ones the Dominion has to contend with right now.
Damar's resistance movement...
What's left of it. Half his troops were killed in their assault on Rondac.
They may have failed to capture Rondac, but the attack sent a message to the Cardassian people.
If the rebels can show them that they have a chance of succeeding, their support will grow.
Does the rebellion have a chance of succeeding?
Yes, but they need to adjust their tactics -- concentrate on small-scale hit-and-run attacks, sabotaging key facilities...
Damar's a by-the-book soldier. Does he have any experience waging that kind of campaign?
No, he doesn't. That's why we need to send him someone who does...
You want me to go behind enemy lines and teach a bunch of Cardassians how to be resistance fighters?
I'm aware of the irony. But the tactics you used to drive the Cardassians off Bajor are exactly what this situation calls for.
But to work with Damar? He's a murderer. When he killed Ziyal -- he murdered an innocent girl.

You're going to have to put your personal feelings aside. Whether you like Damar or not is irrelevant. We need him. (laying it out for her) The Dominion knows it has to stop his rebellion before it spreads. It's your job to make sure they don't. It's as simple as that.
Yes, sir. I understand Damar and his men went into hiding after the attack on Rondac. Any idea how we can locate them?
I suggest you talk to Mister Garak about that.
Garak?
He still has contacts on Cardassia. In fact if I were you, I'd ask him to join your team. He could be useful.
Damar, now Garak... should be an
... it's very difficult to keep a supply of synthetic organs on hand in a battlefield situation. You never know how many livers you're going to need, how many hearts --
I can imagine. But what does that have to do with me?
Well you see, the Holy Grail of organ replacement is to come up with a way to inject the patient with undifferentiated tissue that can become whatever organ is needed. The problem is --
Doctor, get to the point.
Can I borrow a cup of goo?
Excuse me?
I promise I'll give it back.
I just want to study your
(putting it together) To use for organ replacement...
Exactly.
Can't you just... scan me or something?
I need a sample... (off Odo's hesitation) It's for a good cause.
All right, Doctor...
Just a tad more...
Thank you.
I'm going to want that back as soon as Kira and I return from our mission.
She thought I might be useful.
When do you leave?
As soon as Garak is able to locate Damar.
I'm very concerned. It's not like Solbor to disappear like this. Please, do whatever it takes to find him.
Well done. I almost believed you myself.
How like a Cardassian to find amusement in an old man's death. You don't know how much I regret having to kill him.
He was going to expose us. (reaching to touch her) No one can be allowed to stand in our way...
Remember your place, Dukat.
I thought my place was in your bed...
That was before I knew who you were.
But they can't change what you did. Do you really think I could let myself be touched by a man
When we release the Pah-wraiths from the fire caves, your hands will be stained as well.
The Pah-wraiths will spare those who are worthy. The rest... are of no consequence.
You've been studying that for days... perhaps I could help?
The text of the Kosst Amojan is for my eyes alone...
Have you learned what we have to do to release the Pah-wraiths?
Only that it's not a simple matter... Leave me. I've had enough of your distractions.
-- when is Gowron's ship due to arrive?
In the morning.
Martok seems a little nervous about the ceremony.
The Chancellor is coming all the way from Kronos to induct him into the Order of Kahless... I'd be nervous, too.
Good news. Garak was able to contact Damar.
He provided us with his location and requested assistance as soon as possible.
With your permission, I'd like to depart first thing tomorrow.
By all means.
There is one other thing...
Yes?
Damar expressed certain concerns when I told him Colonel Kira was going to be leading this mission.
If he wants to defeat the Dominion -- (with a glance Sisko's way) He's going to have to put his feelings aside.

He's willing to do that, he knows your skills would be useful. But he's concerned that his men would see your uniform as an affront. We Cardassians are a proud people. Losing Bajor to a ragtag band of terrorists -- no offense -- was a humiliation. Simply put, taking on a Bajoran officer as an advisor would undermine his authority.
I'm sorry, colonel. We'll have to send someone else to head up the mission.
No, sir. Colonel Kira is the best person for the job. There's another way around this problem.
I don't know...
Do you really think it's going to make a difference to the Cardassians that you've been given a Starfleet commission? You're still a Bajoran.
A Bajoran with the authority to speak on behalf of the Federation.
You do realize you're going to have to do something about your "uniform," as well?
I was afraid you were going to say that...
Well?
It's a little... drab.
It's how I appeared when I worked for the Cardassians.
It should put them at ease, anyway.
I wonder if Doctor Bashir could help us with that nose of yours?
I'm only willing to go so far. Damar's men are just going to have to get used to the idea of having me around.
They'll tolerate you. To a point. But if I were you, I'd watch my back. See you in the morning.
You see the problem.
Our food supplies are running low.
We'll have to cut back our rations until we get hold of some food replicators.
When I spoke to Garak, I told him to bring some.
Federation food replicators?
Rusot, we're in no position to turn down help -- no matter where it comes from.
Taking help from the Federation is bad enough, but having to take it from that Bajoran terrorist...
Kira Nerys has certain "skills" she's willing to teach us. "Skills" we'll need if we're going to defeat the Dominion.
I don't believe what I'm hearing. When we were stationed on Terok Nor, you spent hours telling me how much you despised her.
I did hate her. But that's a luxury I can no longer afford. And neither can you. I need your support in this, my friend.
Maybe I shouldn't wear the kro'jek...
Look at me! Fussing like a woman! It's ridiculous.
Gowron is according you a great honor. There is no shame in
What if I make a mistake during the ceremony tomorrow... ?
I'll help you memorize the proper responses.
I tell you, my friend... I'd rather be going into battle than doing this...
That is why you are being honored. Because you've fought the Dominion with all your heart. Your name is known throughout the Empire. They sing songs of your exploits. You've earned this.
Ops to General Martok. You asked to be notified when Chancellor Gowron's ship arrived.
Acknowledged.
Welcome to Deep Space Nine, chancellor.
It's been too long, captain.
You know Admiral Ross.
We met at Khitomer.
Of course, admiral. Martok!
(grabbing his shoulders) The man I came to honor!
The Son of Mogh...
Chancellor...
(to Martok; suspicious) They say you've made him part of your House...
It's true.
Then what's past is past! If Martok considers you his brother, that's all I need to know.
Come! I brought a barrel of the finest bloodwine and it must be drunk tonight!
I guess we're not invited...
I finally tracked her down in Quark's and said flat out, "Ezri, why have you been avoiding me?" She was just about to answer when I got called away.
I haven't noticed her avoiding you. Are you sure you're not imagining things?
I haven't crossed paths with her in days.
Neither have I. It's a big station. The truth is you want to spend more time with her, so it seems like she's never around.
I'm telling you something's going on. And I intend to find out what it is when she gets here. I told her I have some test results from her last checkup that I want to discuss.
Isn't that unethical, or something?
Is that Odo?
Part of him, anyway.
Never mind, I don't want to know.
Computer, begin a morphogenic enzyme analysis...
Hi.
You wanted to see me?
Yes, come in.
Good running into you. I haven't seen you in days.
So...
You said something about test results... ?
Yes, of course. Let's see...
You know, we never finished our
Our conversation?
In Quark's. You were about to tell me why you've been avoiding me.
I suppose this is as good a time as any...
I guess it goes back to when Worf and I were held prisoner by the Breen. We spent a lot of time together.
Naturally.
You can imagine that it would bring up all sorts of old feelings.
Sure.
And, uh... one thing led to another...
Ezri, you don't have to say any more.
But I want to.
Really, it's all right. I wish you both all the happiness in the world.
Who?
You and Worf.
Julian, that's not--
(glancing at the screen) There's no need to explain.
You don't understand. What I'm trying to tell you is that I'm in love with --
Oh, my God.
What is it, what's wrong?
-- I was running a scan on the sample you left when I noticed something unusual.
Unusual in what way?
The disease that's killing your people... you're infected...
-- my guess is you became infected the last time you Linked with the Female Shape-shifter.
(not wanting to believe it) Are you sure about this? He doesn't have any symptoms.
So far. From what I can tell, the virus is replicating quickly -- it may not be long before symptoms start to surface.
We have to get you back to the station.
No. We have a mission to accomplish and I intend to see it through.
Odo --
It's all right. At this point there's not much I can do for him. I feel confident that'll change.
What do you mean?
I'm running a series of tests on the sample you left. I'm going to ask Starfleet Medical to send me the results of the tests they ran on you a few years ago.
(not a pleasant experience) I remember. They were very... thorough.
By comparing the results, I might be able to figure out how the virus works. That may well lead to a cure.
Thanks, Julian.
We should be crossing into Dominion space in a few minutes...
I'll start scanning for enemy patrols...
What have you been keeping from me, my sweet? What dark secrets... ?
Dukat?
Adami, help me --
You fool --
I can't see...
-- no I don't want to talk to Lieutenant Douglas. I already talked to her. I need these test results. My patient's life is at stake.
I wish I could help, but as I said, the files you requested are classified.
Why would Odo's medical records be classified?
They are, that's all I know.
I want to talk to your supervising officer.
You did -- Lieutenant Douglas.
Then I want to talk to her supervising officer.
I'll patch you through, but he's going to tell you the same thing...
Commander Hilliard, here.

Yes, commander. I was hoping you could sort out this situation for me. I realize that the files I requested are classified, but considering the circumstances, I trust you can appreciate the need for expediency.
Of course.
You wouldn't mind answering a few questions?
If that's necessary.
You've requested Security Chief Odo's medical records from Stardate... ?
Four-nine-four-one-nine.
You state that he's contracted the morphogenic virus that's infected the Founders.
Correct.
How did he contract it?
Presumably when he Linked with one of them.
You're saying he's been in contact with the enemy?
Not recently. It happened over a year ago.
I assume you've done your own scans of Odo over the years?
Of course.
Then why do you need ours?
To use as a point of comparison, in the hopes of finding a cure.
A cure.
That's right.
Is there anything else?
No. That pretty much covers it.
Good. So when can I expect to receive a copy of the files?
I'm afraid those files are classified.
But... I thought you were asking all these questions so you could clear me to receive them.
You misunderstood. I can't release those files to anyone who doesn't have Sigma Nine Clearance.
I don't give a damn about Sigma Nine clearance, I'm just trying to find a cure for this disease!
I fail to see why you're so determined to cure a disease that's infected the enemy. We're at war, doctor.
This has nothing to do with the Founders -- I'm trying to save Odo's life.
Ah, yes. Odo -- who by your own admission has been known to consort with the enemy.
You have to understand the circumstances --

I don't care about the circumstances. If you find a cure, there's a good chance it could fall into Dominion hands. That's a risk Starfleet Medical is not willing to take. Your request for the files is denied. If I were you, I'd drop this matter. Otherwise I'll have to refer it to Starfleet Security.
I'm telling you, Miles. It was bizarre. This Commander Hilliard let me think he was going to help me just so he could ply me with questions.
Sounds like your typical bureaucrat flexing his muscles.
No, it was more than that. He practically accused me of being a traitor. He made it sound like I was in league with the Dominion just because I want to help Odo.
Maybe the attack on Starfleet Headquarters has him spooked -- guys like Hilliard are used to sitting behind their desks, not under them.
I've got to find a way to get that file. Maybe the captain could request it.
Does he have "Sigma Nine Clearance" -- whatever that is?
For Odo's sake, we'd better hope so...
-- today we honor our brother Martok in the manner Kahless taught us.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: We're next...
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: You're kidding.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: I wish I were...
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: I accept this honor in the name of the House of Martok... and I ask only to be allowed to continue to serve the Empire.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: You did well.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: Thank you for your help, my friend.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: It still stings...
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: That's what the bloodwine's for...
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: Congratulations, general.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: Martok! How does it feel to be the most famous warrior in the Empire?
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: I'm grateful to have been given the opportunity to serve.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: And you've served well. But you've borne the burden of this war for a long time.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: I do it gladly. And I'll fight until victory is ours.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: No, my friend. I can't ask you to carry this weight forever. It's time for me to take a more active role in this war.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: As of today, I'm assuming direct command of our forces.
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: Chancellor, I don't understand. Are you unsatisfied with the way I've performed my duties?
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: Would I have given you the Star of Kahless if I wasn't satisfied? (slapping him on the back) You should be happy! You're a warrior again. No more meetings, no more reports to file -- you'll be out there, savoring the quick of battle. I envy you!
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: I intend to see an end to this war -- and soon. The Dominion will rue the day they heard my name!
scene: 31   INT. WARDROOM - CLOSE ON THE STAR OF KAHLESS

quote: Welcome to the headquarters of the Cardassian liberation front. It's been a long time.
Yes, it has.
Did you bring the supplies we requested?
Food replicators, weapons... I believe you'll find everything you asked for.
Excellent. The Cardassian people won't forget the Federation's generosity.
How nice. And now that the formalities are out of the way, let's try to remember that our enemy is the Dominion -- and not each other.

... a Resistance organization is structured into cells -- autonomous groups of ten to twenty people. That way if anyone gets captured, their ability to compromise the organization is limited. They can't be forced to name names they don't know.
(trying to be helpful) The Obsidian Order used to operate the same way.
We've got to decentralize your operation. Having all your men
And if you stay in one place, they could wipe out your entire Resistance movement in one attack. Smaller groups are safer -- they're harder to track down.
I'll have my men start investigating possible locations for other bases.
Good. Garak and Odo looked over your intelligence reports and came up with a list of vulnerable facilities for us to target.
The weapons depot on Adarak Prime is protected by only a single garrison. And there's a weakness in its perimeter defenses. A small group could infiltrate the compound and --
(looks up from his own PADD) Adarak Prime is defended by a Cardassian garrison.
That's correct.
You expect us to attack our own people?
If necessary, yes.
That's out of the question.
I agree. We'll limit ourselves to targets defended by Jem'Hadar and Breen troops.

Believe me, I understand how you feel. During the Occupation, I didn't want to attack facilities where Bajorans were working. But I did. Because they were collaborators -- they were working with the enemy.
We're not Bajorans. We don't kill our own.
Then you might as well give up now. Because the minute the Dominion realizes you're not willing to attack your own people, they'll station Cardassians at every base they have.
She's right. The Founders won't hesitate to play your own people against you.
And anyone who isn't fighting with you, is fighting against you.
If we want to free our people from the Dominion, we have to be willing to use whatever means are necessary.
You were saying that Adarak's perimeter defenses are vulnerable.
Damar.
Not another word, Rusot.
Continue.
We would need to disable the garrison's security protocols.
I believe that's where I come in...
I would've loved to have seen Hilliard's face when he realized Captain Sisko had Sigma Nine Clearance...
So is the file worth all the trouble you had to go through?
There's more data here than I expected. Starfleet Medical certainly was thorough.
By the way, what happened with Ezri?
Don't ask...
Come on.
Believe it or not, she and Worf are involved.
What? Did she tell you that?
Not in so many words...
Julian, I had a drink with Worf the other day. He told me he and Ezri are just friends. You must've misunderstood her.
I suppose it's possible... (hope springs eternal) She never actually came out and said it...
Did you at least find out why she's been "avoiding" you?
That's odd. The dispersal
What do you mean?
When I first came to the station, I had to familiarize myself with Odo's physiology. Doctor Mora was kind enough to share his data with me. This looks like a scan he did when he first found Odo.
Are you sure? (studying the screen) There are a lot of numbers here.
I saw it with my own eyes not seven years ago.
You are genetically enhanced.
According to the date, this scan was done when Odo was at Starfleet Medical.
There's no way two different scans could have exactly the same dispersal patterns.
It's impossible.
Someone took Mora's results and built a phony medical workup around them. This isn't Odo's file. They sent a fake.
I can't believe Starfleet Medical would actually put together a fake file just to throw you off...
You're right. It's not something Starfleet Medical would do.
Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
Section Thirty-one.
An organization that's prepared to do whatever it takes to "protect" the Federation wouldn't blink at doing something like this.
They don't want me to find a cure because they're afraid the Founders will get a hold of it...
To keep that from happening...
First he gives me a medal, then he takes over my command. It makes no sense.
Our people have come to see you as the saviour of the Empire. That is something Gowron cannot tolerate -- he wants to be its saviour.

What is he afraid of? That I'm going to challenge his position? I have no interest in politics. I'm a soldier. By the hand of Kahless. I earned my position, Worf. I've risen through the ranks, fought countless battles -- what has he done except plot and scheme his way to power?
His military experience is limited. He is not half the tactician you are.
Many brave warriors have given their lives in this war...
(putting a hand to his shoulder) I am honored to be part of your House.
I'd better gather my things. This office belongs to Gowron now...
How's the food?
Replicated.
Are you going to ask him or not?
I wouldn't recommend it.
It's a legitimate question, Garak.
Well, if you won't ask him, I will. Odo -- when you were the head of security on Terok Nor, what did you think was going to happen to the Bajoran prisoners that you arrested?
You don't have to answer that.
Why not? It's a legitimate question.
If you're looking to provoke an argument.
Just as I said.
I expected my prisoners to be dealt with justly, though I soon came to realize that Cardassians had little interest in justice.
Then why didn't you resign in "protes?t"
What're you getting at?
Nerys -- don't.
(to Seskal, re: Kira) I believe you struck a nerve. Apparently, Commander Kira doesn't like to be reminded that
Odo was not a collaborator.
I suppose that depends on your definition of "collaborator."
Nerys -- it isn't worth it.
Odo's right, commander.
I guess we have a difference of opinion.
You don't know how lucky you are.
Why's that?
She'd have killed you.
I only wish she had tried.
I'm glad we're in agreement.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: You want to knock over some supplies -- be my guest.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: You did the right thing, Nerys. Our enemy is the Dominion, not Rusot.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: I don't need you to remind me of that.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: I'm sorry. It's just so hot in here.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Cardassians do love the heat.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Well, I don't. I'm going to go see if I can find a cooling unit.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: I'll come with you.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: It's all right.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: I'll hold you to that.
scene: 46A  INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: You're not going to believe this...
scene: 50   INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Believe what?
scene: 50   INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Damar had this cooling unit waiting for us. (picking up Odo's state of mind) Something wrong?
scene: 50   INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Don't worry -- (holding up the cooling unit) I'm going to keep a cool head.
scene: 50   INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Assuming this thing actually works...
scene: 50   INT. DAMAR'S BASE - ANOTHER SECTION OF CAVERN

quote: Adami... ?
Are you there?
I'm here. (knowing this will irk him) I spoke with the doctor. She said she can't find anything wrong with your eyes.
Then she's incompetent! A Cardassian doctor would've cured me by now...
You still don't understand, do you? The Pah-wraiths have taken your sight as punishment for your
Only they can give it back to you.
I meant them no disrespect. I only wanted to study the book to see if I could help you learn how to release them.
You were trying to find out if you could do it without me.
You can't.
Pray with me, Adami. Help me earn the Pah-wraiths' forgiveness.
I'm afraid you'll have to do that on your own. Door.
Deputy Bodan will see you out.
See me out? I don't understand.
You need a lesson in humility. I'm going to see you get it.
By putting me out on the street?
You'll find that Bajorans are a kind people. I'm certain a blind beggar will elicit their sympathies. With any luck, you'll make enough to eat, maybe even enough to buy yourself shelter each night.
You aren't serious.
Return when you've proved yourself worthy and your sight has been restored. Bodan.
Adami...
Please --
Come in, come in. (standing to greet them) I've been studying the strategic situation. I want to share my
Of course.
The Dominion is deploying their fleet in preparation for a final
We must hold the line until the Federation and Romulan fleets become operational again.
No. Don't you see? That's exactly what the enemy is expecting. The time to act is now.
What are you proposing, chancellor?
We're going on the offensive. Starting tomorrow, I'm sending sorties deep into enemy territory -- to strike at the very heart of the Dominion!
But we're barely holding the line as it is.
We need every ship we have to defend the border.
What's wrong with you two! Don't you understand? We must seize the day!
What of it? (smiling at the beauty of it) We'll have the element of surprise on our side.
Chancellor, in my opinion we --
Did I ask your opinion! Trust me, my friends. I can see it all so clearly.
While our allies sit and do nothing, the Klingon Empire will score the final triumph over the Dominion. We'll be the saviours of the Alpha Quadrant. The glory will be ours -- and ours alone!
-- I don't know, Julian. if Section Thirty-one is involved in this, we should tell the captain.

We've been through this, Miles. If we go to him, he'll have to report it to Starfleet Command. Thirty-one will get wind of it and realize that we figured out the file was fake. Once they know we're onto them, they'll take steps to make sure I don't find a cure.
I see your point. Just what kind of steps do you think they'd take?
Believe me, we don't want to find out.
Excuse me, gentlemen.
Is that coffee?
I figured you were working on a way to help Odo. I thought it was the least I could do.
Who told you Odo was sick?
I hear things.
Keep it under your hat, all right?
Why?
Just do it.
All right, all right. Do you still want the coffee?
Sure. Thanks, Quark. (reaching for the mugs) Odo would be touched if he knew you were doing this.
(pulling the tray away) You're not going to tell him, are you?
It'll be our little secret.
Good luck.
Here you go...

Hang on, I'm trying to figure out when Odo was infected. I analyzed the sample he left and mapped the life-cycle of the virus. I'm programming the computer to calculate how long it took for the virus to achieve its present level of concentration.
Makes sense...
According to this, Odo was infected over two years ago.
(watching the calculation continue) More than that... I don't understand. I assumed he became infected when he Linked with the Female Shape-shifter.
If it happened so long ago, why hasn't he shown any symptoms before?
Good question.
Got it. Stardate Four-nine-four- one-nine.
Almost three years ago...
Four-nine-four-one-nine. That's the day Odo was at Starfleet Medical.
Are you sure?
Yes.
My god. That's why Hilliard didn't want me to see the file.
Section Thirty-one must have created the virus, and infected Odo to use him as a carrier...
So that when he Linked with other changelings, he'd pass it on... and eventually their entire race would be infected...
Thirty-one isn't just trying to stop us from finding a cure... they're trying to cover up the fact that they set out to commit genocide...
We've got to find a way to get our hands on it...
Before Thirty-one gets its hands on us...
You'll have to remove them.
Do you know how much they cost?

No, and I can't say that I'm interested in learning. Station regulation twenty-five-sixty-two, paragraph four: "All furniture intended for use on the Promenade must not pose a danger to public safety."
What danger?
Without a back on that stool, Morn could tumble off his perch at any moment, shattering his upper vertebrae or puncturing three or four of his lungs.
Nonsense.
His body weight is perfectly distributed across the seat.
He's also better able to enjoy the view of our lovely dabo girls than he was before. And should he require another drink...
... he need only spin back.
Which points out another danger -- vertigo.
This isn't going to give anyone vertigo...
Your appeal has been heard and rejected. I want the barstools removed by the end of the day.
Now... it's come to my attention that your dabo wheel is in violation of station regulation forty-seven- twenty-one, which states --
Odo?
Are you busy?
Not at all.
Then can I interest you in lunch?
Where shall we go?
I was thinking about the Klingon restaurant. I haven't been there in ages and I have this craving for broiled Krada legs...
Too bad about the barstools. I kinda liked them.
Hm. Did you notice how he changed the minute she walked in the room?
They're in love.
And what's love? Love... is a distraction. And a distracted policeman is... ?
An opportunity.
Captain's Log: Stardate xxxxx.x With the safe arrival of convoy PQ-One in the Vegan System, our escort duties are now complete and I've set course for home.
. My first, and hopefully last, mission report for Starfleet Command.

You know, when I agreed to be convoy liaison officer, I thought, "Sure. Why not? I know most of the freighter captains in the convoy -- should be a piece of cake." I didn't know I'd be making twenty log entries a day and filling out formal reports every night.
Well, it looks like you did a pretty good job.
If you're going to do something, do it right -- that's what my father used to say.
Every father says that. Even I say that.
That's why you're a good parent -- you know all the cliches by heart.
Well, hello stranger. Haven't seen you in days.
I've been filling out reports for Starfleet Medical.
I knew there was a reason I didn't join Starfleet -- I couldn't do all this paperwork.
Smart woman.
I remember a time when you couldn't get him to shut up.
I think I like him better this way.
That's mean.
I'm just kidding.
No, you're not.
Bridge to Captain Sisko.
Sisko here.
Sir, can you come to the bridge? We've picked up a distress call.
On my way.
We've been unable to establish two- way communication so far, but we have determined that the signal is coming from somewhere in the Rutharian Sector.
Let's hear it.

--and Commander Gatsby's dead too. I didn't see any other escape pods leave before the ship was destroyed so I may be the only survivor. My escape pod was torn open on impact and the rain is pouring in. I'll take the radio and a survival kit with me, but the environmental suits were damaged in the crash, so I'll have to rough it. This is an L-class world and the atmosphere is barely breathable out there. Repeat: This is a general distress call. I am a citizen of the United Federation of Planets and a Starfleet officer. If you can hear me, please respond. My government will reward you for any assistance you can offer. And most of all, you will be my personal heroes.
How long will it take us to reach her?
At maximum warp... six days.
Any other ships closer to that sector?
No, sir.
Mister Worf.... turn us around and set course for the Rutharian Sector.
Aye, sir.
Chief, I want you to establish a two-way com link with that woman. And when you do, tell her... her heroes are on the way.
Captain's Log: Supplemental. The marooned Starfleet officer, whose name we've learned is Lisa, continues to transmit her call for help...
... but so far, Chief O'Brien has been unable to establish two-way communications.
... the rain has stopped. I guess that's a good sign. At least I won't have to swim out of here. Now if the sun would just come out. Or maybe the sun doesn't come out on this planet.
I don't believe it. It's raining again.
How can there be so much water and so little life out there?
Repeat: This is a general distress call. Hello? Are you paying attention?
I know you're out there. I know you can hear me. So just... answer me. Tell me you're on your way... tell me I'm going to be rescued... tell me I'm not going to die alone.
I hope you're satisfied. I'm sure nothing gives you more pleasure than stifling my creativity.
Only you would consider barstools to be a form of artistic expression.
Oh yeah? Well, let's see how creative you are. Have you picked out the major's gift yet?
Gift?
For this Saturday. You do know what Saturday is, right?
Saturday?
Yes...
It's the one-month anniversary of your first date with Major Kira.
Oh. I suppose it is.
And you haven't picked out a gift.
Why should I?
The man's experienced unrequited love for the better part of three years and now that he finally has her, he wants to know why he should celebrate their anniversary.
Whatever you're trying to sell me, it won't work.

You think I'm going to get involved? No, thank you. The last thing I want to deal with is a panicked lover scrambling to find a present at the last minute. There's a whole Promenade of shopkeepers out there if you want to buy a gift.
A one-month anniversary gift. Have you ever heard of anything so ridiculous?
Okay... so now you've got him looking for a gift. What're you up to?
I tell you, you write it down, the next thing I know I'm in a holding cell.
I won't write a word, I promise. This is just... character research.
Right.

Quark, listen... I've been working on a crime novel. But I've hit a wall in my writing. It's not... truthful anymore. It's phony. Artificial. I'm having trouble creating real, flesh-and-blood characters. Especially nefarious ones. If you'd let me just watch and listen as you pull off...
... whatever it is you're going to pull off... it could really help me out. You could give me insight. I could even model my lead villain after you.
Lesson number one: no one involved in an "extralegal" activity wants to think of themselves as nefarious.
Sorry.
I'm a businessman. Now if you're interested in learning about my business... I suppose that could be arranged.
Great.
But nothing you see or hear turns up in print. And none of it gets back to your father. Understand?
Completely. So -- tell me about the scam. I mean, the plan.
Let's just say that the Constable's one month anniversary is going to be a very special occasion. For the major and for my bank account.
HELLO!! I can hear you two talking!! Can you hear me!!??
Yes! Yes, we can hear you!
Thank God!! Whoever you are, I love you! YES!! YES!! YES!!
My name's Lisa Cusak. Until a couple of days ago, I was the commanding officer of the Olympia.
The Olympia...
We left the Federation over eight years ago for a long-range exploration of the Beta Quadrant.
What happened to your ship, captain?
We were... finally heading home, if you can believe that. But then we picked up some strange energy readings in a nearby star system, and... I decided to stop and investigate.

We found an energy barrier around the fourth planet that was unlike anything we'd ever seen. When we probed it with our scanners, it triggered a quantum reaction. There was an enormous surge of metrion radiation that disabled our engines. The next thing I knew, we were spiraling in toward the surface. I gave the order to abandon ship and the last thing I remember is a console exploding in my face.
I woke up in an escape pod on the surface and I've spent the last day and a half sitting in this cave trying to raise someone on subspace.
Captain, I'm Doctor Bashir, chief medical officer. Your message said that you're on a L-class planet. Are you certain?

Positive. And to answer your next question, yes I've been giving myself fifteen cc's of triox every four hours to compensate for the excess carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Just like it says in my medical tricorder.
How much triox do you have left?
One hundred and fifty milliliters.
Captain, I want you to decrease the dosage to eight cc's every six hours. We'll have to stretch your supply as long as possible.
What happens when she runs out of the drug?
Yeah, what happens when the hypo goes dry?
You'll begin to experience the effects of hypoxia. But before that happens, the triox compound will have strengthened your cardio- pulmonary system, allowing you to better withstand the effects.
"Better withstand the effects." In other words, I'm going to be gasping for air and turning different shades of blue by the time you get here.
I'm... afraid so.
Thanks for brightening my day.
I wish there was something else we could do.
There is, actually. I can't sleep -- I think the injections are keeping me awake -- and I haven't had anyone to talk to for two days.
I think we can help you there. I'll have one of my officers stay on the com channel with you at all times.
And order them to enjoy it, too.
Done.
So who's first?
I think I better start. A lot of things have happened since you left, captain...
Second Fleet has hit the Dominion forces occupying Betazed three times in the last month. But they're still bringing in more reinforcements and fortifying their positions on the surface so--
Okay, that's it. No more war news. You're depressing me.
Sorry.

No, I'm sorry. I'm sorry for you and me and everyone in the Federation... I can't believe we're at war. Let's... change the subject. How about some good news. Tell me there's still something to look forward to when I get home. Tell me people still fall in love and get married and raise families.
They do.
Good. What about you? Are you married?
Seeing anyone? I hate to pry, but I'd like to think that there's still something positive in the life of a starship captain these days.
I... am seeing someone.
Now we're talking. Tell me about her. What's her name?
Kasidy Yates.
Kasidy? Is she the same Kasidy I spoke to earlier?
That's her.
She one of your officers?
No. Civilian. Freighter captain.
Uh, oh. Sounds like you're having problems.
What makes you say that?
There's no joy in that voice of yours, Ben. In fact, the tension level went up when you said her name. You sounded more relaxed when you were telling me about the war.
You still there?
Yes. You just... caught me a little off-guard.
I can tell. You know, back when I was a junior officer, I dated a civilian for six years. Want to hear about it? Sure you do. Why? Because it's a funny story and one of us needs to cheer up.

So -- we met on Andor. I was assigned to the Federation Embassy as an attache and he was working in the Andorian Agricultural Ministry. At first, I didn't want anything to do with him -- he kept pointing his antennae at me whenever I walked through his office and I found that sort of rude...
So let me get this straight -- you have fifteen cases of stolen Denevan crystals...
Allegedly stolen.
... allegedly stolen crystals hidden somewhere down in Cargo Bay Three. And you're planning to sell them to a Nausicaan friend of yours -- who just happens to be a known criminal...
Alleged criminal.

So, how are you going to get an "alleged" criminal onto the station and deliver the "allegedly" stolen goods to him without Odo getting wind of it? And what does any of this have to do with his anniversary?
Watch and learn..
Well. This is it.
Can I see it?
Very nice. I'm sure the major will love it.
So how're going to give it to her? What sort of evening do you have planned?
I... don't have anything planned.
Fortunately for you, there's still time. (pulls out a tray of isolinear rods) Pick one.
A holosuite program?
It's your anniversary. You have to do something special.
I bought her a gift.
Have it your way.
Of course, if it was me... and I'd found true love after a lifetime of searching... every month would be worth celebrating.
Let me see those programs.

Looks like the constable's going to be busy Saturday night. I guess that means he won't be following me around the station... or watching the airlocks for wanted criminals... or monitoring the cargo bays for illegal transactions.
He has deputies.
Deputies I can handle. With Odo out of the way... my biggest problem will be deciding what to do with all the money I'm about to make...
... and both my sisters are teachers. I don't know how they can do it. Personally -- I can't stand children.
Uh-huh.
I know, I know -- everyone loves children. Not me.
Uh-huh.
What about you? You like children?
Uh-huh.
Really?
Uh-huh.
You know, doctor... I'm starting to think that maybe, just maybe you're not really paying attention to-- wait a minute. What's that? There's something moving out there. It's getting closer.
What?
Stay back... no, don't hurt me...
Captain, what's going on?
Please... stay back... no... don't... NOOOO!!!
Captain Cusak can you hear me!
Hello? Hello? My God...
She's... gone.
Who is this? What have you done?
I have... eaten her.
What?
I've eaten her! What difference does it make to you? You weren't even listening to her!
My sincere apologies. I was... caught up in my work.
I'm a patient, aren't I? Doesn't that make me part of your work?
You're right, you're absolutely right. I don't know what I was thinking. You now have my full attention.
Well, I've got news for you, Doc -- I'm all talked out. It's time for you to cheer up one of your patients and take her mind off her impending doom.
You're not doomed.
I feel better already. See how easy that was? Now keep going.
Uh... what should I talk about?
How did they let you out of medical school with this kind of bedside manner? Are you sure you're a doctor?
Graduated second in my class.
Oh... and we're especially proud of that, aren't we?
I get the feeling it's going to take me several hours to crawl out of this rather sizeable hole I've dug for myself.
Not at all. It'll take you days...
Captain... ?
I'm fine. It's almost time for my next injection.
Any dizziness?
A little... especially when I stand up.

If you're about to deliver more bad news, I'd just as soon you kept it to yourself. Besides, you're just trying to change the subject. You were about to impress me with amazing tales of your brilliant academic career at medical school.
All right. Medical school. I matriculated in the fall of --
Back up. Don't you know how to tell a story. Start at the beginning. Why did you decide to become a doctor?
Ah. Therein lies a tale...
You have my personal assurance that they're high-quality crystals. And you won't find them at this price anywhere else in the quadrant.
Five days. Cargo Bay Three. See you then.
I'll take this one.
Paris, Nineteen twenty-eight. Good choice. Say what you will about Hew-mons today -- their past was certainly romantic.
Book us four hours beginning at twenty-one hundred, Sunday night.
You mean Saturday.
No, I mean Sunday.
But Saturday is the anniversary of your first date.
Yes, but our first date ended badly. It's not something I want to commemorate, so I've decided to celebrate the anniversary of our first kiss.
Your first kiss?
Romantic, isn't it?
Come on... come on... please...
What's the matter?
My partner. I can't... get him on the channel. He's changed his com system protocols.
Already? You just talked to him.

He's a wanted man, Jake. He has to be very careful about how often he uses subspace... the authorities might try to... trace his signal. I don't have any way of contacting him before he gets here Saturday night.
But... you can explain it to him when he arrives. Just tell him he'll have to wait a day.
Haven't you been paying attention? If he sets foot on this station while Odo's on duty, we'll both end up in a holding cell faster than you can say "criminal conspiracy."
Then what are you going to do?
I think my best option is... panic.

... when the fighting first broke out, I thought, "All right, O'Brien. You've done this before. Keep your head down and focus on the job, you'll get through it, just like you did in the last war." But this war is different. Or maybe I'm different. I have this sense of... growing isolation... I see people every day, talk to them, laugh with them, but... part of me is always saying, "They may not be here tomorrow, Miles. Don't get too close... " I'm... I'm sorry. I shouldn't be putting this all on your shoulders, captain.
It's all right, Miles. I don't mind. It sounds like you really need to talk with someone about this.
I'm sure it's the last thing you need to hear. I should be cheering you up.
Forget about me. You're the one who needs cheering up.
Now there's a sad state of affairs.
Look, you've seen a lot of combat in the last year -- that's a heavy burden to carry around.
You sure you're a captain and not a counselor?
Oh, I'm sure. I'll let you in on a little secret, Miles... I dislike the whole concept of a ship's counselor.
Me too. I mean, I like some of them personally, but...
But sometimes they just get in the way.
That's exactly how I feel! But saying it out loud is almost heresy. There's this assumption nowadays that only someone with a diploma can listen to your problems or give you advice.
Sometimes all you need are good friends.
Exactly.
So where are they?
Excuse me?
Where are your friends, Miles? Why aren't they helping you through this?
I... haven't spoken to them about any of this. We just don't... talk about that kind of thing.
Well... if you can't talk to your friends and you can't talk to your wife, you know who that leaves... ?
Excuse me, but it's eighteen hundred hours.
Already?
'fraid so.
But we're still talking.
Boys, boys -- don't fight over me. Miles, I'll talk to you in the morning. Think about what I said.
All right. And I will. Good-night, Captain.
Good-night.
Well, don't let me keep you from your work, Julian. I know how busy you are.
No work tonight.

Oh, so you've decided to spend your valuable time conversing with your patient again. That's three days in a row. You must be swamped with paperwork by now... I feel awful keeping you from your duties like this.
I was able to catch up on my paperwork this afternoon, thank you very much.
Let me guess -- thanks to your amazing, genetically engineered brain, you not only did your work, you did the work of ten other doctors at the same time.
Wrong again, my superhuman friend. As a matter of fact.... I'm not feeling well at all.
Tell me.
The last injection didn't do the trick. I feel this... heavy weight on my chest... it's getting harder to breathe... and every time I move my head, the cave starts spinning...
Come in.
What is it?
Captain Cusak's out of triox. She's beginning to feel the effects of C-O-two poisoning.
Already? I thought she had at least another day's worth of injections.
So did I. But it appears that the last vial of triox was tainted somehow -- probably in the crash.
How long does she have?
No more than two days.
That's not good. Because we're still three days away.
We need more speed.
Speed's not the problem. I could increase the warp plasma ninety- seven gigahertz. That would increase our velocity to warp nine point five and save us almost a full day.
But the problem on the Defiant is how to maintain structural integrity when we go above warp nine.
Exactly. The ship literally starts tearing herself apart at those speeds.
Is there any way of strengthening the structural integrity field?
Not without bleeding power from some other system.
Such as?
The phaser reserves...
That would be extremely unwise. If we empty the defense reserve, we could find ourselves at an extreme disadvantage if we encounter a Dominion ship.
We're a long way from the front lines, Worf. The chances of meeting a Dominion ship out here are negligible.
We should not take the risk.
She'll die if we can't get to her faster.
Use the phaser reserve, Chief. Give us all the speed you can.
Aye, sir. Thank you, sir.
How's it going?
We're... increasing speed. The captain's condition is worsening.
I see. Is there anything I can do?
I don't think so.
Well. I guess I'll see you later.
Right.
Right.
Are you sure you want to hear about this?
Trust me Ben, I'd much rather be worrying about your love life than about my own problems right now.
When Kasidy came to the bridge last night, all I wanted her to do was leave. And I couldn't begin to tell you why.
She doesn't belong there Ben, that's why. She doesn't belong in that part of your life and you know it. Off-duty, I'm sure Kasidy is exactly what you need.
But on the Defiant, she's a random element... a piece that doesn't fit anywhere in the puzzle.
She was our convoy liaison officer on our last mission, and a damned good one...

This isn't about her, this is about you. You're having trouble doing your job when she's on the Defiant and that's a problem. It's also affecting your relationship, and that's another problem. Don't take it so hard. So you can't mix your personal life and your professional life? Most people can't. I certainly can't. I once served on the same starbase as my sister -- what a nightmare that was!
I'm looking forward to meeting you, Lisa. And I know I'm not the only one around here who feels that way.
If you ask me... ... everyone on that ship... could use some R and R...
Beautiful aren't they?
Gorgeous.
Do you know how much I was going to get for these?
Almost... two hundred bars.
That's a lot.
No kidding it's a lot. Now it's just a crate full of junk.
You still have another day. Things might work out.

They might. But they won't. That's the way my life is. Do you know how much latinum I almost made in the last year? I almost made a fortune by overcharging Weyoun during the Dominion occupation. I almost made a fortune by helping the Grand Nagus regain his throne. And I almost found a thousand bricks of gold- pressed latinum, before I realized it was in Morn's stomach.
It's been a tough year for everyone.
You mean "the war?" Let me tell you something about "the war" -- everyone's had a victory in this conflict except me.
You did rescue your mother from the Dominion.

And then she promptly destroyed the entire fabric of Ferengi society by letting women wear clothes. That's no victory. I'm cursed. That's what it is. I should change the name of my bar to "Cursed Quark's." I wonder how much it would cost to redo all the signs... Ah...
You know, there's still a chance that Odo won't find out about any of this.
Oh, he'll find out. Odo would love nothing more than to see me in jail... and after all I've done for him...
Like what?

Like helping him find true love. That's right -- if it wasn't for me, he and Major Kira would've never gotten together in the first place. I was there for him during all the heartache and lonely nights when he was wallowing in misery because she was still seeing Shakaar. I told him to make his move. I told him not to give up. I was there for him. And what did I get out of it? Nothing. He still spies on me, still hassles me for minor infractions of the law and still can't wait for the opportunity to send me to prison. I should've remembered the two hundred and eighty-fifth Rule of Acquisition: No good deed ever goes unpunished.
To failure.
I'm not drinking to that.

Jake, in ten minutes, my partner's ship will dock. In fifteen minutes Odo will arrest him. In twenty minutes, my name will come up, and in twenty-five minutes Odo will be in here with a warrant. I think you should humor me on this one.
Quark, I'd like that holosuite now after all.
You would?
That's right. It turns out that... Nerys agrees with you. She wants to celebrate the anniversary of our first date, not our first kiss. So... here we are.
Is the holosuite still available?
It's... all yours.
The program... ?
Odo... have a good time.
Thank you. We will.
I don't believe it.
Neither do I.
I'm going to win this one, Jake. And you know what's the best part -- I beat Odo. I finally beat him, Jake. I did it!! I beat him!!
Well... he looks happy.
He should be... he's about to make his biggest profit of the year.
I don't know, Odo. You sure you want to let him get away with smuggling Denevan crystals?
I owe him one. So, he'll get this one -- but only this one.
Why is it every time I think I have you all figured out... you manage to do something to surprise me? Like tonight -- where did you get the idea to celebrate our one month anniversary in Paris?
Some mysteries are better left... unsolved.
I want a complete scan of that barrier, but use passive sensors only, gentlemen. An active scan is what triggered the destruction of the Olympia.
Aye, sir.
It appears to be an exogenic field generated by unstable elements in the planet's core.
Captain Cusak just lost consciousness. She's in the last stages of C-O-two poisoning. If she's going to have any chance at all, I have to get her to Sickbay in the next forty-five minutes.

Captain... there's no way for the Defiant to penetrate the barrier. The energy's composed of subspace metrion radiation -- if we get anywhere near it, the dilithium matrix in our warp core will collapse... and we'll be pulled down to the planet surface, just like the Olympia.
Options?
Could we beam through it?
We can't get close enough to the barrier to initiate transport.
What about a shuttle pod? Their impulse engines don't use anti- matter.
It is unlikely that a shuttle could withstand the gravimetric stresses within the barrier.
Unlikely, but not impossible.
I didn't come all this way to give up now. I'll take the risk. Doctor, Chief, you're with me. Mister Worf, you have the bridge.
Aye, sir.
Sisko to Defiant. We're preparing to enter the barrier.
Acknowledged. Good luck, captain.
Thank you, commander.
Shields down to seventy-three percent.
Primary power grid off-line -- switching to backups.
Shields at fifty percent.
I'm losing the navigational computer...
We're coming out of it!
Damage report.
Some buckling in the starboard hull plating... but otherwise, we're fine.
Scan the planet, Doctor.
I'm not showing any lifesigns.
But I have found the crash site... and the cave.
Is there a place for us to set down nearby?
Yes.
How're we doing on time?
It's going to be tight. We have to get her in the shuttle and back to the ship in twenty minutes.
Still no life readings.
There's only one direction she could've gone...
It's a human female... fifty-one years of age at the time of death...
Cause of death... carbon dioxide poisoning.
But this can't be Lisa. This woman's been dead for years.
Three years, two months.
All the evidence fits. Her age, rank, the way she died.
But if she died three years ago... how have we... been talking to her?
It must have something to do with the energy barrier. When her subspace radio signal passed through the metrion radiation in the barrier, the signal was somehow... time-shifted into the future.
And when you sent a return signal...
It went through the barrier and traveled back through time in the same way.
We've been talking to someone in the past.
So what do we do now?
We should bury her.
Not here. Not... alone in this cave. We'll take her back with us. Give her a proper burial. Among friends.
It's called an "Irish Wake." It's a way of memorializing a death and celebrating life at the same time.
What are we supposed to do?
We drink. Sing songs. Laugh. Cry. Talk about the deceased.
It sounds... almost Klingon.
Hey.
Hey, yourself..
When this is over... I want to talk to you about something. Something that's been on my mind.
Okay. Is this.... about me?
No. It's actually about me.
That's a relief.
I wanted to explain... my behavior these last few days...
Sounds good to me. But let's talk about it over dinner. You can cook.
That's a deal.
I'd just like to say... that although I only spoke with her for a short time... that I admired Lisa Cusak...

I cared about her... and I'll miss her. And one more thing -- contrary to popular belief... I am not the arrogant, self-absorbed, god-like doctor that I appear to be on occasion... Isn't anyone going to object to that statement?
I will if you insist.
I insist.
Then I object.

Thank you, Miles Edward O'Brien. I do have a heart. And I do care for all of you... even if it sometimes seems as though all I care about is my work. To the woman that reminded me that it's necessary to say that sometimes... Lisa Cusak.
To Lisa.
I never shook her hand... and I never saw her face... but she made me laugh... and she made me weep. She was all by herself... and I was surrounded by my friends...

... but I felt more alone than she did. We've grown apart, the lot of us. We didn't mean for it to happen -- but it did just the same. The war's changed us... made us pull away from each other. Lisa Cusak was my friend and now she's dead. But you're my friends too. And I want my friends in my life. Because one day we may wake up and discover that someone's missing from this circle... and on that day we'll mourn... but we shouldn't have to mourn alone. To Lisa and the sweet sound of her voice...
Doctor Bashir. The time is oh- five hundred.
Right.
Julian... we have to get up.
Are you sure?
It's a big day.
It was a big night. It cleared up a lot of questions.
Such as?
(touching one of Ezri's Trill
I suppose you're going to want to tell Miles.
Why would I do that?
Because you tell him everything.
True... but this time, I'll make an exception.
Good -- now we really should get going. We don't want the Defiant leaving without us.
You know, I've never gone into battle with someone I've slept with.
There's a first time for everything.
Now that we're finally together, it'd be a shame if anything happened to one of us...
Let's make a pact. We both come home alive.
You've got yourself a deal.
I'm going to hold you to that.
Now remember, Kirayoshi has his checkup tomorrow morning at oh- nine hundred.
I've already confirmed the appointment with Nurse Bandee. One more bite...
And try to get some rest... don't stay up too late writing that paper on... whatever those trees are called.
Arfillian Ficus and they're not trees, they're shrubs.
Right. Anyway, be sure to get some sleep, oh yeah, and --
Miles -- stop worrying. We're going to be fine.
I know.
Molly -- don't touch that!
I let you play with my toys.
It's not a toy -- it's a model.
Then maybe it belongs in a museum. DEEP SPACE NINE: "What You... " - REV. 04/26/99 - TEASER 4.
I suppose I could give it to Julian...
Sounds good to me. Speaking of Julian... have you told him about Starfleet's offer yet?
I haven't had time.
I knew it.
What's that supposed to mean?
We're not going back to Earth.
Of course we are. Daddy's going to teach at the Academy -- as soon as the war's over.
Then why haven't you told Julian?
Out of the mouth of babes...
I'll tell him. When I think he's ready to hear it. I love you. Be a good boy, now. And you listen to Mommy while I'm gone.
Just you be careful.
I always am.
How's that?
It's doing wonders for my head. But it's my stomach that's bothering me...
Well, if it helps -- morning sickness usually ends after the first trimester.
That's two more months! I don't think I'm going to make it.
You'll make it.
Promise me something, Ben... (patting her stomach) ... promise you'll come back to us.
I promise.
I don't believe it...
(hit by another wave of nausea) It's not that...
Come in.
I thought I'd walk you to the Defiant.
I'd like that.
(looking around the room) How's Kas?
That answer your question?
Reports of my death have been exaggerated. But not by much.
Isn't there something you can take to make you feel better?
She doesn't believe in taking medication unless it's absolutely necessary.
Sounds necessary to me.
Waiting for you to leave only makes me feel worse. If you're going to go -- go.
You're sure I can't get you anything?
I think she's sure...
Times like this... I'm glad I'm a man.
You're up early today.
I'm always up early.
But this is a special day, isn't it?
I don't know what you mean.
(leaning over, confidentially) It's a good day to die.
Every day is a good day to die.

But some days are better than others. Like today, for instance. The day the Federation- Klingon-Romulan Alliance launches its invasion of Cardassia. The final push in the long struggle to rid the Alpha Quadrant of the Dominion and save my bar in the process.
Who told you that?
He did.
Morn? And how does he know?
He's friends with Admiral Ross. Or maybe Sisko told him while they were having dinner. I don't know how he knows. He just knows.
I have to go.
Good guess, Morn. Today's the day...
Mind if I walk with you, commander?
Not at all. Captain Sisko informed me you were joining us on the mission. I hope that when we reach Cardassia, we find Colonel Kira alive and well.
So do I, commander. So do I...
Captain on the bridge.
All right, people... what do you say we end this war?
Sounds good to me.
Ensign, I believe you know the way to Cardassia.
If I get lost, I'll just follow the ship in front of us.
The Federation invasion fleet has left Deep Space Nine. They'll reach the Cardassian border by tomorrow night.
Our brave Jem'Hadar soldiers have a motto "Victory is Life."
I'm glad you're familiar with it. Because today, those words have meaning for us all.
The outcome of this battle will determine the outcome of the war. Either we destroy their invasion force or they destroy us. There are no other options.
Fight well today, and Romulus will be yours to do with as you please.
Yes, yes -- and Earth too.
I assure you, the pleasure is all mine.
Is something bothering you?
Apparently, I was under the mistaken impression that all Federation territories would fall under my jurisdiction -- including Earth.
And so they shall.
But you just promised the Breen...
I'd promise the Breen the entire Alpha Quadrant if I thought it would help win this war.
The Founder is wise in all things.
Founder. I've heard a disturbing rumor about the traitor Damar.
What about him?
He may be alive.
Is this possible?
I don't see how. We destroyed his ship, his rebel bases...
But his body was never found.
They say he's here -- on Cardassia Prime. In the capital, no less...
Look into this matter.
And if Damar is alive...
... he won't be for long.
Halt.
Step forward. Slowly.
Have we done something wrong? We're new to the city and I'm afraid we've gotten lost --
Quiet!
You are Legate Damar.
You see? I told you you looked like him. This isn't the first time my cousin has been mistaken for that traitor.
He will be taken to Dominion Headquarters. You will die here.
I do not understand you.
I hope you don't consider me ungrateful, but what are you doing here?
Watching your backs.
I thought we agreed it would be safer if you stayed out of sight.
That's what the helmet's for. You should be wearing one, too. Every Jem'Hadar and Breen soldier on Cardassia is looking for you.
If I'm going to lead this revolt, I can't do it hiding in a cellar. I had to attend tonight's gathering.
It was a great success.
You can tell me the details later.
If anyone asks, you're my prisoners.
... the vote was unanimous. The work disruptions will begin tomorrow.
Power, transportation and communication facilities throughout Cardassia will be sabotaged.
The Dominion fleet will be cut off from all ground support.
That way, they'll have to face the invasion force on their own.
And once the Dominion is crushed...
Cardassia will be free again.

When you were a small boy, I was worried about you. Always getting in trouble. Secretive... so full of deceit. Little did I know you would turn such distasteful characteristics into virtues. More tea?
You're too kind.
You hear that, Chief?
Sounds like the Doppler compensators are out of phase.
How's she handling, ensign?
She's not quite as smooth as the old Defiant, sir. Feels a bit sluggish.
Chief?
I'm on it. O'Brien to Engineering. Recalibrate the inertial dampers and check the plasma flow regulators while you're at it.
Right away, Chief.
You'd think someone would've come up with a a better inertial control system...
What's that, Miles?
I said, could you please wipe that grin off your face? You're not the first person to fall in love, you know.
I thought you'd be happy for me.
I am happy for you. O'Brien to Engineering. Now try re-aligning the induction coils.
Will do.
Look, Julian... there's something I have to talk to you about.
You're getting pressure from Keiko, aren't you?
How'd you know?
It's a big decision. I'm surprised it didn't come up sooner.
Actually, we've been talking about it for quite a while.
Well, you can stop talking about it. We'll put the Alamo in my quarters.
I could still use a little more equalization on the torque buffers.
Right. I'll try to compensate with the impulse response filters.
That way, your quarters won't be so cluttered and you can still use it whenever you want.
I wasn't talking about the Alamo model. Besides, it's too big for your quarters.
You let me worry about that. So what did you want to talk to me about?
It's nothing that can't wait. Is that any better, Nog?
Torque buffers are stable.
You're sure you're not angry?
Why should I be angry? I've been asking you to tell the doctor how you feel about him for the past month.
Well, now that he knows how I feel...
I am happy for you.
That's a relief.
... but I am going to kill him.
You're kidding, right?
And Jadzia said I had no sense of humor.
I wish she were here, too, Constable.
If I only knew where Kira was... that she was all right...
The colonel's a survivor. She knows how to take care of herself.
This war, captain... it has to end.
One way or another... it will. And soon.
Mother?
The Emissary's task is nearing completion.
Are you talking about the war?
You have walked the path the Prophets laid out for you, Benjamin. Do not falter now.
I don't intend to.
Know this, my son. Your journey's end lies not before you, but behind you.
Captain?
The Prophets just came to me in a vision...
I take it they weren't bringing good news.
I'm not sure. I suppose only time will tell.
Hello, Adami.
You're back.
Is that all you have to say to me?
I see the Pah-wraiths have restored your sight.
They've forgiven me. I hope you can find it in your heart to do the same.
I don't forgive war criminals.
To think I took Gul Dukat to my bed, one of the most hated men in Bajoran history...
Adami -- I've told you how much I regret my actions during the occupation...
Of course you do.
(glad to change the subject) Have you learned how to release the Pah-wraiths?
The secrets of the Kosst Amojan have been revealed to me.
Then why haven't you gone to the Fire Caves and freed them?
(with a beguiling smile) I was waiting for you.
So you do forgive me...
I need your help, Dukat. It's as simple as that.
All you have to do is ask.
Together we'll free the Pah- wraiths so they can lay claim to the Celestial Temple and destroy the Prophets.
And their Emissary...
No -- Benjamin Sisko will be dealt with by me and me alone.
Assuming he survives the invasion of Cardassia.
He'll survive... but I promise you, he'll wish he hadn't.
Do you have any threes?
Go fish.
Don't tell me you're quitting?
It's just not my game.
Want to try pinochle again?
How 'bout rummy? Or gin rummy? Five card stud? Canasta?
How about some tongo?
Did they play tongo in Las Vegas in nineteen sixty-two?
How could they? It's a Ferengi game.
Which is why my holographic program can't create it.
I know, I know this place is period specific. For a hologram, you're not very accommodating.
Is that why you dropped by? To insult me?
I dropped by because I had nothing else to do. My bar hasn't had half a dozen customers all day. Everyone's off fighting this stupid war.
It's not easy to stay behind, is it? Knowing that your friends are out there risking their lives...
They think they have it rough, they should try living my life for a day. The hospitality industry isn't for the faint- hearted.
The bartender's life is a lonely one.

That's right. But few people understand that. They think it's one big, happy party. They forget that the person giving the party never has any fun. DEEP SPACE NINE:'What You... " - REV. 04/26/99 - ACT TWO 28.
He's too busy making sure everybody else is having fun. All I do -- all day long -- is give, give, give...
Bartending is a very noble profession. And you do it well under some very difficult circumstances, I might add. You should be proud.
You think so?
I know so, pallie.
I just hope Nog and the rest of those heroic idiots come back in one piece..
Vic, sweetie, are you ready? Jimmy and Pete are about to go on.
(explaining to Quark) Sorry, pallie, gotta run. Durante and Lawford are at the Sands. Can't miss that.
I thought you said a bartender's life was a lonely one?
It is. But I'm not a bartender.
Go fish.
Is it really necessary to rest so often?
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I don't need you to wait for me. Go on ahead... wander aimlessly through these caves for the rest of your miserable life.
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I'm in no hurry. During the Occupation, my people found the Bajorans' fear of these caves amusing. Yet somehow, none of us ever found the time to visit them. And now, here I am... Ironic, isn't it?
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I don't care.
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: (surprised by her bluntness) Excuse me?
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I'm sure you have many "interesting" anecdotes about the Occupation, but I have no desire to hear them.
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I meant no disrespect, Adami --
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: And stop calling me Adami. That privilege is no longer yours.
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I see. Then how should I...
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: From now on, you will address me as "eminence." Is that clear?
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: Perfectly... eminence.
scene: 37   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES (SECOND LEVEL CAVES)

quote: I see your point. But for two millennia the Jem'Hadar have been the Dominion's first line of defense. It would damage their morale to take a back seat to the Breen.
Very well. In the spirit of our new alliance, I will inform the Jem'Hadar that the Breen forces will be positioned alongside them.
I'm glad that pleases you.
I think we have a problem.
Our lines are spread too thin, especially here -- -- at the center.
Do you agree?
Notify the Jem'Hadar. Order them to reinforce the center of their lines...
Now what?
Founder -- I'm relieved to see you're all right.
Long range communications are down. I can't contact the Jem'Hadar.
Of course I'll keep trying.
What caused the power failure?
I'm afraid it was sabotage.
Almost every Dominion installation on Cardassia Prime has suffered damage.
Damar.
We captured some of the terrorists... But they're not soldiers -- they're ordinary citizens.
Are you telling me the Cardassian people are rising up against us?
(struggling to get the words out) I'm sure it's only a small number of malcontents...
We have no way of knowing that, do we?
Founder, may I make a suggestion?
(still strangling Broca) I'm sure Broca is most interested in what you have to say.
If the Cardassian people are responsible for these acts of terrorism... if Damar and his fanatics have turned them against us, then it's the people who should be punished.
What do you say to that?
(barely croaking out the words) Severely punished.
I'm glad we're all in agreement.
It's been twenty-four minutes.
Not bad.
If the Dominion hasn't been able to restore power in the capital, then the entire planet must be in chaos...
Let's hope so.
I'm afraid I could only find two more lightsticks. I know there are others in the house somewhere...
Stop dawdling and bring them over here.
Ah, how well I remember that tone of voice... it reminds me of the demanding and inconsiderate boy ou used to be.
I haven't changed much, have I?
This will send a clear message to the Dominion... the Cardassian people will fight to regain their freedom.
I hope they realize their fight is just beginning. We have to hit the enemy again -- and harder this time.
That won't be easy. They'll have tightened their security.
It doesn't matter -- we can't lose our momentum.
The colonel is right. We can't rest until Cardassia is free. And when it is, we'll have you to thank. Without you, this rebellion would've died in its infancy.
