How ironic that Cardassia's saviour should be a former Bajoran terrorist.
Don't canonize me just yet.
Twenty-six and a half minutes. Let's see what the Dominion has to say for itself.
Citizens of Cardassia... shame on you. This latest wave of vandalism directed against your Dominion allies must stop.
I wouldn't count on it.

Let me assure you, we know that these disgraceful acts of sabotage were carried out by a mere handful of extremists. But these radicals must come to realize that their disobedience will not be tolerated... that you, the Cardassian people, will suffer the consequences of their cowardly actions. Which is why I must inform you that a few moments ago, Dominion troops reduced Lakarian City to ashes. There were no survivors. Two million men, women and children... gone in a matter of seconds..

For each act of sabotage committed against the Dominion, another Cardassian city will be destroyed. I implore you not to let that happen. Let us return to the spirit of friendship and cooperation that has existed between our peoples, so that together, we can defeat our common enemies... the Federation, the Klingons, the Romulans and all the others who stand against us. Thank you.
I should've killed that Vorta jackal when I had the chance.
You want another one? Then let's attack Dominion Headquarters.
Chop off a snake's head and its body dies...
Damar -- for the past two years, you practically lived in that building...
If you're asking me if I know a way to get us inside, the answer is no -- not without valid security protocols.
Then we'll have to force our way in -- We'll need some kind of explosive device.
I'll get right on it.
What you're proposing... is suicide.
Mila, if you don't have anything positive to say...
I'll prepare some food. No one should die on an empty stomach.
Be still.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: I am being still. What's taking so long?
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: The stinger is embedded in your skin.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: I know that.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Does it hurt?
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Of course it hurts. Have you ever been stung by a cave-wasp?
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Not that I recall. I warned you not to slap at it.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: It was annoying me.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: There. Is that better?
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Not really. This Bajoran skin is so... delicate.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Then perhaps you should've stayed a Cardassian.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Nothing would've made me happier. But I needed to win your trust.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: And you have to trust me. Only together can we free the Pah- wraiths.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: You still care about me, don't you? Don't you?
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: All I care about is freeing the Pah-wraiths.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: That's not true and you know it.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: You may look like a Bajoran, but your ego is unmistakably Cardassian.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: I'll take that as a compliment.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Of course you will. Now do us both a favor... next time you see a cave-wasp, leave it alone.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: I'll try to remember that.
scene: 46A  INT. ANOTHER SECTION OF FIRE CAVES

quote: Sir -- Chancellor Martok is asking to speak with you and Admiral Ross.
Put them through.
Gentlemen! A magnificent victory lies before us.
I trust those are prophetic words, chancellor.
They are. And I haven't forgotten the promise I made to both of you.
That the three of us would share a bottle of bloodwine on Cardassia Prime.
A bottle? I brought a barrel of twenty-three-oh-nine -- there is no finer vintage.
Then I'll meet you two on Cardassia.
We'll see who gets there first.
The chancellor makes victory sound easy.
He knows it won't be. Sisko to all hands. Prepare to engage the enemy.
I'll say one thing for the Breen, they know how to pilot their ships.
So do you, ensign --
Stay with him.
I'm trying, but he's slippery...
Mister Worf?
Unable to lock target.
We have two Jem'Hadar ships coming in behind us, bearing one- three-six mark four.
Evasive action, pattern Delta.
Hang on.
Well done, ensign.
But I lost the Breen ship we were after.
I wouldn't be too worried about it -- there are plenty more to choose from.
You've hardly touched your meal. No wonder you don't look well.
Of course I don't look well -- I've been living in a cellar.
So has Legate Damar.
What about him?
He finished everything on his plate. Which explains why he's such a fine, handsome figure of a man...
I'm not sure I follow you.
I do. Mila -- I believe you're falling in love.
I'm old enough to be his mother.
Nonsense.
Politicians...
Who could that be?
I'll go see.
Can I help you?
What's taking her so long?
I don't know...
Mila!
Garak -- look out!
I can't take my eyes off you for a minute...
Just fix the shoulder.
(to Julian, wincing in pain) Careful!
Sit still or you're going to wind up with one arm shorter than the other.
You'd do anything to beat me at darts.
I haven't lost a game to you in months.
I'm going to miss our games, Julian.
What are you talking about? You're going to be fine --
I'm leaving D.S. Nine -- I'm moving back to Earth.
When?
When the war's over.
Why?
I've been offered a position at Starfleet Academy. Professor of Engineering.
I see.
Somebody has to teach you officers the difference between a warp matrix flux capacitor and a self-sealing stembolt.
I suppose so...
Captain -- I have Admiral Ross.
On screen.
The Romulan flagship's been destroyed. Their entire line is collapsing.
We'll try to help out.
With what? Ben, we're losing too many ships. We've got to find a way to turn the Dominion's left flank.
It's too well protected, but their lines are spread pretty thin in the middle.
You help the Romulans. Martok and I will hammer their center.
On my way. Have Attack Wings Six-Four and Six-Five follow us.
Aye, sir.
What's taking so long?
Our engineers assure me that long- range communications should be restored momentarily.
You've been saying that for hours. Meanwhile, we have no way of contacting our ships... no way of knowing how the battle is progressing.
Founder -- our troops have captured the traitor Damar.
Finally, some good news.
There's more. Colonel Kira and Garak have been apprehended with him.
Even better.
Shall I have them brought here?
What for? Have them executed immediately.
With pleasure.
Understood. It will be done at once.
On your feet.
Why?
We prefer our prisoners to be standing when they die.
Does anyone have any final words?
You may kill us, but Cardassia will --
Enough. Final words are not permitted.
How disappointing.
Ready weapons.
That's for Lakarian City.
Legate Damar -- I pledge my life to free Cardassia from the Dominion.
With men like you on our side, how can we fail?
Jem'Hadar ship off the port bow.
Shields are down to sixty percent.
This is no good -- I'd better get you to Sickbay.
I'm a little busy right now...
That's an order.
Look, Julian --
You heard him, Chief.
Yes, sir.
Another Jem'Hadar to port.
Diverting auxiliary power to port shields.
Dax -- we need some support from our attack fighters.
Breen ship off the starboard aft.
Sir -- most of our fighters are either destroyed or under attack themselves.
You're going to have to get us out of here, ensign.
I'm trying, sir.
Sir -- the Cardassians... they're attacking the other Dominion ships.
I think they've switched sides.
Yes!
It couldn't come at a better time. Come about and head for the center of their lines. This is our chance to punch through.
Aye, sir.
Founder -- long range communications are back on-line.
It's about time.
(off his monitor, shocked) I don't believe it...
What now?
The Cardassian fleet has turned against us.
Have our forces pull back and regroup at Cardassia Prime.
But we'll be completely surrounded.
There'll be no more running.
We should've rid ourselves of the Cardassians at the first sign of rebellion.
If I could speak to the rebels... get them to change their minds...
Perhaps you could reawaken their patriotic spirit...
Exactly.
On the other hand, they're just as likely to convince you to betray us.
Me betray you? Never!
You're right. Because we're not going to give you the opportunity.
Wait! You're making a mistake...
I don't think so.
But I've done everything you've asked! I tell you -- I'm loyal. I believe in the Dominion!
I won't miss him.
I want the Cardassians exterminated.
Which ones?
All of them. The entire population.
That's going to take some time.
Then I suggest you begin at once.
Captain -- the Dominion forces are retreating toward Cardassia Prime.
Sir -- Admiral Ross and Chancellor Martok would like to speak to you.
I'm sure they would. On screen.
I never thought I'd say this, but thank god for the Cardassians.
As I predicted -- the day is ours.
Not yet it isn't.
Ben, we've driven the Dominion back to Cardassia Prime. We can keep them bottled-up there indefinitely.
But what if they use that time to rebuild their fleet?
The Dominion has displayed an ability to build ships at an impressive rate. We must continue our attack.
At what cost?
We've already lost a third of our fleet.
And we must see to it that those soldiers did not die in vain.
Admiral -- with the Cardassians joining us, we have an opportunity to put an end to this war, once and for all.
All right, gentlemen... we press on.
My people will sing songs about this moment.
All right, people. You heard the orders. Let's finish what we started.
Let me guess... we're here.
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: We've reached the end of one journey and stand ready to begin another.
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: What's the matter, Dukat? You look disappointed.
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: I know this sounds naive, but I was expecting to see fire... they are called the fire caves.
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: And with good reason.
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: (reading from the book) Lano ka'la bo'shar lanu no'vala, pahrom carana mokado ba'jah. Ko'se nusso ma'kora kajani... lano ka'la Kosst Amojan.
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: Is that better?
scene: 92   INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: (to Damar, looking at a PADD) According to this map, it's a long way from the cargo door to the briefing room.
That could be a problem. If we get trapped in one of the corridors --
What the hell --
The Jem'Hadar... they're leveling the city, building by building.
We have to go -- now.
Once we get inside the complex, we stop at nothing until we capture the changeling. For Cardassia.
Garak --

During all my years of exile... I imagined what it would be like to come home... maybe even to live in this house again with Mila. But now she's dead and this house is about to become a pile of rubble... My Cardassia is gone.
Then fight for a new Cardassia.
I have a better reason than that, colonel. Revenge.
That can work, too.
I rid myself of the Prophets and shed a lifetime of hypocrisy.
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: I've never seen you looking so radiant...
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: I feel like a young woman, waiting for my lover to sweep me off my feet...
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: Do you give yourself willingly to the Pah-wraiths?
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: With all my heart.
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: Then call to them.
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: Bring me the book.
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: I said, bring it.
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: Meek rak dorrah Pah-wran... Yelim cha ono kosst amojan... shay ta- hel ter-rah no'vala de-ram... aka'lu far che...
scene: 104  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (OPTICAL)

quote: Sisko to Bashir. Report.
Three dead, eight wounded -- four of them critically.
I need every able-bodied crewman at their post.
I won't keep anyone here a second longer than I have to.
She did pretty well for a first date, don't you think, captain?
I do, ensign.
Our phaser banks are fully charged, but we're down to only forty-five quantum torpedoes.
That'll have to do. How're you holding up, old man?
All things considered, I'd rather be on Risa.
That makes two of us.
Have you seen these reports? The Dominion has begun destroying Cardassian cities... millions of people are dying...
Captain -- we're approaching the Dominion defense perimeter.
Let's see what they have waiting for us. On screen.
Now we know...
scene: 112A INT. DEFIANT - BRIDGE - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: We have a problem.
Only one?
I'm afraid it's a rather large one. The cargo door is made of neutronium.
Then the explosives we brought aren't going to make a dent in it.
You see the problem.
What do we do?
I don't know, but I'm through hiding in basements...
I fail to see what's so funny, Garak...
Isn't it obvious? Here we are, ready to storm the castle... willing to sacrifice our lives in a noble effort to slay the Dominion beast in its lair and we can't even get inside the gate.
We could knock on the door and ask the Jem'Hadar to let us in...
Or have them send the Female Shape-shifter out to us.
Like I said, we have a problem...
But I've come to depend on having you here at my side.
Your advice has proven invaluable to the Dominion.
Very well. If you feel that the situation demands your presence on the front lines, I won't stand in your way. Knowing that you will be leading our troops into battle is very reassuring.
I still can't help but wonder.
Wonder what?
What's under that helmet?
A braver man than you. Though I do find the shrillness of his "voice"... tiresome.
Founder -- what's wrong?
I'm dying, that's what's wrong.
Perhaps if you were to rest for a while... revert to your natural state.
I haven't been able to change form in weeks. Ironic, isn't it? That I'm going to die as a Solid...
You're not going to die. You're a god.
My loyal Weyoun... the only Solid I've ever trusted.
I live only to serve you.
And you've served me well. (a beat, with some bitterness) I don't mind dying. It's knowing that my entire race is dying of the same illness and there's nothing I can do about it...
I would give my life to save yours.
I only wish it were that simple.
What if I were to give myself up? Pretend to be your prisoner.
scene: 116C EXT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - NIGHT

quote: They'd kill you on sight.
scene: 116C EXT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - NIGHT

quote: And us along with you.
scene: 116C EXT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - NIGHT

quote: The cargo door...
scene: 116C EXT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - NIGHT

quote: But I haven't done anything wrong! I'm not a traitor! Please -- just let me speak to the Founder --
scene: 116C EXT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - NIGHT

quote: No!
scene: 116C EXT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - NIGHT

quote: He's dead.
scene: 120  INT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - DAY

quote: Remember Damar's orders -- we stop for nothing.
scene: 120  INT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - DAY

quote: For Cardassia.
scene: 120  INT. DOMINION HEADQUARTERS - CARGO DOCK - DAY

quote: We have a security breach.
The guards will deal with it.
Is there a problem?
(not an easy admission) The guards... there're only a handful left in the building.
I sent the rest... ... to help eradicate the Cardassians.
(to two of the guards in the room) You two, get out there and see that no one gets through that door. (to the two remaining guards) You, stay here -- in case they fail.

We'll launch a three-pronged attack. The Romulans and our new Cardassian allies will engage the Jem'Hadar forces... the Klingons will target the Breen... and the Federation will take on the orbital weapon platforms. Any questions?
When do we go?
As soon as everyone's in position.
It will be a glorious battle.
But a costly one. Estimates project our casualty figures could be as high as forty percent.
And God knows how much higher they'll go once we send in our ground forces.
The Dominion's beaten and they know it -- but they're going to make us pay for every kilometer of that planet.
Yes, they will...
Godspeed, everyone.
Qa'pla!
Founder... perhaps we should consider moving to a safer location.
And where would that be?
Colonel Kira -- what a pleasant surprise.
The pleasure's all mine.
The Federation fleet has surrounded the planet.
(to the Female Shape-shifter) Contact the Jem'Hadar and the Breen, order their ships to stand down.
And order their troops on Cardassia to do the same.
I'll do no such thing.
Tell me, where's my old friend, Damar?
Damar's dead.
A pity.
He died helping to free Cardassia.
What's left of it.
I wish you hadn't done that. That was Weyoun's last clone.
I was hoping you'd say that.
(to the Female Shape-shifter) This war's over -- you've lost.
Have I? I think you'll find that neither the Jem'Hadar nor the Breen would agree with that assessment. They'll fight to the last man.
What will that accomplish?
Isn't it obvious?
You may win this war, colonel... but I promise you, by the time it's over, you will have lost so many ships... so many lives -- that your "victory" will taste as bitter as defeat.
I'm glad to find you in one piece, colonel.
Very glad.
What's your status?
Only three of us made it to the Briefing Room.
What about Damar?
He's dead.
Is your position secure?
I don't think the Jem'Hadar will attack -- they won't risk endangering the Founder. She's in pretty bad shape. She won't speak to anyone... just sits at her desk, deteriorating.
If she dies before ordering the Jem'Hadar to surrender...
They'll fight to the last man.
Captain, I should beam down there. The Founder will speak to me. Maybe I can reason with her.
You haven't had much success with her in the past.
I'd still like to try. Think of the lives it could save.
(turning to viewscreen) Commander -- tell the Founder that Odo would like to pay her a visit.
And now we begin the most important part of the ceremony.
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Tarna pur-ono ull-kess pah-ran. lano ka'la bo'shar lanu.
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: After you.
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: I'm honored.
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Now you.
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Why?
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: The Pah-wraiths demand a sacrifice. Someone worthy of them... Who better than you?
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: (to the abyss, re: Dukat) I offer you this life as nourishment... to feed your hunger and fuel the fires that will set you free. Kosst Amojan... I am yours, now and forever.
scene: 147  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Nerys...
It's been a while. (sotto, re: the Female Shape-shifter) Watch yourself. I don't trust her.
But you trust me, don't you?
Of course.
That's all I need to know.
Constable.
Garak.
You're looking well, Odo.
Thank you for seeing me.

It's always good to see you. But I have no intention of surrendering my forces. If I did, it would be a sign of weakness... an invitation to the Solids to cross into the Gamma Quadrant and destroy the Great Link.
Believe me, I'm well aware that the Federation has its flaws... but a desire for conquest isn't one of them.
And what of the Klingons and the Romulans... can you make the same claim for them?
The Klingon and Romulan Empires are in no shape to wage a war against anyone... besides, the Federation wouldn't allow it.
The Dominion has spent the last two years trying to destroy the Federation... and now you're asking me to put our fate in their hands?
Yes.
I can't do that, Odo. I don't share your faith in Solids.
Perhaps I can change your mind (holding out his hand) Link with me.
Odo -- what are you doing?
I'm afraid I can't Link with you. This disease prevents me from changing form.
If we Link, I think I can cure you.
That's a very bad idea, Constable.
He's right.
Nerys -- I know what I'm doing. (to the Female Shape-shifter) Take my hand.
And if you do cure me? What will you ask in return?
All I ask is that you Link with me.
I'm warning you, Odo...
Lower your weapon, Garak.
I don't think so...
I said, put it down.
Why?
Because I trust Odo.
Move away, Constable.
That won't be necessary. (to the Female Shape-shifter) Will it?
If you'll step aside, I'll order the Jem'Hadar to cease fire.
(re: the Female Shape-shifter) May I suggest securing her in a containment field.
Don't worry. She won't try to escape. She's agreed to stand trial for what she's done.
I would've thought she'd insist on going back to the Gamma Quadrant to cure her people.
There's no need for that. I'm going in her place.
For how long?
(as gently as possible) Nerys... it's time I rejoined the Great Link.
This is a moment worth savoring. To victory -- hard fought and well earned.
Something wrong?
Suddenly, I'm not thirsty.
Neither am I.
Before you waste too many tears... remember, those are Cardassians lying dead at your feet... (re: the devastation) The Bajorans would call this poetic justice...
That still doesn't mean I have to drink a toast over their bodies.
Eight hundred million dead...
And the casualty reports are still coming in... Aren't you going to congratulate me, doctor? My exile is officially over. I've returned home. Or rather, to what's left of it...
I know things must look bleak to you right now, Garak...

Some may say that we've gotten exactly what we deserve... after all, we're not exactly "innocent," are we? And I'm not just talking about the Bajoran occupation... our entire history is one of arrogant aggression. We collaborated with the Dominion... betrayed the Alpha Quadrant... there's no doubt about it, we're guilty as charged.
We both know the Cardassians are a strong people... they'll survive... Cardassia will survive.

Doctor, please -- spare me your insufferable Federation optimism. Of course it will survive... but not the Cardassia I knew. We had a rich and ancient culture -- our literature, music, art were second to none. And now, so much of it is lost... So many of our best people... our most gifted minds...
I'm sorry, Garak. I didn't mean..
Quite all right, doctor. You've been a good friend. I'm going to miss our lunches together.
I'm sure we'll see each other again.
I'd like to think so. But who can say... we live in uncertain times.
The war between the Dominion and the Federation Alliance is now over.
Four hundred years ago, a victorious general spoke the following words at the end of another costly war...
"Today the guns are silent. A great tragedy has ended...
We have known the bitterness of defeat and the exultation of triumph, and from both we have learned there can be no turning back. We must go forward to preserve in peace what we've won in war."
It's up to you now, Odo.
You're coming to Vic's tonight, right?
I will be there. But I will not dance.
Who's asking?
Commander Worf.
Can you spare a moment?
We've been discussing your plans for the future.
I wasn't aware I had plans.
Commander, how would you feel about being named Federation Ambassador to Kronos?
I am not a diplomat.
And I am not a politician. But sometimes, fate plays cruel tricks on us. Come, Worf -- Kronos needs you. And what's more, I need you.
You helped him become Chancellor... you can't very well turn your back on him now.
My first loyalty is to you, captain.
I'll probably regret this in the morning, but if this is something you want, then by all means...
It has been a great honor to serve with you, sir.
The honor was all mine. DEEP SPACE NINE: "What You... " - REV. 04/26/99 - ACT EIGHT 88.
I accept.
Excellent.
An ambassador who will go targ hunting with me. Maybe being chancellor won't be so bad after all.
Congratulations, Worf.
When will you be going?
Soon.
You could come back, you know... after you've cured your people.
I could...
But you're not going to do that, are you?
Nerys... You know my feelings for you will never change... but my people need me.
They need to know what I know... learn what I've learned from living among the Solids. It's the only way they will ever learn to trust you.
You don't have to justify your decision, Odo. There's only one thing I ask.
Name it.
I want to go back with you to your homeworld. That way, we can spend your last few days as a Solid together.
I'd like that. I'd like that very much.
Hey, pallie -- if you're here for another game of "go fish," I'm a little busy right now...
Actually, I'm here for the-end-of- the-war-good-bye-Chief-O'Brien- good-bye-Odo-good-bye-Worf-party.
At the bar.
... I'm serious, Miles -- I envy you. Going back to Earth... a chance to enjoy paradise again...
Any idea where you're going to live?
Not yet. Keiko and I are still mulling over a few possibilities.
Have you considered Minsk?
I'm not sure that's on our list.
New Orleans is a wonderful city.
Jadzia loved Rio.
I've heard nice things about Paris.
Minsk.
You certainly have a lot of choices.
Too many.
Minsk.
Wherever you decide... I'm sure you and Keiko will be very happy.
Look, Julian... I know that Earth isn't exactly around the corner, but I still expect you to visit me.
I intend to.
Imagine, you and me taking a little trip to Texas.
Standing side by side in front of the Alamo...
The real Alamo. You see? It's going to be great.
Absolutely. Great.
I don't see what's so great about it. Earth's nothing more than a rotating ball of boredom. If you ask me, you'd be better off staying right here -- -- and that goes for you two as well.
Don't tell me you're getting sentimental, Quark...
Me? Not a chance. I just don't like change, that's all.
Well you better get used to it, because things are going to be pretty different around here.
To the best crew any captain ever had.

This may be the last night that we're all together, but no matter what the future holds, no matter how far we travel, a part of us -- a very important part -- will always remain here... on Deep Space Nine.
Ladies and gentlemen --
This is a very special night for some friends of mine. They've been together a long time. But like the man said, nothing lasts forever. So... Gang -- this one's from the heart.
Dorra tolka bre-tri pah-wran...
scene: 173  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (FORMERLY 164)

quote: Dorra tolka o-chen... Dorra tolka wey-sah shay-hal...
scene: 173  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (FORMERLY 164)

quote: Ko'se nusso ma'kora kajani... preen dah-ono uka'lamor-eye anu -- Kosst Amojan -- I await you! Come to me!
scene: 173  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (FORMERLY 164)

quote: No...
scene: 173  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN (FORMERLY 164)

quote: Ben - what's wrong?
I understand now...
Understand what?
What I have to do. What I was meant to do. Kas -- I have to go...
Go? Where?
To Bajor. To the fire caves.
I'll go with you.
No...
I have to do this alone.
Dad...
Jake?
You've got to come back to the station with me.
How'd you get here?
It doesn't matter. If you stay here, you'll die.
He's right, Ben.
Our baby's going to need a father.
You're not real -- neither one of you...
But what we're saying is real.
If you try to stop the Restoration, you'll be killed.
You can't defeat the Kosst Amojan. They're too powerful...
Come home, Dad -- you don't belong here. It's not your fight.
I know what you're doing...
We're trying to help you.
No, you're trying to make me doubt myself... I won't let you.
Dad... please!
Ben... don't.
Did you really think the Pah- wraiths would choose you to be their Emissary?
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: (dripping with contempt) Soon the Pah-wraiths will burn across Bajor, the Celestial Temple, the Alpha Quadrant... Can you picture it?
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: A universe in flames, burning brightly for all eternity.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: The Prophets have sent me a gift.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Their beloved Emissary... sent forth like an avenging angel to slay the demon.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: I should've known the demon would be you.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Go on -- kill me if you can.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Come now, captain... you'll have to do better than that.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: This is too easy.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: That's right. Come closer.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Satisfied? Now bow to me.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: I said bow --
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: You're pathetic.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Am I? Then why are you the one on your knees?
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: First the Dominion... now the Pah-wraiths... you have a talent for picking the losing side.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Benjamin... please. We've known each other too long. And since this is the last time we'll ever be together -- let's try to speak honestly. In the past, we've both had our share of victories and defeats... but now it's time to resolve our differences and face the ultimate truth -- I've won, and you've lost.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: The Pah-wraiths aren't going to conquer anything. Not Bajor. Not the Celestial Temple. And certainly not the Alpha Quadrant.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: And who's going to stop us?
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: I am.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: You? You can't even stand up.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Then I'll stop you --
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Are you still here?
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Emissary, the book...
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Farewell, Adami.
scene: 190  INT. BAJORAN FIRE CAVES - MAIN CAVERN

quote: Sarah? Are you here? What happened?
The Emissary has completed his task.
But the Pah-wraiths...
You've returned them to their prison within the fire caves.
The book was the key, wasn't it?
To a door that can never be opened again.
And Dukat? Is he dead?
He's where he belongs... with the Pah-wraiths. Your time of trial has ended. You need to rest now.
I intend to. As soon as I get back to Deep Space Nine.
That won't be necessary...
You're with us now.
We found the captain's runabout orbiting Bajor.
But when we scanned the fire caves, there was no sign of him.
Here. Tarkalian tea -- very soothing.
Better keep it coming.
You're not calling off the search yet, are you?
Not until we find your father.
What about Kendra Province, where he bought that land. Maybe he went there for some reason...
Colonel Kira and Chief O'Brien have just completed another scan of the planet. As far as they can tell, he's not there. DEEP SPACE NINE: "What You... " - REV. 04/26/99 - ACT NINE 105.
Something's happened to Ben. Something bad... I can feel it. The Prophets warned us.
Hello? Is anyone here?
Ben? Is that you?
Kasidy.
Ben! I was so worried... (looking around at the whiteness surrounding them) Where are we?
The Celestial Temple.
This is scaring me -- let's go home.
I can't. Not now.
Why not?
Oh, God... this is it, isn't it? The sorrow the Prophets warned us about...
It's difficult to explain... it isn't linear...
What isn't?

My life... my destiny... the Prophets saved me, Kas -- I'm their Emissary, and they still have a great deal for me to do. But first, there's a lot I have to learn... things only the Prophets can teach me.
When will you be back?
It's hard to say. Time doesn't exist here. It could be a year. It could be yesterday. But I will be back.
I'll be waiting.
Kas? Can you hear me?
You seemed pretty far away for a second...
I was talking to your father.
Are you sure you want to leave without saying good-bye?
Quite sure. I'm not very good at good-byes.
A lot of people are going to be disappointed.
If they don't know how I feel about them now, a few parting words won't make any difference.
I knew it!
When I saw the two of you slip out of the holosuite, I said to myself, "That no-good, misanthropic, cantankerous, changeling is trying to sneak off the station without anyone noticing."
That was the idea.
Well, it's not going to happen.
Apparently not.
So now that I'm here... isn't there something you want to say to me?
Such as?
Such as, "Good-bye, you certainly were a worthy adversary" -- or maybe something with the words "mutual respect" in it...
No.
No? What do you mean "no?"
There's nothing I want to say to you.
You're telling me that after all these years... after all we've been through, you're not even going to say good-bye to me?
That's right.
Nerys... I'll be on the Runabout.
I guess that's it then...
Don't take it so hard, Quark --
Hard? What are you talking about? That man loves me -- couldn't you see? It was written all over his back.
The Link... it looks different.
They're dying.
You should go to them.
Nerys, tell the captain... and the others... I'm going to miss them.
Even Quark?
Even Quark. (looking into her eyes) But most of all...
I know.
What's that for?
You always said I looked good in a tuxedo.
You do.
Then that's how I want you to remember me...
I'll remember this moment forever. I'll remember all our moments...
As will I.
Good-bye, Nerys.
Today's duty roster, colonel.
Nice work. And congratulations on your promotion, lieutenant.
Thank you, sir. I guess putting me in for promotion was one of Captain Sisko's last official acts.
I'm sure he's very proud of you, Nog.
I'd like to think so, sir.
Now about the cargo inventories...
I'll get right on it.

... the thing of it is, I thought the cardiac apoptosis would lead to terminal coronary failure, but in actuality -- and here's the really interesting part -- the apoptosis was part of the normal cardiac renewal process.
What do you think?
I think maybe tonight, after dinner, we could go to Quark's... spend some time in a holosuite.
I wouldn't mind a little trip to Vegas...
Actually, I was thinking about the Alamo.
We can't go there.
Why not?

That was something Miles and I did. But we could try a new program I got... The Battle of Thermopylae. You know, where a small band of Spartans led by King Leonidas defended a mountain pass against the vast Persian army.
What happened then?
For two days, the Spartans put up a heroic struggle.
Until they were wiped out.
How'd you know?
Lucky guess. I take it we'll be the Spartans?
Fighting to the last man.
Just like the Alamo.
Exactly.
Have you ever talked to a counselor about these annihilation fantasies?
You think I should?
I'll set up a session for tomorrow.
But tonight...
Tonight we defend the pass.
That'll be ten strips of latinum.
I know, I know -- I'll put it on your tab.
Don't worry, it's guaranteed to grow hair within a week. Though if you ask me, that dome of yours is hairy enough. Besides, hasn't there been enough change around here already?
Quark!
You mind explaining this?
That's this week's betting pool...
You're taking bets on who's going to be the new Kai?
It's a wide open field. Just between you and me, the smart money's on Vedek Ungtae.
Well just between you and me -- all bets are off.
What are you talking about?
As of this moment, betting pools of any kind are illegal on this station. I catch someone placing a bet, and you'll spend fifteen days in a holding cell. Is that clear?
Fifteen days... can I bring my own pillow?
Quark!
It's clear, it's clear.
It better be.
It's like I said, the more things change, the more they stay the same.
By the way, your gagh has arrived.
My what? Oh, no.
Oh, yes. And it's waiting for you in Cargo Bay Two.
Your gagh?
Jadzia ordered it. She was planning a party for Martok's birthday next week.
How much gagh did she order?
Fifty-one cases.
Each containing a different variety.
There are varieties of gagh?
Oh, yes. I can remember what each one tastes like... and the way they... move when you swallow them. Torgud gagh wiggles. Filden gagh squirms. Meshta gagh jumps...
You all right?
Are you all right?
Me?
You've barely said three words. Something on your mind?
Oh. Just... can't wait to see Miles.
Let me guess -- you have a holosuite appointment -- defending the Alamo again?
You know me too well.
When's his transport get in?
Half an hour.
Bithool gagh has feet.
Flush it out the airlock. All of it.
Environmental regulations.
Why don't you give it to Martok?
He'd insist on sharing it with me as a point of honor. Wistan gagh is packed in targ blood.
I have to go now. I'll see you later.
I think I'll head out as well.
Give my regards to Santa Anna.
What!
Miles asked me not to say anything. But I haven't heard from him in three days... and he wasn't on this morning's transport. I think something may have happened to him.
He told me he was going home to visit his father.
Well... he may have implied he was going to visit his father, but he didn't actually say that--
Doctor, please.
Yes, sir.
So where is he?
The last message I got said that he was still in New Sydney, and that he was following up on some promising leads.
He's not a detective! He's an engineer -- he's my chief engineer and now he's missing!
So tell me about this woman he's supposed to be looking for.
She's the widow of Liam Bilby. You remember Bilby?
The man O'Brien befriended during that undercover operation last year?
Yes, sir. Miles still feels responsible for his death. He's kept in touch with Bilby's widow ever since... and when she dropped out of sight three weeks ago he got worried and decided to go find her.
And now they're both missing. Perfect.

In his defense sir, he did try to go through official channels first. But... the authorities on New Sydney weren't very helpful and since it's a non-Federation world, Starfleet doesn't have jurisdiction...
So he decided to turn into a one- man police force.
Yes, sir.
New Sydney. That's in the Sappora System, right?
Right.
I want a written report, detailing everything you know about this woman, O'Brien's plan to find her, and anything else you've neglected to mention.
Aye, sir. May I ask what you're going to do?
No you may not. I want that report on my desk within the hour.
... and since your family still lives in the Sappora System, I thought they might have a few contacts on New Sydney.
I'm sure they do. My mother's one of the more important business leaders in the system.
Your personnel file says she owns the fifth largest pergium mining facility in the entire sector...
Actually, it's the sixth now. The Ferengi discovered a large deposit on Timor Two a few years ago. My mother nearly had a heart attack when she found out we'd been knocked out of the top five.
Do you think she'd be willing to intervene with the local authorities -- get them to look into what happened to the chief?
I'm sure she would.
That's the first good news I've heard all day.
Something wrong?
No. Yes. I don't know. I haven't talked to my mother in almost six months.
Oh.

The last time I saw her was just after I was joined. She came to visit me on Trill. I was still a little... confused. When she walked into my room, I put on a big smile, looked her straight in the eye and said, "Hi, Mom, it's me -- Curzon!" Things kinda went downhill from there.
I'm sure she understood what you were going through. You weren't prepared to be joined -- she couldn't blame you for being confused.
She didn't. Not really. But she did want me to come home to recuperate. We had a disagreement.
Not for the first time... ?
No, not for the first time.
If there was any other way, I wouldn't ask you to do this.
It's all right. My family problems aren't as important as finding the chief. I'll call my mother right away.
Thanks, old man.
Anytime.
We've been worried about you.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: I'm all right. Really. And I'm a lot more sure of who I am than the last time you saw me.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Well, that's a relief. I'd hate to have to start calling you Curzon.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: I... I've been promoted.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Oh?
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Lieutenant junior grade Ezri Dax at your service.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Ezri... Dax.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: The symbiont name always replaces the family name of the... new host. It's traditional.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Of course it is. I haven't been away from Trill that long. The important thing is you're doing well.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Mother, I've called because I need your help. One of our officers -- Miles O'Brien -- went to New Sydney three weeks ago and now he's missing. Captain Sisko was wondering if maybe you could--
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: I'll do everything I can.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Thank you.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Now. When are you coming home?
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: I don't know when I can get away...
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Ezri, you haven't been home in three years.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: I know... but with the war on and everything...
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Ezri Tigan... Dax. Tell your commanding officer that your mother is a very difficult woman and that she refuses to help look for Mister O'Brien unless you're allowed to come home right away.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Mother, no. Don't put me in this --
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Good-bye, Ezri. I'll see you when you get here.
scene: 6    INT. EZRI'S BEDROOM - CLOSE ON VIEWSCREEN (OPTICAL)

quote: Use twenty milligrams at the first sign of spacesickness. If you wait any longer, you'll regret it.
So will the other passengers.
Everything Starfleet knows about Bilby and his widow.
What about your report?
It's in there -- it's the one with Captain Sisko's bootprints all over it.
Don't worry, I'm sure you'll be out of the doghouse by the time I get back.
Let's hope so.
Would it help if I said that as someone who isn't especially close to his parents -- I do sympathize.

I'm about to present my family with a whole new Ezri. And to tell you the truth, they didn't know what to make of the old one. But, thanks for trying, Julian. I'll let you know as soon as I find out anything about Miles.
Have a safe trip.
Zee!
Norvo...
I can't believe you're really here.
Neither can I.
You cut your hair.
It kept getting in my eyes... You like it?
It'll take a little getting used to.
I think you've just summed up my whole visit. Is this yours?
Mom insisted on hanging it in here. I hate it.
Why?
The composition is puerile and obvious. The colors belong on a child's toy and the technique is laughable.
But other than that...
It's perfect.
Welcome home, little girl.
Hi, Janel.
Do I have to take a sonic shower before I get a hug?
It's good to see you.
You too.
What happened here?
She cut it. I think it brings out her eyes... gives her more of a classic look.
It's cute.
Mom's on her way. She said to give you the preliminary police report on your friend.
Have they found anything?
Not yet...
... but they have a few leads.
I hope you appreciate how much trouble she's going to. She called in a lot of favors from the New Sydney police.
Of course I appreciate it.
How long are you staying?
I'm... not sure yet.
She's not going to be here a minute longer than she has to, you know that.
We're in the middle of a war, Janel. I have responsibilities back on DS Nine.
There's always something.
Hello, Mother.
I hate your hair...
Have you eaten?
Not yet.
Good. Because I've got Korella working on a very special dinner. Have you taken care of Lorkin?
I was just about to contact him.
I want him paid and gone by the time dinner's ready.
Yes, ma'am.
And what about that third quarter review I asked for?
I'm still working on it.
You've been working on it for a week now.
I... miscalculated some of the revenues. I had to redo them.
I know you don't like doing the bookkeeping, but I really need that review as soon as possible, all right? Good.
I want to show you the new solarium. I had all the tile brought in from Andoria and then hand-painted by this charming old man I met on a trip to the Hovarian Cluster...
Have Mister Lorkin report to the main house.
Yes, sir.
Why're you getting rid of Lorkin?
That broken waveguide in fourteen three-A is going to cost us a thousand bars of latinum a day. Mother thinks it's the result of sloppy maintenance.
What do you think?
I think a brand new waveguide doesn't just "break."
You mean... Bokar was behind it... ?
He's trying to send us a message. The Orion Syndicate doesn't take no for an answer.
Maybe we should tell Mother...
No. I can deal with Bokar.
I don't know...
Relax. Everything is going to be all right.
... Jadzia considered Kira one of her best friends, and I'm starting to think of her the same way. We spend a lot of time together.
She didn't have any trouble adjusting to having a... "new Dax" in her life?
No more than anyone else. I don't think any of them were expecting another Dax to walk into their lives.
Hmm. Did any of them wonder if you --
Whatever happened to that young man on the Destiny you were so interested in? Lieutenant... something?

Brinner Finok. He was an Ensign. I did talk to him after I was joined... once. I don't think we're right for each other anymore. He reminds me too much of my son, Gran. It makes me a little uncomfortable to be around him now.
Sorry. He reminds me of Audrid's son, Gran. I'm still sorting out my pronouns.
I'm sure all joined Trills go through this.
No, just me.

Nothing simple for Ezri. There're times when the computer asks me to identify myself and I have to think about what to say. Worse yet, there're days when I wake up and I don't even know if I'm a man or a woman until I pull back the covers.
I also have an unfortunate tendency to ramble...

Don't be embarrassed. It's not your fault. You should've gone through years of training before receiving a symbiont. It wasn't fair of them to join you to Dax just because you happened to be the only Trill on board. It's no surprise to me that you're having trouble sorting out eight lifetimes' worth of memories and experiences.
It can be a little... overwhelming at times.
I'm sure. But don't worry. We'll take care of you... won't we?
Absolutely.
Of course.
That's... good to know. But I think I've got things under control.
Ezri... you always were too proud for your own good.
Come in, Zee.
How'd you know it was me?
No one else would bother with the chime.
I see some things never change.
Here...
... have a seat.
How many of these are yours?
All the bad ones.
When did you become such a harsh critic of your own work?
Just being realistic. It's amateurish. I know that. it says so right there --
Saurian brandy?
Sure.
Oh. I should probably get a clean one.
I don't care.
Norvo, this doesn't mean--
To my sister -- a shining angel in a dark sky.
All right. The Andorian Academy rejected your application... that doesn't mean your work is "amateurish." There are other art schools.
It's the best.
You shouldn't just give up.
I'm not very good, Zee. I never was. All this... it's an indulgence. Just like my other "hobbies" -- poetry... music...
I can't concentrate. My mind wanders. I don't have the discipline it takes to succeed.
Those are Mother's words -- I know, because I've heard them too. She wasn't right about me and she's not right about you either.
I'm fine with the way things have turned out. Really. Besides, they need me here.
To do what? The family bookkeeping? Norvo, you could do so much more.
I'm not trying to make you feel bad. I just want you to know that I still believe in you...
Thanks.
Good-night.
'Night.
I hope you're satisfied. Have you seen Norvo today?
No.
Well, maybe you should. You'll find him lying in bed with a hangover. When I woke up this morning he was passed out in the entry room. Evidently he spent most of the night doing this...
You think it's funny?
I think it's funny that you think he did this because of me. He's not happy here, can't you see that?
That's nonsense.
Mother, he's defacing his own artwork -- work that you insisted on displaying after he objected.
I'm proud of him... I'm trying to encourage him.
But all you've done is make him feel trapped and powerless.
You've barely spent one night in this house and you think you can analyze our entire family. You don't know your brother anymore, Ezri. Norvo is a fragile young man who needs to be cared for.
He's a grown man who needs his freedom. You're smothering him.
How dare you come in here and tell me how to be a mother? What do you know about raising children?
I have three -- no, four lifetimes worth of memories about raising children.
I have worked and sacrificed for each one of you for over --
-- thirty years. Not now!
Sorry to interrupt, but...
Miles!
Ezri? What're you doing here?
This is my home... ... my mother.
It's a pleasure to meet you, Mister O'Brien.
Can you... ?
He wasn't very friendly when we located him.
Neither were you.
If you'll excuse me... we're having a problem with a drill down in twenty-four B.
(to Fuchida, re: cuts & bruises) Did you do this?
Just the one on the jaw. The rest he got thanks to the Orion Syndicate.
Did you find anything on Bilby's wife?
I found her. She's dead.
Thank you. The DNA scan confirmed that the body was Morica's. She'd been dead for at least six weeks.
Do you have any idea what the cause of death was?
No.
Yes. The cause of death was the Orion Syndicate.
There's no evidence of that. It could've been an accident.
She "accidently" hit herself in the head and accidently threw herself into the river?
We pull a dozen bodies a month out of that river. You think they're all Syndicate murders?
If they're anything like this one -- yes! And if you hadn't interfered, I might've proved she was murdered.

If we hadn't "interfered" you'd be dead. When your mother called us, we already had word that a Starfleet Intelligence operative was trying to infiltrate the Syndicate. It didn't take long to realize it was your friend. We found him being beaten up by a pair of Nausicaans.
They were just trying to scare me.
Why?
Exactly! Why would they be trying to scare me? Because I'd found the body of Morica Bilby and they didn't want me tracing her murder back to them.
The Syndicate would never kill the widow of an operative. The only thing that holds them together is this "loyalty" they show to operatives and their families.
Maybe they're not as loyal as you think.
Mrs. Tigan, please contact us if there's anything else we can do for you.
Thank you. I will.
Ezri, why don't you show Mister O'Brien to one of the guest rooms... let him clean up and have something to eat.
... so that tip led me to the river. I searched the south bank for about three hours before I found her. The organic solvents in the water had partially decomposed the body... but it was her.
I'm sorry, Chief. I wish there was something more I could do.
You could put in a good word for me with Captain Sisko.
It may take a lot of good words... but I'll talk to him.
Mister O'Brien, how are you feeling?
Fine, ma'am. I've eaten enough for a week.
Glad to hear it. I understand you're an engineer.
That's right.
He's not a mining engineer.
We have a problem with a trans- sonic drill that no one on my staff seems capable of fixing.
I would appreciate it very much if you would be so kind as to take a look at it.
Now? Mother, he needs some rest.
How much rest do you require, Mister O'Brien?
Actually... I feel fine...
Thank you, Mister O'Brien. I'll see you at dinner.
I'm sorry about this. Our mother is a force of nature.
It's all right. It'll do me good to get my hands on a problem I can solve for a change. Lead on.
Good morning.
Good afternoon.
Oh.
Mother... is not going to be happy about this...
Don't worry. You're out of the line of fire for the moment -- she's busy torturing Janel and Miles.
Miles... ? Oh, your friend. They found him?
He's fine.
Great. That's really great, Zee. Does that mean you're leaving?
Not right away. Let's talk about you... more specifically, about what you did last night.
Oh, yeah... last night. What can I say? When I get drunk, I become an art critic.
Do you regret what you did?
Not really. I never liked those pieces anyway.
So what are you feeling?
I am feeling like I don't want to be analyzed by my sister.
Sorry. It's what I do.
This situation isn't that complex, Zee. I'm wallowing in self-pity and acting out my frustrations by throwing tantrums.
All right Doctor Norvo, if that's your diagnosis, what's your prescription?
Mother disapproves of suicide -- all that blood on the carpets.
Not funny.
Best I can do with a hangover.
Norvo... what would happen if you left with me tomorrow?
What do you mean?
I mean, what would happen if you went back to Deep Space Nine with me?
Mother would go insane.
Forget about her for the moment.
I can't just... pick up and leave.
It doesn't have to be a permanent move. Think of it as a vacation... a break from all this. Some time to clear your head, that's all.
I don't know if I can leave all this on Janel's shoulders...
Janel can handle it.
It's not that simple... there're some things going on that are... complicated.
Like what?
Things... with the company...
No offense, Norvo, but you're not exactly holding the company together. Mother can pay a real accountant to do the work she's given you.
I don't know, Zee...
Think about it?
You're right. The problem's in the secondary input transtator.
But the transtator checks out perfectly...
I'm sure it does. But it's the wrong transtator for this drill.
What?
You need a fifty-two J, this is a fifty-two L.
It says fifty-two J...
I know. But it's definitely an L. It must've been accidently mislabeled.
Or deliberately...
Another equipment failure?
Perhaps if you hadn't dismissed Mister Lorkin, this wouldn't have happened.
He was dismissed on my Mother's personal order.
Then we'll have to find a way of changing her mind, won't we?
Who's your new mechanic, Janel?
This is Mister O'Brien. He's a friend of the family.
That wouldn't be Chief O'Brien would it?
How'd you know that?
I have several friends in the New Sydney Police. I heard they recently rescued a Starfleet chief named O'Brien from an unpleasant situation.
That's me. I don't believe I caught your name.
Thadial Bokar. I'm a commodities broker, attempting to establish business ties with the illustrious Tigan family.
Could you excuse us for a moment, Chief. Mister Bokar and I have some business to discuss -- thank you for your help. I'll have a new transtator installed right away.
Glad to do it.
Sabotaging our drills isn't going to convince me to do more business with the Orion Syndicate.
We'll argue about that later. We have more immediate concerns. O'Brien is with Starfleet Intelligence.
No, he's not. He works with my sister on Deep Space Nine.
That may be what he wants you to think. But why was he on New Sydney trying to infiltrate the Syndicate?
He was looking for some woman.
"Some woman." Do you know the name of this woman?
No.
Well I do. Her name was Morica Bilby.
What... ?
Now, of course, I haven't heard from Morica Bilby in quite some time... rumor has it that she's dead, but I wouldn't know anything about that.
What I do know is that Chief O'Brien should leave this system. Quickly. Before something happens to him.
So you're not leaving until tomorrow?
Probably. It really depends on Ezri.
Why?
She's my superior officer. I go when she goes. Besides, I'm not looking forward to seeing Captain Sisko. He's got a boot with my name on it.
This isn't a good time for guests. There's a lot of work to do. The quicker you're on your way, the better.
Your brother seems eager to get rid of us.
Don't mind him. He's under a lot of pressure.
Hmm. Do you know a man named Thadial Bokar -- says he's a commodities broker?
No. I make it a point to know as little as possible about the family business. Why?

He came down to the mine to talk with Janel while I was working on the drill... there was something about him... it reminded me of when I was working undercover with the Orion Syndicate... the way they dealt with "civilians."
You think this Mister Bokar is a member of the Syndicate?
It's just a feeling. But it's a pretty strong feeling.
We should tell Janel.
I think Janel knows. I realize I'm not giving you a lot of hard evidence here, lieutenant -- but Janel seems like a man who's being pressured by the Syndicate.

He's experiencing sudden equipment "breakdowns," work stoppages, mysterious "accidents" -- it's the way the Syndicate extorts money from legitimate companies. "You do business with us or we'll ruin you."
Janel is not someone who's easily intimidated. And my mother, she'd burn this place to the ground before she'd do business with the Syndicate.
There's one way to find out. Do you have access to the company's financial records?
I knew your family had some money, but I had no idea...
We're rich, I know. It's my mother's doing. She built Tigan mining from the ground up... surveyed the planet, she even dug the first mining shaft.
You must be very proud of her.
I am. She's a... remarkable woman.
What about your father? Is he involved with the business?
No. He... has other interests that keep him away from home for extended periods. I don't know why I'm sugar- coating it. He stays away because he doesn't want to be around my mother.
I'm sorry to hear that.

It's all right. I can't believe I still feel the need to make excuses for either of them. You know, if there's one thing being joined does... it makes you look at things as they are, instead of the way you want them to be. After eight lifetimes, you start to develop a pretty low tolerance for denial. And there's a lot of denial in this house. But we do have money...
What would you do on Deep Space Nine?
Take a... vacation... clear my head.
Clear your head of what?
I don't know.
Then why do you need a vacation?
I guess, I don't, really. But it'd be nice to spend some time with Ezri...
You're spending time with her now, aren't you?
Yes...
We're ready to open twenty-five beta.
I'll be right there. Norvo, this is a bad time for you to take a vacation. We have far too much work to do. Have you finished that review?
Almost...
Then maybe you should get to it.
Yes, ma'am.
Let's go.
Now I remember why I never went into the family business... all these contracts and invoices and balance sheets and shipping orders... I feel like I'm trapped in some kind of Ferengi nightmare.
What? What is it?
I don't know.
What's going on here?
What do you mean?
Did you come here to find me or to prevent me from finding the truth?
I don't know what you're talking about. So maybe you better tell me, Chief.
The connection between the Orion Syndicate and your family... is Morica Bilby. She was on the company's payroll when she died. Did you know that?
No. Of course not.
Well, someone in your family knew... and since they haven't mentioned it, they obviously don't want us to know...
Are you suggesting... ?
I'm not suggesting anything, but you have to face the possibility that someone in your family may have been involved in her death.
There. Nine months ago, Morica Bilby shows up on the payroll as a "shipping consultant."
Five bars of latinum a week... "for services rendered." What services... ?
There's no cross-reference... no indication of what she was doing for the company...
Whatever it was, she must've been doing a good job -- look here. Her salary increases to ten bars a week... then to twenty... then thirty...
The last payment entry is six weeks ago.
The day before she was killed.
Who's in charge of the payroll?
My mother... ultimately. But she's turned over most of the day to day operations to Janel... and Norvo's been doing the bookkeeping.
Any one of them could have known about the payments to Morica. Or all of them.
Lieutenant... we need to show this to the authorities on New Sydney.
Not yet. Not until I find out what happened. That's an order.
Aye, sir.
Why was this woman on our payroll?
We were returning a favor.
To whom?
To the Orion Syndicate...
And what... "favor" did they do for us?

Remember when the Ferengis opened up the Timor Two mine... and there was a ten point drop in the price of pergium? That came at a bad moment. We were overextended on some loans... our cash reserves were depleted... and a Jem'Hadar raid destroyed an entire shipment before it reached the refinery on Rigel Four.
So you turned to the Syndicate!
They came to me! They offered us a way out and I took it! I did what I had to do. And I don't remember you asking a lot of questions when our cash problems were resolved overnight.
Because I trusted you -- obviously that was a mistake.
What about Morica?

About a month after Bokar arranged the loan, he came to me and said it was time to return the favor. There was a woman who needed a job... with a salary, but without any actual work involved. He said she was the widow of one of their associates and they needed to take care of her.
I didn't feel that I was in a position to say no. So I started making the payments. No one would've been the wiser if Norvo had altered the payroll records like I asked him
You dragged your little brother into this?

You're the one who said nothing's more important than the company! Well, that's all I was thinking about -- the company! You dumped it in my lap and I saved it! So don't start complaining now! if it weren't for me, we would have been finished!
Don't try to rationalize what you've --
All right! All right! We can discuss who saved what later. Right now, we have to concentrate on what happened to Morica. The payroll records show a steady increase in her payments. Why?
She wasn't "happy" with her salary. She said the Syndicate had promised her a comfortable living and that she wasn't "comfortable" on what we were paying her.
How did she die?
I don't know.
Janel, if you had anything to do with this, now's the time to --
What are you saying? That I had her killed?
I'm asking.
Mother, he wouldn't have killed her!
Stay out of this.
Listen to me... I'll get the best solicitor on New Sydney for you, but you have to tell me the truth...
I didn't kill her.
Why don't I believe you, Janel? Why don't I believe that this woman just happened to die at the very moment she was pressuring you for more money?
Why won't you listen to him -- he didn't do it!
I tried to reason with her. But she was... very angry. Angry at the Syndicate. Angry at us. Even angry at her husband for getting himself killed.

I didn't go there to kill her, Zee. I really didn't. But she wouldn't listen to me. She started yelling... said our family was no different than the Syndicate. That we were all liars and cheats. Then... I suddenly realized that if she were dead... all our problems would go away.
Norvo...
I took care of it. You always said I was too weak to... handle the tough ones. But I'm not. I proved it. I handled a problem that you couldn't. I handled it.
I need to... inspect the... ore samples from fifty-three C. We have to make a decision on... whether to open up a new--
Janel. Forget about the mine. It doesn't matter. I want you to listen to me. After Norvo's... trial is over, you need to go.
Go where?
It doesn't matter. Just go. Find another life for yourself. Trust me -- you'll be happier.
They've taken Norvo. I talked to Dad a little while ago. He said he's coming home. I'm going to stay on New Sydney for the trial... then head back to D.S. Nine.
This isn't my fault, is it Ezri? I didn't do this, did I?
This is not my bar bill.
You're a member of the House of Martok, right? You don't want it to get out that you're refusing to honor the debts incurred by your own House, do you?
Always a pleasure to do business with the House of Martok.
Mind if I join you?
When'd you get back?
Last night. Norvo was sentenced to thirty years.
I wish I could say I'm sorry. But considering what he did... he got off easy.

I understand why you feel that way. But you didn't know him. He was very... gifted. When we were young... he had so much potential. Norvo was the one we all thought would turn out to be something... special. I don't know what happened. I don't know what turned my brother into...

I guess I was so busy dreaming of ways to get out of that house... I never saw what was really going on inside it... what was happening to Norvo... the endless humiliations... the constant drumbeat of criticism... the way his heart was carved up into little pieces. I should've seen it. I should've tried to stop it.
You can't blame yourself for that. You're not responsible.
But I am. Don't you see? I should've gone home a long time ago.

Personal Log, Stardate 47329.4. I finally realize why I've had trouble sleeping the last few nights. Yesterday was the fourth anniversary of the massacre at Wolf three five nine... the fourth anniversary of Jennifer's death.
I'm not sure what bothers me more. The date itself... or the fact that it almost passed unnoticed.
Dad... what are you doing up?
I was about to ask you the same thing.
I had a weird dream.
Why don't you get a hot chocolate and tell me about it?
Nah, it's nothing.
So tell me about this "weird" dream.
it's stupid.
Maybe so, but the thing about dreams is, if you talk about them, they kind of go away faster.
Okay, but don't laugh.
I promise.

I don't know... I was... on the station somewhere, but I'm not sure where... and I kept trying to get back here... but I couldn't find my way. Every time I thought I saw a familiar corridor, it kind of twisted off in some other direction... See? I told you it was stupid.
You got me interested.
Well... then... I guess I got a little scared and started looking for you... but I couldn't find you... Somehow I ended up in Ops... but you weren't in your office.
And then it was like... the floor started sloping down... and I couldn't keep my balance... and all I wanted to do was find you...
And here I am.
Dad... I love you.
I love you too.
I have a calculus test in the morning.
Then you better get some sleep.
Dad... I miss her.
Me too.
Beautiful, aren't they?
I don't think I've ever seen the stars shine so brightly.
The Bajorans call that constellation the Runners. I can never figure out if they're running toward something or away from something.
Does it really matter? Sometimes it just feels good to run.
I never thought of it that way.
My names Benjamin Sisko. I'm the Commander of this station.
I'm... (there's the slightest pause before she says her name) Fenna. I'm sorry. You must be very busy. I didn't mean to bother you.
You're not bothering me at all.
Good. I'm glad.
Commander of the station... that must be very exciting. All those ships coming and going... Every day must bring something new.
It has its moments. In some ways, though, I prefer times like this the best... when everything is quiet... And...
And you can feel a kind of anticipation in the air... like something wonderful's going to happen... but you don't know what it is...
I guess that sounds pretty silly, doesn't it?
Not at all. That's one of the great things about this station. You never know what's going to happen next...
Or who you're going to meet.
I like it here. I wish I could stay longer.
Where are you going?
(thinks for a beat, then) I'm not really sure. So I guess I'll just keep going... Like the Runners.
I'll tell you what, before you run any farther, why don't I show you around the station... If you have the time?
Fenna?
Good morning, Chief.
Morning, Commander.
(nodding at the circuitry) Is this maintenance or repair?
Right now it's maintenance, but five will get you ten it'll end up being repair before I'm through.
Admit it, Chief... If you were on a station where everything worked, you'd be miserable.
You may be right, sir.
But I'd be willing to give it a try.
Good morning, Major. Chiraltan Tea, with a double twist of lemon.
Something wrong?
No, nothing.
Major, if something's bothering you... I want to hear it.
It's just... every morning for the last year, I've seen you walk in here and start your day with a raktajino.
I like raktajino.
I know. You never even talk to anyone until you've had your first cup.
I'm not awake until I've had my first cup.
Then how come you're drinking Chiraltan Tea?
I guess I felt like having something different. That is all right with you, isn't it?
Of course. You can drink whatever you want.
Thank you, Major. Your support is appreciated.
Dax to Sisko.
Go ahead, Lieutenant.
Professor Seyetik and I are in the science lab, if you'd like to meet him.
On my way.
The commander seems to be in an especially good mood this morning.
He is... isn't he?
Something on your mind, Major?
No... it's just... You work with someone for a year or so... You think you finally have them figured out... and then... They go and order Chiraltan Tea.
Lieutenant... Where's our guest?
Inside the flux generator.
What?
What's he doing in there? He could be killed.
That's what I tried to tell him.
And he went in anyway?
Have you ever met a terraformer?
No. What's that got to do with it?
You can't tell a terraformer anything. It's an amazing talent... bringing dead worlds to life. But humility and common sense aren't exactly part of the job description.
There you go, Lieutenant. That should increase your generator output by at least five percent.
(continuing, with gusto) You must be Commander Sisko. Gideon Seyetik... It's a pleasure to meet you.
Professor... I'm a great admirer of your work.
Excellent. A man of intelligence and taste. I can tell we're going to get along famously.
My son and I visited Blue Horizon on our way to Deep Space Nine. I was impressed.
Of course you were. I created the place and even I'm impressed. How'd you like Da Vinci Falls?
I'm afraid we didn't get to see them. We were only on the surface for a few hours.

Then you missed Blue Horizon's crowning glory. Imagine... Water cascading off cliffs the height of Mount Everest and thundering through continuous rainbows, straight into an ocean the color of Sapphire Wine. I'll have to take you there one day... By God, I wouldn't mind seeing it again myself.
I may take you up on that.
But first... Epsilon One-Nineteen.
I understand the initial surveys look promising.
Promising... They look magnificent... Think of if... Reigniting a dead sun. Bringing new life to an entire solar system. Next to that, terraforming planets will look like child's play.
Let's hope it works. Right now, it's only a promising theory.

Of course it'll work. I never fail... Well, I did once, but I found it didn't agree with me, so I swore not to do it again... and I never break my word. You should be glad you're coming with me, Lieutenant. This will be my crowning achievement. Giving birth to a star. Even I'll have a hard time topping this one.
Maybe we should go over your proto- matter containment procedures.
A splendid idea. I think you'll find it fascinating. After all, I designed the containment capsule myself.
Benjamin, you're not going to let that last piece of Andorian tuber- root go to waste, are you?
Why do you ask?
Because it's delicious, that's why. May I?
Be my guest.
I'm going to need the extra calories to keep up with Seyetik. The man works almost as much as he talks... (realizes Sisko isn't paying attention) Benjamin?
What?
Looking for someone?
I'm sorry. What were you saying?

Nothing important. (she gets up, changes the subject) I have to meet with Chief O'Brien. We're boosting the maximum speed on Seyetik's ship to warp nine point five. If his experiment fails... and that sun goes supernova... we're going to want to get out of there... fast.
I'll see you back in Ops.
Benjamin... I was hoping to see you again.
I was just thinking about you.
Were you really? I've been thinking about you, too.
Where did you disappear to last night?
I had to go. I'm sorry... I didn't mean to rush away like that. Does your invitation still stand? (off his questioning look) To show me around the station?
Of course. What would you like to see?
Everything.
Everything? That's going to take some time.
I don't mind, if you don't.
What do you think?
It's wonderful.
I'm glad you like it.
You must come here all the time.
Not really. And when I do, there's usually a ship blocking the view.
I wish we'd brought a picnic basket with us.
Here?
What better place?
Well, there's always tomorrow.
Is that an invitation?
Sounded like one to me.
Then I accept.
Good... Come on. There's plenty left to see. In fact, I doubt we can see it all in one evening.
Then you can show me the rest after our picnic tomorrow.
Do you always do that?
Do what?
Say exactly the right thing.
No one's ever told me that before.
There you go again.
So... tell me all about yourself.
There's not much to tell.
Well, whatever there is, I want to hear it.
I can't.
Can't what?
I can't tell you.
Why not?
I'm sorry, Benjamin. But I have to go.
Fenna... wait.
So then Tiet looked down at Altrina's lunch and said, "Klingon food? Those are worms." And Altrina vomited all over the table. It was pretty disgusting.
That's nice, Jake.
Nice? (thinks his dad didn't get it) She threw up.
Huh? Oh... I'm sorry. I guess I was thinking about something else.
Dad, are you in love?
What?
You know... with a woman. (defending his supposition) You're showing all three of the signs.
Signs?
The ones Nog told me about. Loss of appetite. Daydreaming. Smiling all the time.
You've been talking to Nog about women again?
I just want you to know that if you are in love... it's okay with me.
Thanks, Jake.
What's she like?
She's... really... interesting.
Interesting, huh? So... when do I get to meet her?
It might be a little early for that.
Why? She likes you too, doesn't she?
I think so.
Then what's the problem?
It's just that... (knows this sounds strange) She keeps disappearing.

Above all, stay alert. If the subspace transmission I received is correct and Villus Thed is en route to the station, I want to be notified the moment he arrives. Keep him under constant surveillance, but remember, he's a short-range telepath, so stay at least five meters away from him at all times.
That's all.
What can I do for you, Commander?
I have a favor to ask... of a personal nature.
Go on.
I'm looking for someone... a woman.
Name?
Fenna.
First or last?
I don't know.
Species?
I don't know... Humanoid.
What ship did she arrive on?
(realizing how little he knows) I don't know.
All right. What can you tell me about her?
Let's see... I'd say she's about one point six meters tall... brown skin... dark hair... the last time I saw her she was wearing a... Dark red bodysuit.
Well that's something, anyway.
So do you think you can help me?
I don't know.
I need to find her, Constable. I think she may be in some kind of trouble.
What kind of trouble? (before Sisko can answer) Let me guess... You don't know. This isn't much to go on... but I'll do what I can.
I appreciate the help, Odo.
Benjamin, do you have a minute?
In my office.
What's on your mind, Dax?
I was hoping you had something to say to me.
I don't follow you.
You really have no intention of telling me, do you?
Telling you what?
Come on, Benjamin... I saw you with her last night on the Promenade What's her name?
Fenna. Believe me, Dax... there's nothing to talk about.
You used to tell Curzon everything.
Not everything.
You know what I mean. It's because I'm a woman now, isn't it?
Don't be ridiculous.
I understand, Benjamin. It's not easy talking man to man with a woman.
That has nothing to do with it.
Then tell me what's going on
I will. As soon as there's something to tell.
Personal Log. Supplemental. So far Odo has found no new information about Fenna. In the meantime, Professor Seyetik has invited me and the senior staff to dinner aboard the Prometheus.
To be a great terraformer. You need the green thumb of a gardener, the eye of a painter, the soul of a poet... and it doesn't hurt to be a raging egomaniac.
Which makes you eminently qualified.
Of course.
Terraforming is amazing enough, but I still don't understand how you intend to reignite a dead sun.

Basically... I'll use a remote-piloted shuttlepod to deliver proto-matter into the dead star, which'll start a cascade effect transforming the star's carbon and oxygen into elemental hydrogen. Then we'll just stand back and watch the fireworks.
Of course, if anything goes wrong, it might be the last thing we ever see.
Come now, Lieutenant, nothing of any worth was ever created by a pessimist.
I don't know about that. Van Gogh... Beckett... Y'Raka... I wouldn't exactly call them optimists.
Precisely. And look at their work. Dreary, dark and depressing. Art should be an affirmation of life. Take for instance... my own work in the field.
I once saw an exhibit of your paintings at the Central Gallery on Ligobis Ten. They were certainly memorable. I don't think I've ever seen such huge canvasses.
Doctor, no one's ever accused me of understatement.
Certainly not anyone who's ever read your autobiography.

Nine volumes and counting. I always said I wanted to write as many books as I've had marriages. Which reminds me... wait until you taste the food my wife has created for you today. None of that replicated nonsense you're used to. Each dish was prepared entirely by Nidell's own sweet hands.
(who's had about enough of this) I can't wait to meet her.
And so you shall. She should be just about done. I'll go get her.
You think he'd notice if we weren't here when he got back.
Don't even think about it, Major. I've probably had dinner with two dozen Bajoran ministers by now. I think you owe me this one. Besides, Seyetik is one of the Federation's greatest minds.
I know. He told me.
Well, I for one, find him remarkable entertaining.
Friends... I'd like you to meet my wife and my inspiration... Nidell.
Now we have something to talk about.
I can't eat another bite.
That was delicious. Do you think I could get the recipe?
That's up to Gideon. It's his creation.
It took me years to perfect it. The secret is to sear the Kalo roots slightly before layering them over the slices of roasted Waroon.

She acts like she doesn't recognize me. But the most important thing is the broth. One DAX liter of clear Rumall stock.
