A tumbler and a It is the same woman, half of Gremish, two isn't it? clusters of Vulcan redspice, half a dozen SISKO minced Humat pods, and a She looks the same... dash of ice salt.

doesn't recognize me. But the most important thing is the broth. One DAX liter of clear Rumall stock. A tumbler and a It is the same woman, half of Gremish, two isn't it? clusters of Vulcan redspice, half a dozen SISKO minced Humat pods, and a She looks the same... dash of ice salt.

DAX liter of clear Rumall stock. A tumbler and a It is the same woman, half of Gremish, two isn't it? clusters of Vulcan redspice, half a dozen SISKO minced Humat pods, and a She looks the same... dash of ice salt.
redspice, half a dozen SISKO minced Humat pods, and a She looks the same... dash of ice salt.
SISKO minced Humat pods, and a She looks the same... dash of ice salt.
Then you reduce it in a Andorian boiler at exactly five hundred degrees Kelvin and pepper to taste. Any questions?
Maybe you should write it down.
Of course. No trouble at all. Now, why don't we continue this conversation in the other room. We'll be more comfortable there.
(as she continues to clean up) Can I help you with anything, Commander?
I hope so.
I don't understand.
(thinks she's being coy) Yesterday... on the Promenade... You had plenty of opportunity.
Commander, I don't know what you're talking about. I never met you before tonight.
I suppose you never told me your name was Fenna?
(with a forgiving smile) Would you like to talk about it?
Commander, you've obviously mistaken me for someone else.
Seems that way, doesn't it?
I'm telling you Dax, it was the same woman. The face... the voice... It was Fenna.
Maybe you ought to talk to her when her husband isn't around.
Dax, she's a married woman.
That would never have stopped Curzon.
It's just that this was the first time since Jennifer's death that I've felt... really drawn to someone.
Commander, may I have a word with you? I thought you should know... I checked this week's docking and transporter logs and there's no record of anyone fitting the description you gave me.
Thanks, Odo... but you can call off the search. I already found the woman I was looking for.
Did you? Where was she? If you don't mind my asking.
Aboard the Prometheus.
The Prometheus? Are you sure?
We just left there a few minutes ago.
But that's impossible.
What do you mean?
I checked the de-embarkation logs as part of my search. Except for Professor Seyetik, no one has left the Prometheus the entire time it's been at the station.
Commander?
I thought you could use this.
Thanks, but I was just leaving.
Stood you up, didn't she? When you've worked in a bar as long as I have, you get to recognize that look. I've even seen it in the mirror... Once or twice.
I'd better be getting home.
If you'd like, we could go down to the bar and talk... You know... about women.
I don't think so.
Don't forget, the holosuites are always open.
Benjamin.
I missed you. Is something wrong?
I just had dinner with someone who looks exactly like you.
Like me? How strange?
Then you're telling me that your name isn't really Nidell and you're not the wife of Gideon Seyetik.
Of course not. I'm Fenna. You know that.
Right now, I'm not sure what I know. I don't suppose you have a twin sister.
Not that I know of.
Fenna... I need to know where you came from... what you're doing on this station.
Does that matter?
Of course it matters. I need to know who you are.
You do know me, Benjamin.
When I came here, I thought I was looking for a place... somewhere I belonged... but I was wrong. I wasn't looking for a place. I was looking for a person. I was looking for you.
Benjamin...
All right, Lieutenant. I've got the warp drive on the Prometheus purring like a kitten. It'll do nine point six in a pinch but I wouldn't take it any faster...
I thought the theoretical maximum for those engines was warp nine point five?
It was.
Must I remind you, Lieutenant, that some of us only have one lifetime.
I'll be right there.
Good luck, Lieutenant.
Come to see us off, Benjamin.
Not exactly. I'm going with you. After all, how often do you get to see a star reborn.
You sure this is a good idea?
I need answers, Dax. And the key to Fenna's disappearance could be on that ship.
Your chief of operations did some amazing things with our engines. We should reach Epsilon One-Nineteen well ahead of schedule. Have you finished loading the proto- matter device into the shuttlepod?
All set. The containment field is holding up fine and the remote guidance systems are fully operational.
I'm telling you, Commander, by the time I was through with New Halana, it was a paradise. How are we doing, Mister Piersall?
We'll be initiating preliminary scans in a few hours.
Let me know when we get there.
You must be eager to get started. What did you call this? Your crowning achievement.
Don't remind me. Commander, my whole life has been a series of escalating triumphs. It's what I live for... knowing that no matter what I achieve, there's always another challenge waiting for me.
And now?
Are you familiar with the Klingon poet G'trok?
A little. "The Fall of Kang" is required reading at the Academy.
"So honor the valiant who die 'neath
"But pity the warrior who slays all his foes."
A little obvious perhaps, but true nonetheless.
So what were we talking about?
You.
Of course. My favorite subject. Where was I?
You had just finished terraforming New Halana.

Ah, yes. Well, you can imagine how grateful the Halanans were. There were endless parades and receptions. It got to be a bit of a bore actually. But then, I met Nidell. She was the daughter of a local dignitary. She was utterly infatuated with me from the start. I can't say I blamed her. The first time she saw me, I was surrounded by a cheering crowd, unveiling a statue they'd commissioned in my honor.
I could tell right away she was someone special. She'd never been offworld before she met me. I promised to show her the galaxy... I'd've given it to her if I could've.
She must love you very much.
She does, Commander. Don't ask me why. But she does.
Yes.
Nidell, it's Commander Sisko. Can I talk to you for a minute?
I'm sorry, Commander. I'm not feeling well at the moment.
Is there anything I can do?
No, thank you. Maybe you could come back later?
Of course.
Fenna?
Benjamin. I'm so glad to see you.
Dax, report to my quarters immediately.
On my way.
Benjamin... What's wrong?
The last time I saw you, you... vanished.
I'm with you now. And I'm never leaving you again.
I wish I could believe that.
You have to, Benjamin.
Dax, this is Fenna.
What's she doing?
It's all right. She's not going to hurt you.
I'm not reading any cellular structure, no DNA patterns, just... pure energy.
Benjamin... what's she talking about?
I think it's time we found out.
Help her.
She won't wake up.
She's in shock. Respiration is shallow. Heartbeat irregular and falling. Her blood pressure is dropping. She's dying, Benjamin.
You've got to do something.
I'm not sure I can.
Fenna. I should have known.
You can't be here. Nidell promised me you'd never come back.
I don't know what you're talking about.
Just look at her.
She looks like me.
Of course she looks like you. She is you. The real you.
Professor, what the hell is going on here?
That thing over there isn't real. She's an illusion, created by my wife's unconscious mind.
That's not true... Benjamin, you know he's lying.
Nidell is a psychoprojective telepath. And Fenna is just another one of her projections.
(looking for confirmation) Lieutenant?
I've never seen readings like these. Her occipital lobe is giving off enormous amounts of energy. I don't see how she can survive like this more than another hour or two.
She's dying. You have to help her.
There's nothing I can do.
(taking control, to Dax) Take Fenna to my quarters.
No.
Get her out of here, Dax.
(not wanting to be separated from Sisko) But, Benjamin, I want to stay with you...
It'll be all right, Fenna. I just need to talk to Seyetik.
Alright, Professor. If what you're saying is true, Nidell's psychoprojective abilities are killing her... and I need to know why.

Nidell doesn't even know this is happening. During times of deep emotional distress... Halanans can lose control of these abilities. And I'm afraid my wife... is very emotionally distraught. She's done this once before. Three years ago, on Terosa Prime. It almost killed her then. She swore to me it would never happen again.
Obviously it has.

You may have noticed I invoke strong reactions from people, Commander. Especially my wives. They all start out loving me, but a few years of togetherness soon cures them of that. My other wives all had the sense to leave.
Why can't Nidell? What keeps her with you.
Halanans mate for life. She can never leave me, no matter how much she might want to.
Benjamin, I've never seen Seyetik or that woman before. I don't know why he's saying those things about me... but they're lies. I'm as real as you are.
I want to believe that. Just tell me where you came from... How you got to the station?
Can you tell me a single memory of your life before we met on the Promenade?
Benjamin... I'm so frightened.
Nidell's dying. She only has a few hours left.
If she dies... what happens to me?
You can't exist without her. But you might be able to save her. Give her back the life she's given you.
I don't know how.
You can go back to her. I've seen you do it three times.
(feeling the weight of her situation) But even if she lives, I'll die. And everything you and I have will die with me.
Fenna, what we have is a dream. I wouldn't trade it for anything... but it's still just a dream. Nidell's dream.
And she won't remember any of it, will she?
There's no way to be sure.
(she moves closer to him) I love you, Benjamin, and I always will.
Commander, you'd better come to the bridge, right away.
What is it, Dax?
It's Seyetik. He's launched the shuttlepod toward Epsilon One- Nineteen... And he's onboard.
On my way.
He's opening a channel.
On screen.
I hope this transmitter is working. I'd hate to go to all this trouble
Professor, what do you think you're doing?
Making history. You might want to record this. For posterity and all that.
He's about sixty seconds away from impact.
Seyetik, you don't have to do this. We found a way to save Nidell.

I had the feeling you would, Commander. But this is the only way to truly set her free. I owe her that. Besides, this will be my crowning achievement. Remember "The Fall of Kang." Well, you're looking at one warrior who refuses to be pitied.
What's he talking about?
Klingon poetry.
Thirty seconds until impact.
Professor, I want you to turn that shuttlepod around. That's an order.
Too late, Commander. I've already entered the gravity well of the star.
Engage the tractor beam.
He disabled it before he left.
Commander, when this is over, you'll find a case with my personal belongings. There's something in there you need to find.
What is it?

My obituary. I wrote it myself. After all, I couldn't trust such an important document to some stranger. Do me a favor and see to it that it's sent to the Daystrom Institute for publication. Which reminds me, I didn't get a chance to update it before I left. Let the record state "He sacrificed himself on the alter of science."
Ten seconds.
I'll be sure they get it.
I knew I could count on you.
Five seconds. Keep you eyes on the viewscreen, Commander. You'll never see anything like this again... Let there be light.
Station log, supplemental. Epsilon One-Nineteen continues to burn brightly, a fitting memorial to a brilliant man. Meanwhile, I'm happy to report Nidell has made a complete recovery.
Unfortunately, she has no memory of Fenna's experiences.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: Benjamin...
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: Nidell. How'd you know I was here?
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: Lieutenant Dax told me.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: So... when does the Prometheus leave?
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: Soon. I just wanted to say goodbye... and thank you.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: It'll be good to get home.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: How long do you plan to stay on New Halana?
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: For the rest of my life. I've been away too long as it is.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: I wish I could remember Fenna... what she did, how she felt... But I can't.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: I'm sorry.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: That's all right. I can remember for both of us.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: Tell me one thing...
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: If I can.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: What was she like?
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: Fenna?
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: She was just like you.
scene: 83   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL (THE NEXT DAY)

quote: I thought I told you to cancel that order. Now what am I supposed to do with five thousand wrappages of Cardassian yamok sauce. They were the only ones who could stomach that swill!
Hey, are you gonna play, or what?
You ordered it, you're going to pay for it! I'll take half of your paycheck every week for the next... six years! (turns to face him squarely) And from now on, no more Cardassian food in here! Ever!
C'mon, Nog, it's your turn.
... five thousand wrappages... that's a lot of yamok sauce...
Look, either take your turn, or I win.
... it'd be a shame for it to go to waste...
(tosses in cards; disgusted) That's it; game's over.
Jake, I'm getting that... tingle in the lobes. And when a lobe tingles, it means only one thing: "Opportunity."
What're you talking about?
I'm talking about gold-pressed latinum... maybe four, or five bars...
I thought you were talking about yamok sauce.
You've got a lot to learn about opportunity. Come on.
Where?
Station log. Stardate xxxx.xx. With the help of the Federation, Bajor is about to commence its first large-scale energy transfer: The tapping of the molten core of its fifth moon, Jeraddo.
Magma pressures remain constant...
Differential subsurface movement is at zero-point-three percent.
Is that good?
They'd tell you if it weren't.
Why is that red light blinking?
We're in normal standby mode.
I take it, then, that we're not expecting any surprises.
We don't like surprises any more than you do.
Minister Toran, these people are professionals.
Forgive my bureaucratic nitpicking, Major, but we're counting on Jeraddo's energy to heat a few hundred thousand Bajoran homes this winter.
With that in mind, we're due to make our next inspection...
Anyway, so there I was, sitting in Quark's, when Morn just comes over and invites me for dinner... Grid square twelve-delta reads clear of life forms...
Morn? Are you serious?
Beginning scan of grid square fifteen delta...
So what did you say?
I told him I was busy.
Good.
But you know those seven or eight little wiry hairs sticking out of his forehead?
What... ?
They make him look kind of cute.
That's odd... Sensors read a humanoid presence in fifteen delta. Could be one of the project thermologists.
Not in fifteen delta.
See for yourself.
All the inhabitants should've been evacuated by now. I'd better beam down there and see what's going on.
Ready to transport.
I won't be long.
The problem is, they don't like uniforms.
Neither do I, but it comes with the job.
Which is?
Do we talk, or do they attack?
You're halfway pretty.
Does that mean I can come in?
Problem is, I don't like uniforms, either. They scare me. We've had our fill of uniformed bullies.
I'm no Cardassian. You know you're supposed to be out of here by now.
All I know is this farm. If you want proof, girl, just take a look at my crop.
I'd rather you didn't call me "girl."
... Our crop, I should say. Mostly the katterpod beans. You won't find better katterpods.
My father always said you get bigger katterpods when you spray in some chlorobicrobes.
Is that right. That could be. So your family's farmers, then.
No... but if I don't get on your good side soon, my arm's going to fall off.
Pretty eyes like yours deserve a meal. Come on in.
I'm afraid we don't have the time. Obviously, you were overlooked in the general evacuation; I've got to get you out of here.
We'll talk about that over supper.
Excuse me, Sir... Are you the captain of the Lissepian cargo ship?
That's right.
And you do a lot of trading with the Cardassians?
Why not... one thing about Cardassians; they pay their bills.
Yes, I've heard that... And I've also heard they really love their yamok sauce.
Look, if you're trying to buy some yamok sauce from me, boy, you're wasting your time. I'm not carrying any.
We're not buying... we're selling.
Five thousand wrappages of it.
Where would you two boys get all that yamok sauce?
We have connections.
... five thousand, you say.
And they can be yours for... say... five bars of gold-pressed latinum.
That's a lot of latinum.
That's a lot of yamok sauce.
Look, I'm not carrying any latinum. But I'll tell you what I'll do: I'll trade you something for it.
We were kind of counting on latinum...
Hold on. What would you trade?
I'll give you a hundred gross of self-sealing stem bolts. Some Bajoran ordered them from me, and now he can't pay.
Self-sealing stem bolts?
Top grade merchandise; you won't find a better stem bolt in this sector.
I don't think so. We deal strictly in latinum.
Nog, are you sure?
What're we going to do with stem bolts?
What're we going to do with yamok sauce?
Sir, I've discussed it with my partner, and you have a deal.
Good. I'll meet you at cargo bay nine at twenty-one hundred hours. We'll make the trade then.
Now the question is, what do we do with a hundred gross of self-sealing stem bolts.
I've got a better question. How do we get your uncle's yamok sauce?
At least you're not the type that'd dispossess a man on an empty stomach.
I wouldn't think of it.
That's fine. Of course, these roots take about three hours to soften.
What?
Surely you don't eat your roots hard.
I'm in no hurry. Kira to Ganges.
This is Dax. Are you all right?
A man with a talent for delay just invited me to a farewell supper here. You go on. I'll have one of the thermologists bring me back.
Enjoy supper; Dax out.
After you wash it, scrub off the skin.
You don't talk much, do you?

They don't talk at all. Cardassians took care of that. They escaped to this moon about eighteen years ago. I've been here forty. We've done well together. Be a good girl, and set out the plates and utensils, please.
In that cupboard on the other side there.
Y'know, dear, you look good even from this angle; but you walk like a carnivorous rastipod.
(wheels around; losing it) Now look!...
You're trying to make me mad.
How'm I doing?
Not well enough to get rid of me.
Damn.
So what do they call you, dear?
I'm Major Kira; I'm in charge of evacuating all the...
You're given name.
Nerys.
Well, Nerys, I'm Mullibok, and this root really does take three hours to cook, so... You sit yourself down and relax, child, it'll be tasty.
Mullibok, they begin tapping the core of this moon in seven days.
I know.
With respect... you are only three people. This project will benefit thousands... hundreds of thousands.
I made myself unconcerned with all of that forty years ago when I ran away from a Cardassian labor camp on your precious Bajor.
What we're trying to create now is what you weren't allowed to have then. It can be your Bajor, too.
This is where I live. This is my home.
You'll have a home on Bajor... and people who'll welcome you and your friends. Life'll be different, yes. But it'll be fine... really.
No it won't. I told you; my life is here. I'll die if I leave. I'd rather die here.
Uncle Quark...
Last night... that dabo player who dropped his drink... I saw you run and get him another one without charging him. I've warned you about picking up your father's habits.

It'll never happen again, Uncle. Y'know, I was trying to find some storage space for the shipment of lokar beans that're due in tomorrow. Is it okay if I stack them on top of the yamok sauce? If I can reach that high.
Please! Don't talk to me about yamok sauce.
Do you want me to get rid of it? I can take it to the matter reclamation unit.
Anything... Just get it out of my sight. You're a good boy, Nog.

I stowed away on a Cardassian survey vessel. They made stops all through the Bajoran system, looking for possible mining sites. When they got here to Jeraddo, I overpowered the crew and stole what I'd need to start building my life here.
You overpowered the crew... by yourself?

There were only six of them... ... which was fortunate, because I'd been weakened a bit by captivity and starvation. Anyway, here I was; the first person ever to settle on this moon. Trouble was, I had no farm implements. Once again, starvation and I stared each other in the face. I'm not boring you... ?
No, no, I want to hear who won.
Well, it was mind over matter. Every twenty-six hours I just tightened my waist-belt another notch, so my belly could never really be sure it was shrinking.
Excuse me... ?
Now you asked me how I got started here, and I'm trying very politely to tell you, if you'll kindly let me finish.
I assume you found some food before you ran out of belt notches.
Are you telling this story or am I?
By all means...
Well, it was obvious I was going to have to plant and harvest a crop. So I did what anyone'd do who had an entire world to build...

... I rolled back and forth across the ground til it surrendered. Then I went down on my hands and knees and started to plow... Using my bare fingernails, mind you... I plowed every last furrow in that field straight as a plumb line.
Now that's inventive.
And when I'd hit a patch of mineralized clay, I'd just grind it up in my teeth to enrich the soil. Baltrim, let's taste a bit of your wonderful wine here.
What I'm telling you, Major, is that I tamed this place. Me.
I believe you.
You look like a bit of a fighter yourself.
On Bajor, we had to be.
To get rid of the Cardassians. Mindless butchers.
We paid them back.
I bet you did... They probably never knew what hit them. I'm sorry I missed the fun.
Fun?
Like spearing kandippers in a bottle.
Wait a minute; are you serious? You know what the Cardassians were like; the weapons they had. We didn't stand a chance against them.
Well then, how did you beat them?
We beat them because... (beat, she realizes where he's taken her) ... We hung on like fanatics.
Hung on like fanatics. I'll have to remember that.
Listen to me, Mullibok...
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: You know, one of these days I've got to finish this kiln... So I can temper my baking pots... put colorful tops on them. That'd be nice, wouldn't it?
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: Look... I appreciate that you're trying to hang on here... and I sympathize... but you can't stay. The minute they start tapping the crust, it will release sulfer and carbon compounds that will make the air unbreathable.
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: The Cardassians probably told you that you didn't stand a chance, either. Did you surrender?
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: No.
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: Then why would you expect me to act any different than you? You tell them they can start cracking this moon apart anytime they're ready. I'll be here.
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: I'll tell them.
scene: 31   EXT. OUTSIDE COTTAGE - NIGHT - FAVORING KILN AREA

quote: So that's a stem bolt.
A self-sealing stem bolt. There's a difference.
You're sure about that... ?
What's important is that it's top grade merchandise. You can't find a better stem bolt in this sector.
And we have a hundred gross of them!
That's a lot of stem bolts.
Excuse me, gentlemen...
Anyone know what this cargo is doing here?
Uh... it belongs to my Uncle Quark; they're... stem bolts.
Well, do me a favor and tell your uncle we're getting a bit weary of him short-circuiting import procedures.
I'll certainly do that, Sir... It's just that my Uncle Quark really needed some stem bolts...
You mean self-sealing stem bolts.
That's right! That's it! Self- sealing stem bolts.
He sure needs a lot of them.
This is top grade merchandise. You can't find a better stem bolt in this sector.
I don't doubt it. What's he need them for?
Oh... the usual.
The usual?
Well, you know... ... Why does anybody use self-sealing stem bolts...
I wouldn't know; I've never used
Never?
I've never even seen one.
Then how did you know they're self- sealing?
I read it here on the manifest padd.
I would've bet anything he'd know what they were.
I told you we should've asked that freighter captain.
Wait... I know who can tell us what self-sealing stem bolts are! The Bajoran who ordered them in the first place. His name's gotta be on the shipping codes.
Sirco Ch'Ano... It has his address and everything. You think he'll be mad that we have his stem bolts?
He couldn't afford 'em, remember. But we'll offer to sell them to him at a discount.
I'm glad you finally made it back; I was getting worried.
Is he alone?
I think Minister Toran's in there with him.
Even better.
I don't understand. There were forty- seven other people living on that moon. They all left willingly.
How do we know? All we know is that they obeyed the order to leave.
And so will these people.
You haven't met Mullibok.
Is there anything you can offer that might make him more willing to leave?
Not a thing, believe me.
Would a postponement help?
It'd give us time to work something out with him.
We can't postpone, and if he stays, he'll be committing suicide. We'll have to beam him off the surface.
If we take him like that, we'll be killing him.
I refuse to allow three stubborn holdouts to jeopardize a project that'll benefit so many of our people. I'm sorry, Major; if there were anything else we could do, we'd have done it.
But there is another way. We can tap the core using phased energy retrieval.

I thought we had agreed that phased energy retrieval would take too long. It would mean waiting a full year before we could extract any meaningful amount of energy. I wish we had the time to be more delicate, but we don't.
So instead, we'll act like Cardassians...
Easy, Major.
I resent that. It's obvious to me that you've developed a feeling for this man. Fine; I can accept that. But if you're not comfortable with completing this assignment, I'll find someone who is.
(resigned to the inevitable) That won't be necessary.
Kira to Odo.
Odo here...
I'm going back to Jeraddo. I need two security officers to meet me at Runabout Pad Three immediately.
They'll be there.
Is there something I should know?
I am not a Cardassian!
I knew that.
I mean... What's the point! If we're going to act like Cardassians, why did we bother to get rid of them in the first place!
Not a good meeting, huh?
All right, so it is my job, and I'll do my job, but it's wrong!
Mullibok?
Mullibok!
What about the other two?

They have a cottage about... ... thirty-five, forty meters through there. Now remember; these people were victims of the Cardassians. They don't speak; they're very frightened of uniforms. Understood?
Understood, Major.
If they're out working in the fields, just... start gathering their supplies... clothing, I guess...
Without permission?
We're not going to get permission. Just be careful with everything.
You plan on using that... ?
Protocol. If you like, I'll help you pack your things.
You sent those two uniforms after Baltrim and Keena.
That's right; I'm doing what has to be done.
Me, too.
Don't make us take you by force... Please!

I promise you it won't be that bad. You can plant whatever you want on Bajor; keep to yourself if you want to; that's fine. Take some seeds with you for those terrible roots of yours I had to eat. Just listen to reason!
Just listen to yourself, Major. Tell me what you hear.
What do you mean?
I mean you sound like a two-headed Malgorian I knew as a boy.
Did you every try talking with a two- headed Malgorian?
This is no time for one of your stories...
You see, the thing about a two-headed Malgorian is, it can never make up its mind about what it really wants. Which can be very confusing, believe me.
Eventually, you're going to have to stop talking, and deal with this.
Now you see, that was the trouble with my Malgorian friend. He always had problems, and he could never decide how to solve them. So he would come looking for me to deal with his problems for him.
Mullibok, please...
And you know what I finally told that Malgorian? "Fellows, deal with it yourselves."
Fine. I'll pack your things myself.
Major!
They're crazy! The man just stuck me with a farm tool, and she came at me from behind!
Let her go!
Stay back!
No!
You! Beam up to the Runabout and call the station! Get Doctor Bashir! Move!
I'm sorry, I still can't see you. What'd you say your name was... ? I'm getting some kind of subspace interference.
My name's...
We're, uh... ... the Nog and, uh... The "Noh-Jay Consortium." And we have a hundred gross of self-sealing stem bolts. We were wondering...
You have my stem bolts? What would you want for them?
We'll let you have them for five bars of gold-pressed latinum.
Five bars!
Four bars.
I don't think I...
Three bars.
If I had any latinum, I'd already have the bolts. Would you consider an exchange?
I'd consider one bar of latinum...
He doesn't have any latinum. Let's trade for something.
I don't want "something." I want latinum.
I can't hear you... Can I interest you in a piece of land?
Land is good.
For what? It's nothing but dirt.
How much land?
I can let you have seven tessipates.
"Seven" sounds good.
First yamok sauce... then stem bolts... now tessipates... and still no profit.
But we're getting closer... I can feel it.
You can?
I think so.
Do we have a deal?
We'll have to see proof that you own the land.
Naturally. You'll get a transmission on that by twelve hundred hours.
You've bought yourself some stem bolts.
Land!
Dirt.
Just rest easy. You took a phaser blast which punctured your peritoneum. It's serious, and if you try moving around, you're going to make it worse.
Another uniform.
Doctor Julian Bashir, Starfleet. Major Kira sent for me.
She did, uh?... ... You're backwards, Nerys... I told you...
With me unconscious, she could've just had us swept off of here with no trouble at all. My friends... Baltrim and Keena...
They've been evacuated to Bajor. I'll be taking you back to our station, so I can...
No. I stay here.
He refuses to leave.
Really.
He's got to be cared for. I'm going to take him without his permission.
No you're not.
He needs close attention. There's no medical facility here.
I'll be here.
Leave me instructions and whatever medication you think he'll need.
She didn't offer a word of explanation, Sir. She simply removed her uniform tunic and started... building.
Well Doctor, right now she stands a pretty good chance of being out of uniform permanently. I'm going to tell Minister Toran that she's remained temporarily on Jeraddo at your request.
But sir, that... isn't true.
Make it true, Doctor. Now, please.
Commander, I'd advise that Major Kira remain on Jeraddo for humanitarian reasons, uh... ... How long?
The next day or two.
For the next day or two, sir.
Thank you, Doctor; I'll consider that request. Dismissed.
What's that?
It's for deep bruises. Don't ask my why it works, I'm not the doctor.
What're they going to do to you for staying here?
Probably the same thing they'll do to you. I don't really know.
What're you so angry about?
I don't really know...
... When I was very small... I remember there was a tree just outside my window. It was the ugliest, gnarled and battered old tree I've ever seen. Even the birds stayed away from it.
But you loved it.

I hated it. (turns; faces him squarely) Because it'd grown so huge that its branches blotted out the sun for kellipates. And its roots were buried so deep in the soil that nothing else could grow there. It was a big, selfish, annoying...
...Nasty...
Nasty old tree.
Sounds to me like it had character...
A lot.
And what happened to it? Did you cut it down?
I don't know yet.
Sisko to Kira...
(frowning surprise; taps combadge) Commander?
I'm preparing to beam down.
I don't think that's a good idea.
Major... Either I'm coming down, or you're coming up.
Doesn't have much faith in you, does he?
Now just hold on, Nerys. This is still my home.
What do you want?
I'd like to see Major Kira.
She doesn't want to see you, and neither do I.
Wait a minute... don't speak for me.
You know, you're causing a lot of trouble.
I can't tell you how delighted I am to hear it. How many of your Federation uniforms do you plan to send after me? Forty... ? Fifty?
I don't think it'll come to that.
Depends how badly you want to get rid of me.
Mister Mullibok, I'm here because I'm concerned about my first officer.
What about her?
By staying here, she's jeopardizing her career.
You'd better get back into bed.
Stop telling me what to do!
Major, can I see you outside for a minute?
Go on, talk all you want; tell him your story about the tree.
Be quiet.
You see, there was this big, ugly tree...
Go on...
(sees he's not getting a rise) Never mind.
I can see why you like him.
What can I do for you, Commander?
You and I have a materiel subsistence report to finish by the end of the week.
I'm not sure I'll be able to help you with that.
It's part of the liaison officer's job.
I know.
I don't like the prospect of having to break in a new one...
You have a job to do here, Major, and you're not doing it.
It's not as simple as that.

I'm not saying it's simple; I'm saying it can't wait. Look, I understand you're used to sympathizing with the underdog. You've spent your life fighting to overcome impossible odds... just like he's doing. But you have to realize something, Major... ... You're on the other side now.
Pretty uncomfortable, isn't it?
It's awful.

When I first met you, Major, I thought you were hostile and arrogant. But I was wrong. Bajor needs you, and I need you. I like you... I don't want you to be hurt. So as a friend, I came here to remind you... His fate is already decided... Yours isn't.
Thank you.
There'll be a Runabout standing by. One to beam up.
Mullibok?
...No... Let go... You're hurting her... Lussilla! No!...
Easy... Easy...
(angrily, not referring to Kira) I told you! Get your hands off me!
... that's right... just rest... it's going to be fine...
Oh... it's you.
You were having a bad dream.
Not just a bad dream... bad memories. I didn't say anything, did I?
No. Are you thirsty?
No.
Hungry?
Leave me alone.
Go back to sleep.
Where are you going?
I'd like to get some sleep, too.
Fine. But bring the chair over here.
Well, are you my nurse, or not?
Is this better?
Are you going to talk all night, or let me sleep?
Nog, I'm waiting.
I'm thinking.
About what?
Latinum. And how we don't have any. All we have is dirt.
How many times do I have to tell you... It's not dirt; it's land.
And what're we supposed to do with this land?
Sell it, I guess.
To who?
Why do I have to think of everything.
We should've kept the stem bolts.
Land is better than bolts.
How do you know?
You can build things on land.
You can't build anything without bolts.
Just throw down a card.
And you say they're based here on the station?
That's correct.
... The Noh-Jay Consortium... No, never heard of it. Why do you ask?
I was contacted by a government official this morning. They want to build a reclamation facility on a strip of land owned by four different people.
... Three of them have agreed to sell, but the government doesn't know how to contact the fourth... this Noh- Jay Consortium...
You mean the government can't build without that one piece of land?
Apparently not.
What a wonderful opportunity for profit...
I told you land was better than bolts.
... And you think that I'm part of this consortium?
I think very little goes on here without your knowledge.
True. This time, however... ... someone failed to include me.
Are you telling me you're not involved?
Not yet. But that will be remedied; and you can tell the Bajorans I'll be opening negotiations with them shortly.
Let's see... Who on this station is clever enough...
Uncle Quark?
Not now.
But... Uncle Quark...
Go sweep the floor!
This is important.
Well? Make it fast.
I have a... business opportunity that might interest you... It'll only cost you five bars of gold-pressed latinum.
Any pain?
A little sore. I was starting to think you'd sleep all day.
That's because I was up all night taking care of you.
I don't recall asking you to.
Look, I can handle this. Go in and get something to eat.
There isn't time.
Why? You finally leaving?
Last one.
I never thought I'd finish it.
It's finished.
Nothing left to do but fire it up.
What's all this?
You finished your work; I have to finish mine.
But you don't want to.
No... I don't. Look. I could use a friend on Bajor. I'd like it to be you.
Major, as long as that cottage stands... I stay right here.
What the hell are you doing!
Saving your life.
So you chose your uniform over me after all.
That's not true. The time I've spent with you here has meant a lot to me. But it's over. It's time we got on with our lives. Mine... and yours.
You say you're my friend. Prove it. Use that thing on me.
I can't...
If I leave this place... I die.
No you won't. I won't let you.
Energize.
Station log, Stardate 46729.1. The Bajoran government has asked me to mediate a dispute between two rival factions, the Paqu and the Navot. At issue is a land dispute which could trigger a civil war.
Commander, the Paqu delegation has arrived at docking bay six.
Let's welcome them aboard. Dax, any word on the Navot?
They should be here within the hour.
Excuse me, Commander.
Chief, I thought you'd be on your way to Bajor by now.

We're due to leave any moment. Sir, I was wondering if perhaps Ensign Boyer could take my place on this particular mission. After all, I'd be little more than a chauffeur, and Boyer can pilot a Runabout as well as I can.
Has something come up that requires your presence on the station?
No, Sir. Everything's running smoothly, for a change. But around here, you never know...
Ah, there you are Chief. All set to go?
Yes, Sir.
Commander, did the Magistrate give any indication regarding the nature of this medical emergency?
Only that his village was in danger of extinction.
In that case we better be on our way.
I agree.
Yes, Sir.
Docking port six.
You know Chief, in a way I'm really looking forward to this mission.
Why's that?
I see it as a wonderful opportunity for us to get to know one another.
I'd like you to set up a preliminary meeting with both sides for later this afternoon. Make sure they know that this is an informal session. I just want to get them talking to each other.
Just getting them to sit down at the same table will be an accomplishment. Sir, about these negotiations...
You have some advice for me?
There's an old saying on Bajor, "the land and the people are one." Well, the land inhabited by the Paqu and Navot is some of the harshest on the planet.
Relax Major. This isn't my first time up at the plate.
(doesn't get the baseball reference) Sir...
Besides, I'll have you by my side to help me avoid making mistakes.
What can you tell me about the Paqu Tetrarch?
Not much. The Paqu choose to avoid contact with outsiders.
Commander Sisko?
Yes?
I am Varis Sul, Tetrarch of the Paqu.
Chief, may I ask you a question?
Of course.
And I'd like an honest answer.
You'll get one.
Do I... annoy you?
(looking over his shoulder) Annoy me? What kind of question is that?
Well, the thing is, we've just spent two hours alone together in this runabout and you hardly said a word to me the whole time.
Really? I hadn't noticed.
Oh, I see...
I suppose I was too busy... thinking.
Thinking?
That's right.
About what?
What?
What were you thinking about? I'm just curious.
Let's see... I was thinking that when I get back to the station, I'll have to run a level one diagnostic on the phase coil generators. Satisfied?
I guess so.
Glad to hear it.
I mean, the only reason I brought it up is because your opinion means a lot to me, and I'm aware I have a tendency to run off at the mouth sometimes.
Is that a fact.
I suppose it's a nervous habit. I hope you don't hold it against me.
Not at all, Sir.
Oh, and one more thing.
And what would that be, Sir?
I don't think it's really necessary for you to call me "Sir."
What should I call you? You're my superior officer.
How about Julian.
Is that an order?
Of course not. I'd simply prefer it if you called me by my first name.
All right. We've achieved stable orbit around Bajor. We can beam down any time... Julian.
No sign of any airborne infections, the soil appears free of pollutants, and the ground water's clear of bacterial contamination.
Gentlemen...
I'm Doctor Bashir and this is Chief O'Brien.
This village is in great jeopardy. I only hope you're not too late.
Has he shown any sign of improvement?
None.
You must help him.
How many others are sick?
Others?
You said the entire village was in jeopardy?
It is. (looking down at the old man) If he dies, we all die.
I'll say this for the Cardassians. Their replicators make a fine larish pie.
I didn't come here to eat, Commander.
Then let's talk. The official negotiations won't begin until tonight, but I thought it might be a good idea for us to meet informally to see where we all stand.
According to the treaty that has existed between you for the past ninety years... "... the border separating the Paqu and the Navot shall forever be the river Glyrhond."
That's correct.
Well, at least we all agree on something.
Now, as I understand it, during the occupation the Cardassians diverted the river for use in their mining operations. As a result the Glyrhond now flows twenty kilometers west of its former position.
Twenty kilometers into Navot territory.
It's Paqu territory now. You read the treaty Commander. The river is our common border.
The treaty says nothing about stealing land. If your father was alive he'd give us back what was ours.
My father would have done no such thing. Besides, I'm Tetrarch now. I will not be pressured into betraying my people.
Let's see, one glass of Gamzian wine, two Bajoran synthales... And a Trixian bubble juice for the little lady.
I'm not a little lady.
I'm still charging her for that drink.
Nog, we've been sitting here over an hour. Let's go play some ball in the Holosuite.
No.
Why not?
Because baseball is slow and boring...
And you can't hit my curve ball.
It's a stupid game that even humans stopped playing hundreds of years ago.
Maybe. But you still can't hit my curve ball.
Mister Sisko...
Nog, I thought I told you no dangling over the Promenade.
We're not gonna fall, Odo.
We can see things better from down here.
And what, may I ask, is so important to see?
Nothing.
In that case, you can see "nothing" just as well from up here. Now, on your feet.
Thank you.
Are you gonna come to the Holosuite with me or not? We can have Buck Bokai hit a few out to us. He was the greatest hitter of all time. I'll even let you use my glove.
I've never seen anything so beautiful.
She's all right.
All right? I have to meet her.
The Dal'Rok...
Easy now. Try not to exert yourself.
Hovath, the time... ?
Still two hours before nightfall.
You should have woken me. Help me get dressed.
I'm afraid you're in no shape to go anywhere.
The prophets sent you, didn't they.
I beg your pardon?
No... Something's wrong. It must be your companion.
You mean Chief O'Brien?
Bring him to me.
Why?
Because you are not the one I've been waiting for.
Chief... he wants to see you.
Come closer.
I knew the prophets wouldn't fail us. You may leave now... Both of you.
See that he stays in bed.
What was that all about?
I haven't a clue.
The Sirah... how is he?
I wish I had better news. He's suffering from systemic organ failure brought on by an accelerated rate of cellular decay... his body is surrendering to old age.
Is there anything you can do?
I can keep him comfortable and relatively free of pain. Other than that, it's only a matter of time. I'm sorry.
But we need him. The Dal'Rok will be here soon.
What's the Dal'Rok?
It's a terrible creature that lives in the woods just north of the village. Every year at the end of harvest it appears.
And you say it's coming tonight.
Yes, it always comes for five nights. This will be the fourth. And only the Sirah is strong enough to defeat it.
Right now, the Sirah isn't strong enough to get out of bed.
If what you say is true, this village will be destroyed tonight.
You're sure this is the place?
You saw the readout. There's only one female her age visiting the station, and these are her quarters.
Well go ahead.
What?
Ring the bell.
Me? You're the one who wants to meet her.
Are you afraid?
Of a girl.
Then ring.
You ring.
You are afraid.
No I'm not, you are.
What are you doing?
My name's Jog... I mean Jake.
He's Nog. I'm Jake Sisko.
Sisko...
We're kinda the unofficial welcoming committee around here.
That's right... Welcome to DS Nine.
Thank you. I'm Varis Sul.
Would you like a tour of the station? There's a Klingon freighter leaving for the Gamma Quadrant in a little while. We could watch it go through the wormhole.
Good idea.
21 CONTINUED:
I've never seen the wormhole.
Then you're in luck. We know the best spot on the station for wormhole watching.
Unless you're too busy or something...
Not at the moment.
Then let's go.
Listen to me, Sirah. You must return to bed. To be out here... in your condition...
Your concern touches me, Doctor. But I'm in the hands of the prophets.
Strange. I'm not registering any atmospheric disturbance...
The Dal'Rok wakes.
The Dal'Rok... the Dal'Rok...
We are ready.
Yes... we're ready... the Dal'Rok...
In the shadows of the night he hungers... With the hatred of the ancients he rages... From the twisted pit of chaos he approaches...
The Dal'Rok... the Dal'Rok... it's here...
Is it alive?
The tricorder's still not registering anything.
Could it be some kind of holographic image?
I'm not picking up any power source.
The Dal'Rok's anger is like a wave crashing down on the village.
Yes... the anger... a wave... we feel it.
The weight of its fury threatens to crush us all. The Dal'Rok thinks the village is powerless to defend itself.
But the Dal'Rok is mistaken. The village is strong. Much stronger than the Dal'Rok can ever imagine.
Yes... the village... the village is strong.
Our strength... our unity... shall drive... the Dal'Rok...
The Sirah... Is he hurt... Look out... The Dal'Rok...
Bloody hell.
Chief, help me get him down from here.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Where is my successor?
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Sirah...
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: The one the prophets sent.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Wait a second, you've got the wrong guy.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Say as I say... the village shall not be destroyed.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: What?
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Quickly.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: The village shall not be destroyed.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Louder. So they can all hear.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: The village shall not be destroyed.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Despite our fears, we stand our ground and face the Dal'Rok.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Despite our fears, we stand our ground and face the Dal'Rok.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Stand fast. Face the Dal'Rok.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: The village is strong.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: The village is strong.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: More powerful than the Dal'Rok.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: More powerful than the Dal'Rok.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Together we use that power to drive it away.
scene: 35   EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE - THE PLATFORM - NIGHT

quote: Drive it away.
